author: Obama Bin Laden
review: AMD 6000 SERIES GPU USERS PLEASE READ!Amazing Game! 9/10 it works with 2 controllers playing co-op on the same PC. Issue: Now the only issue had was during the Wasp Level as well as cut scenes there is these black shade that cover the floor and flicker. The game has an issue with 6000 series GPU making the game run on DX11 instead of DX12.Solution: In Game Settings -> Display -> VSync OFF -> Apply SettingsSolution: In Steam Library -> Find 'It Takes 2' & Right-Click -> Properties -> General -> Under Launch Options type "-dx12" (without the " " )There's many other solutions online such as editing the exe file using CMD, as well downloading and replacing a file within the directory, but I found this to be the easiest solution. Please like this review if it help you for others to see.

author: Latón
review: I don't even know where to start to describe this game. Heartwarming, funny, amazing. From start to finish, it was an absolute blast to play and discover every interact-able inside the different scenarios. All the puzzles were pretty well integrated into the level designs. The best part is, regardless of which character you play, both have so much to do,Graphics were absolutely gorgeous, all the different worlds were just full of color.Game-play wise, very easy to control as most of it is just one button for actions.Achievements are easy to get 100%, only a few are some you actively have to seek out but otherwise just progress through the story.Absolutely worth playing this game 10/10!

author: Alpha2749
review: Josef, You've done it again!It Takes Two is absolutely fantastic. The link between story and game-play is honestly unlike any other game (Apart from A Way Out) I've played. From travelling through white water rapids, to being kidnapped by giant squirrels, the story and game-play never gets old or ceases to amaze. Just for some background; at it's core, It Takes Two is a story-driven, 2-player co-op puzzle game, with game-play that genuinely never stops changing. The main game is split into 'chapters' where each chapter let's you play around and solve puzzles with different gadgets. As well as sometimes throwing completely different types of games at you ranging from street fighter to rhythm game. Even without the story, if you enjoy puzzle games, this will be a blast, and a lot of fun. The story however, ties it all together so well that it just blends it into one amazing masterpiece!With a single play-through time of about 12 hours- The game managing to stay new and fresh throughout- And a great story to tie it all together, this game is Absolutely Brilliant!

author: FixxxeR
review: I was convinced to buy this by my eight year old daughter, without looking into what exactly it was, and since we're playing a lot more games together, I took a punt and got it.I was not expecting such an excellent coop experience. It Takes Two is a super casual game, but it's extremely varied and much longer than I thought it was going to be. The puzzles and challenges are fun, accessible, quick to pickup and the game at times forces you to work together, in such a way that it never seems like one player has more fun or a more interesting task than the other. The variety of gadgets you get along the way is also another highlight, you always get something different to your partner, and these tools usually require you to work together again.There are times you're against each other too, in the minigames you find along the way; some better than others, but there is a full version of chess, races, shooting type games - the usual sort of mini-game fare.The story/plot is pretty simple but centers around the reasonably grown-up topic of divorce... I found that, because the game is so long, with so many sentimental moments, I actually found myself getting invested in Cody and May's future. Maybe I'm getting old and soft, but there are sections of the game that are purposely made into sort of 'profound' type moments, where you'll be flying through an amazing place or running away from something and the point is that you should be just enjoying these moments together - there is no real challenge or threat - these were just cool, memorable moments for you and whoever you're playing with to enjoy. You don't see that often in video games, to be honest, I've only experienced this a handful of times in many, many years of gaming.Visually the whole style of the game looks amazing, with lots of highly detailed, interesting fun characters you meet along your journey. The detail on the main characters in particular is fantastic.There are various chapters to the game that are all entirely different, and each of the environments are interesting and detailed. They usually have something to interact with for no other reason other than to mess around or get hidden achievements etc so in certain areas you end up exploring and procrastinating.In summary, It Takes Two is a unique coop game, that sticks to a coop style throughout - it works really well and I'd say this was a rare gem of a game. If you have a close friend or family member that'd play through this one with you - do it.

author: katie_chiu
review: Overall 9->7/10 (goes down as you play the whole thing)It's a fun game at first and exciting to work together with new powers.  I played with my partner and we have decent gaming experience.  We still fell down random holes, but the platforming wasn't difficult at all.  However, I have a few issues with the game.1) It's too long. While it was fun initially, the game peaks in chapter 5(? or 6, the wizard level).  We played the last 4 chapters just to finish the game.  The last chapter is especially anticlimactic, and doesn't compare to the excitement from chapter 5.2) The abilities are repetitive.  I think the developers intentionally gave the female character the more aggressive abilities and the male character the supportive abilities in the teamwork.  While I appreciate the sentiment (as I do usually support in other games), it was tiring for both of us to be supporting and waiting for the female to do all the jumping by chapter 6.3) The narrative on divorce is (???)4) Cutie.  I am traumatized forever.Would still recommend as the game is well made and pretty unique.  It's super beginner friendly and probably more exciting for pairs that don't game so often.

author: skmccord
review: PROSAmazing graphics, setting design, music choices, and creativity overall. Each section had new weapons, controls are tight and rewarding, and puzzles aren't too hard or too easy. CONSYou get to play as a husband and wife who are nasty to each other and always putting the other down. They constantly make side comments throughout the game insulting the other. They are completely unlikable and I honestly would prefer it if they didn't speak. I dropped a ball during a task on accident and the other character said "Hey, butterfingers pay attention" automatically. They just have insults ready to go! There is a magic book that is kinda annoying that is driving the plot and always around.Spoiler AND THE REASON I STOPPED PLAYINGYour characters assume they need to get their daughter to cry to reverse their curse. They don't ask the magic book and just assume the best course of action is to destroy her favorite toy to make her cry. One of her other toys tries to stop them because he says he's her protector but you blow him up. You get into the castle, get thrown in jail, and break out and kill any guards in your way. Then, you drag this cute sentient elephant that sounds like a little girl over to the side of a tower to throw her off. She screams and cries the whole time asking why you can't be friends, asking what she did wrong, and pleading with them to let her go and she would hug them and make them cookies. You rip her arm and her ear off in the process of dragging her and, ignoring her screams, throw her on over the edge.The parents then dance and laugh while their daughter cries and find out that that isn't how to break the curse. Nope! Didn't have to do any of the crazy malicious things they did.

I've rarely seen developers put so much creativity and passion into a game as in this one. 10/10

author: Maah
review: For me, the best part of It takes two was the game mechanics. There are so many, and they're so different. Even if you don't like one as much, you'll like the other and you'll wondering what next power your characters will get. I played as May and I liked most of mine.Then, there's the second best part of the game, which are the characters. I love how much of a badass May is and how gentle Cody is. You can tell by their interactions that they know each other very well and know how to pick on one another lol So seeing the two of them together through the game was really enjoyable. If I may say, I thought the ending was a bit rushed and I wish there was one more "mission" before it. The whole game is beautiful and I liked the story, but I felt like there was a small part of it missing at the end of the game. Still, I guess this is a solid 8/10 game for me. I had lots of fun playing with my boyfriend as my counterpart (and although the game was about a couple making amends, me and him fought many times at a few points lol Simply magical) and it was, overall, an experience I'll treasure!

author: Hound Fluff

author: Dusk
review: Ok, so, I have mixed feelings on this one.  I played this exclusively with one other person, and I played as May.To be totally fair, I understand why this game is as popular as it is.  It's got incredible mechanics, there are times where they throw the visual style and take it to gorgeous extremes.  It also never gets dull, as the game is constantly throwing new mechanics at you and swapping out the old ones roughly around the time where they outstay their welcome.  It does a little too much handholding on the controls for my tastes(yes, for the 100th time, I know F grapples objects), but given the amount of mechanics that this game throws at you, I can totally understand why they decided to tell the players what button does what every time any interaction comes up.  The variety of the minigames is also really good and pretty well paced out to give you a break from the campaign nature of the game of going from point A to point B.Now, for the minor downsides.  You need to make an EA account to play this, that does annoy me.  But it's an EA game, so whatever, I got over it.  I initially had some issues launching the game at all, but apparently something went wrong with the initial installation.  Uninstalling and reinstalling the game got around that issues and the two of us had very few technical issues throughout the rest of the game.  As for some of the sections.  I don't understand what control scheme you are supposed to use for this.  Both me and my friend used KBM, which I feel really served us well in the shooter portions of this, but some of the isometric and top down sections really did not suit themselves to the KBM control scheme.  There were portions where I had to hold down W and tap D to really get the correct average direction to not fall of bridges, not to mention the dash had really weird angles to try and land on the correct platform.  My partner also appeared to be having similar problems with the teleporting mechanic, but I can't comment too much on that because I didn't play Cody(and I'm not planning on going back to this to do so).All of that would be fine, and the upsides far outweigh what I've posted so far.  The issue is the story.  Oh boy the story is... how do I put this?  You know that meme that was going around where people would constantly say "Better love story than Twilight"?  Well, I can't make any comparisons to Twilight, never saw it you see.  But you could take every one of those memes and put the text "Better love story than It Takes Two" and it would absolutely be correct.The story was kind of "meh" at the start.  Ok, two people who are getting divorced get Isekai'd into dolls and basically a world created by their past mistakes.  We have a weird "antagonist"(although not really?  This game doesn't have a true antagonist, which is another problem in of itself) of a book that has them going through challenges to get them back together for love or whatever.  They go through and try to figure out how to return to normal.  For some reason Cody "figures out" that since Rose's(their daughter) tears caused them to go into this world, they must be the key to get them back, so they run off and try to get their daughter to cry on them so that they can go back to normal.  It's a really weird leap of logic and the characters honestly have no reason to assume that this is true.  Spoilers from this point on.Then they get to the castle level.  Rose has a toy castle that they get to, and they decide the the best way to get Rose to cry is to kill the queen of the castle.  Queen Cutie, Rose's toy elephant.  They go up to the elephant, and brutally destroy her, limbs ripping off and Cutie begging for her life.  This goes on for maybe... 2 minutes or more?  All with both players needing to press buttons to continue the sequence.  May and Cody are horrific people for doing this, and even if the rest of the story would have been tolerable, it is all soured by the fact that THIS is the first thing that they agreed they should do.  They did comment that they felt like horrible people, but neither of them even remotely thought "Hey, maybe we shouldn't be doing this?" and that speaks volumes of their characters.  Shocker, Rose's tears don't work, and they are stuck as dolls.  They deserve it.And then they go to therapy.  It's whatever, probably would be pretty decent if it wasn't completely overshadowed by the previous scene.  It ultimately boils down to Cody and Rose need to find their passion or whatever.  It's from this point that I will take a break from what is going on to our two "protagonists", and describe how Rose has been seeing all of this.  Everything has basically been life as normal for Rose, she's more or less been left all on her own and trying to deal with the fact that her parents are getting divorced.  Her age is never stated I don't think, but she's like 10 maybe?  Her parents bodies are still in the house, but they are just kinda sleeping for Rose, she's got no idea any of this magic stuff is happening to her parents.  She goes to her dad and he's just sitting upright at his desk, just sitting there with his eyes closed.  She tells her dad about the book she's gotten and she thinks it would help the marriage.  Her dad doesn't respond(for reasons obvious to the players) and Rose eventually leave, but what really stands out to me is that Rose never left the entrance of the room to go and actually see him.  This all happened with Rose talking to her dad from the doorway.  She eventually leaves the room, but she never approaches her dad.  She also does the same thing with her mom as her mom is sleeping on the couch.  Rose leaves her alone because her mom must "have that headache again".  She does approach her mom to play her favorite song when she finds the vinyl recorder up in the attic, but Rose takes a look at what is going on(and has been going on since almost the start of the game) and makes the conclusion that she is the cause of the divorce and runs away from home.  Like what?  Ok, I can understand that she's not entirely thinking clearly because her parents told her that they are getting divorced, but shortly after that, both of your parents completely stop responding to the outside world, and she doesn't consider that they might be sick or injured?  She has conversations with them were they(from her POV) are *completely* ignoring her and have gone catatonic, and she doesn't think that something is horribly wrong with them?  The only way that I would believe that to be true would be if she has been neglected for a very, VERY long time.  And that just makes me consider that it might be better if she were to run away to a friend's house or something.  At least then she might be able to get some help.  Just utterly heartbreaking how this implies what's been going on before the game even started.Returning to Rose and Cody(what? did you think my complaints about the story were done yet? Almost) they are going through therapy, slowly learning to get along again, but the real kicker for me is the final cutscene.  It is revealed(or at least HEAVILY implied) that the only way that Cody and May could possibly get back to normal is to kiss.  I will be honest, I was furious with the game after that scene.  I know somebody who was in an abusive relationship.  Like a real life threatening situation she was in.  So what, somebody like that is just ♥♥♥♥♥♥ in the situation that this game brings up?  Honestly, if some people go through this scenario, the right call could EASILY be to stay that way, and run from your abuser never to return.  Once you make it even a few houses over, you would never be found by your so called "partner", and the abuser would effectively be dead in the real world, never to prey on anyone else.It's a real shame.  To have such fantastic visuals and mechanics linked to such an abysmally bad story.  This game is the worst tragedy I have ever seen in every way.

author: Woargh
review: One of the very best games in my opinion!Note; You need to create a free EA account, download Origin (which happens at first game launch) and you need a buddy to play with since there is no in-game multiplayer system.I can go on and on about what's great in this game. Its near perfect! The grapchis are amazing, sweet and playful. The gameplay is creative, casual and everchanging. The story is deep, powerful and heartwarmning. I played the game with an Xbox One controller and the controls were on point! This game really is worth every single penny and that says a lot with the current price-tag, but you can get it at a heavy discount at times.Downsides with this game? I don't like that it can be hard to figure out when there is a checkpoint, so the gameplay will be saved, plus the fact that you can't just save manually. Also not a big fan of the whole needing an EA account and that it is not possible to find a Player Two in-game. Its a bit sad, that they haven't implimented that.Stuff worth knowing besides above info? You can play with a friend via Friend's Pass, but one of you need the full game. Only the person with the full game version will unlock achievements. If both players own the full game, both players will unlock achievements simultaneously.All achievements are super easy, as is the whole game. A very relaxing, causal gameplay with lots of elements to keep you interested and entertained for hours!

review: One of the best games I've ever played, and certainly the best two-player cooperative game I've played. Everything is incredibly polished, much more so than in A Way Out. It's actually surprising how little some of the mechanics are used for given how good they feel.

author: Wildt
review: I'm writing this review on behalf of my two girls, aged 10 and 13. They absolutely loved it, and completed the game twice so that they could try all the levels with both characters.Sitting on the sidelines, the game really impressed me with extremely polished and variying visuals. Amazing texture work, lighting and 3d models.Gameplay wise it's a fairly simple platform action puzzler, with strong emphasis on teamwork. But even though the mechanics never get very complicated, they constantly change throughout the game, as the two characters get new abilities that synergize together.I didn't do my homework in regards to the story, so the subject of divorce hit a little too close to home. It's well told, and gets quite emotional at times.Now I have to go try and find a worthy follow up game for them to play - and that's a tall order!

author: Dylster
review: This is game is one of the more excellent games I've played in my time. Josef Fares and his team at Hazelight Studios have once again made a staple in the co-op gaming genre. If you have never played one of their games before; you actually  a second person to play this. They swiftly cut-out any issues with this as only one person needs to purchase the game, while the other can install the "Friend Pass" and be invited to play with no extra cost. Amazing! The game itself is excellent with so many concepts and ideas utilized to create a fantastic co-op experience. As usual with Hazelight, you'll play upwards of 4-5 different genres of games within this story. From 3rd person action-adventure, to fighting game, to hack-and-slash, to rpg, to top-down, etc. etc. There's no shortness of fun and exciting new ways to keep you playing. This game is a bit longer then Hazelight's previous development; A Way Out, which is certainly welcome. Especially because the game never feels like it is taking too long or putting in little effort... If anything, you may feel like you are going too fast in some of the glorious-looking and creative environments you and your partner will be in. I can't recommend this game enough, it is worth every penny it is asking for. Buy it!!!

author: leorean

This was simply *not* possible. After sending each other friend requests, noone had received them, and thats that. We ended up playing with the steam "remote play" option, which sucks, because the input lags, the quality is impacted, the game is in split-screen mode...TL;DR: Coop circumstances are a big disappointment thanks to EA / Origin and f**ks up the whole experience. Too bad..(I'm open to help/suggestions at this point, so if anyone knows how to fix this, please shout)

author: Catholicism
review: Gameplay-☑ Very good☐ Good☐ Nothing special☐ Okay☐ BadGraphics-☐ Masterpiece☑ Beautiful☐ Good☐ Will do☐ Bad☐ AwfulAudio☐ Amazing☑ Very good☐ Good☐ Decent☐ Not too bad☐ BadAudience☐ Kids☑ Teens☑ Adults☐ EveryoneStory-☑ Lovely☐ Good☐ Average☐ Not great☐ NoneDifficult-☐ Just press a bunch of buttons☐ Easy☑ Significant brain usage☐ Easy to learn / Hard to master☐ Not so easy☐ Difficult☐ Dark SoulsGrind-☑ Nothing☐ Only if you care about leaderboards/ranks☐ Isnt necessary to progress☐ A bit grindy sometimes☐ Average grind level☐ Too much grind☐ InsanityGame Time-☐ Short☑ Average☐ Long☐ Depends on you☐ EndlessPrice☑ 100% buy it☐ Worth the price☐ Wait for sale☐ Maybe if you have some spare money left☐ Not recommendedThis was such a beautifully done game. The devs really poured their heart and soul into the story, the levels and the design. Every new level had something different to do and just when you thought the mechanics would carry over to the next level, new mechanics were introduced that made the game a million times more fun than it had been moments ago.The game requires two people (obviously) and the person you choose to play with really needs to be willing to work with you rather than against you. There needs to be a lot of communication between the two of you for the game to work, but once you get it, you're smoothly sailing. I've never played a game that I enjoyed so much and would HIGHLY recommend this for anyone looking to play with a friend/sibling/parent/SO or anything else - it does in fact.. take two.

author: Lotus
review: After developer Hazelight already offered a very entertaining coop-experience with  in 2018, they're back again with a more family-friendly 2-player game, this time with a focus on relationship and cooperation. Still, the basics remain the same: One player has to buy the game, the other one can use the "friend pass" download to play for free. And a second player is absolutely as this game simply can't be played alone; don't expect an option for an AI-controlled partner or something similar. A last heads-up: there's also no option for online-matchmaking, so you'll have to find your coop-partner by yourself.So, what can you expect after finding a coop partner and setting the game up? A surprisingly long story campaign with a lot of variety that'll have the two of you cooperate in ways you never thought about. Seriously, the biggest surprise I had with this game was probably the amount of time it lasted.  lists playtimes between 11 and 14 hours and this matches with how long it took us to beat the game. What's even more amazing is that the game rarely felt like it's getting stale despite its length, the overwhelming majority of the time always offered a new spin on things.And I mean that in more ways than one: From the gameplay to the settings or locations, this game is just bursting with ideas. To not take away any surprise, I unfortunately can't go into detail here, but the featured screenshots should already provide a small glimpse at what's waiting for you. Most of the game feels like a wild theme park ride that moves on just in time when things are about to become predictable. The abilities the two protagonists, May and Cody, can use also change at about the same pace. Sometimes each player controls one part of a magnet, sometimes each of you has a hammer while the other one has a set of nails and so on. Some of these abilities are more standard - like just having a different set of "guns" - but many are entirely unique and used accordingly.And when I say used, I mean used to traverse areas, solve puzzles and so on. Think  but constantly switching the environment and tools. Sometimes a player needs to clear obstacles for another, sometimes the two of you fight together, sometimes you just play discoverable minigames together - ranging from stuff like chess to more exciting ones like Whack-a-Mole (one player being the whacker, one the mole). This does require the players to show off various gaming skills, from aiming to platforming to beating rhythm games.This variety should not pose a problem even for less experienced players: The difficulty isn't high and there are a lot of checkpoints. Boss battles, etc. also only reset when both players die and offer a quick respawn. The game is very forgiving in that regard. However, some parts do require a tighter cooperation between both players. For example, one player might need to cross a huge gap by themselves. The only way to get across is by jumping across a few platforms. These platforms can only be moved by the second player, who constantly has to adjust their positions - or the jumping player might fall down the gap. In a case like this, it's impossible for the jumping player to offer any ingame assistance to the other player. Reloading checkpoints, etc. are not going to help either. The player controlling the platforms has to perform the required actions or the game won't continue. In cases like these, it might be preferable to play the game using local coop, so players can offer each other "real life" help.Moving on from the gameplay, let's talk plot. To keep the whole experience together, a Pixar-like story serves as the rail for the gameplay train to move on, featuring four main and a large amount of side characters. It's not a tense, more gritty experience like , it feels more like a playable Disney movie for the whole family. The message isn't particularly complex and story developments are predictable in some parts, but it features great moments that'll make both, the ingame protagonists and you + your coop-partner feel amazed. This is a game that you two might not talk that much about in regard to the general plot afterwards - but you'll definitely talk about some characters or setpieces or minigames you lost/won against the other.Lastly, I have to mention the graphics. The game offers great looking visuals, which is even more impressive considering just how many different places you are going to visit. Again, no further details because of spoilers, but expect some "wow!" moments - not only because of the used Unreal Engine 4 but because of the amazingly creative designs and setpieces. This game might not break any boundaries for videogame graphics in general but it's still a treat to look at.To conclude,  is an extremely enjoyable coop experience that offers a huge amount of variety despite it's length. It offers some great moments, locations and characters which are certainly going to get both, you and your partner, talking. Sometimes a few chapters stay a little too long and the overall story might not be somewhat predictable and not the deepest - but the overall experience is still amazing and definitely a must-play coop game.

author: Vitlök
review: I played this game with a "friend", on the couch. This review is based on both mine and her impressions of the first two hours of play.Our first issue was that we didn't like the main characters. My friend in particular was very annoyed at the sheer vitriol they have for each other. To paraphrase her: "This is a point where anything but a divorce is just cruelty to everyone involved." Like, wow, I saw my fair share of toxic families, but these guys are on a different level. Cody and Rose hate each other with a primordial passion of a thousand suns, and constantly (and I do mean constantly) nag and insult each other. And Mr Book, the guy who's supposed to make the player characters come together, is pushy and not charming at all.But hey, if the game's fun to play, we can just suffer through the cutscenes until things hopefully get better. Yeah? Well, it was quite well thought and diverse, I'll give it that. You constantly get new toys to play with and they're used and reused in interesting and creative ways. That said, I rarely felt like I'm having actual fun there. It was almost like Simon Says: figuring out what is the intended way to proceed, and then doing it in tandem with your partner. We've played a lot of coop games over the years and didn't have a lot of fun here. And finally, the biggest thing - the tone issues. The game presents itself as kid friendly. Little girl making a wish to a magical book to keep their parents together. And surely enough, that's how it starts out...And then suddenly you have to do a God of War-style execution on a boss as they What in the unholiest of hyucks is that? Don't get me wrong, I don't have a problem with brutality or viscera (to an extent): DOOM 2016 is my jam, I just beat , and I stomped the crap out of the necromorphs in Dead Space. But here this level of violence not only came out of nowhere, it completely clashed against the general tone of the game. And that's not all: later on you get locked by squirrels in a murder room, where you were expected to be killed by wasps - but instead you respawn, and die over and over again (in a cutscene). Also, for some reason there's a torture minigame - one of you gets locked in a jar, while the other one can press buttons to make the other die in horrible ways.What sort of starfish blue and orange morality is this? Oh, the game's made in Sweden? Are you guys okay? Or maybe I've been the starfish all along, considering I've never heard any complaints about what I just wrote.The game's quite pretty, that's for sure - and has this distinct aesthetic that's sure to draw people in. If I had to guess, the popularity of this game comes from the fact that it has this AA/AAA level of production values, and there aren't a lot of coop games of that magnitude. Also, it's published by EA, which grants it massive reach and some top shelf marketing. But the okay-ish gameplay, annoying writing and horrifying tonal issues completely negate any and all goodwill I've had for this game.I'll give it one thing: it improved my relationship by showing me that both me and my partner are sensitive to the same things. But it also revealed to me just how desensitised people are to acts of cruelty. Hope that helps.

author: KnightDragon13PVP
review: This game has such a gorgeous art style and setting design, with such an unique story line, I really can't stress how much I enjoyed the game, however I just can't recommend it right now because the game crashes at the same spot (Pirate's ahoy) in the game every time I play it, so I can't progress any further than where I am now. I had this problem earlier on in the story line but It went away on reopening the game. (The issue that I "Can't connect to EA servers" even though my network is strong and everything else on my end looks fine)Until this issue is fixed I can't say I recommend, as I don't want someone else to spend money only to not be able to progress any further than a certain point in the game. author: nitro

author: kyobi
review: Had a BLAST playing this. 15 hours of co-operation really does test friendships, as it's a game you absolutely cannot complete without working together. The developers really paid amazing attention to detail, and the visual sequences and level designs were stunning. Both myself, and my friend have a whole folder of screenshots dedicated to some of the scenes. It would've been amazing if the game play was choice based, and how you worked together affected the ending (either staying together or getting a divorce). Overall though I would recommend this to everyone, and if you don't have someone to play it with then find someone in the community groups that's also looking for another player. It's a great game that could create new friendships, strengthen your current ones, or completely destroy some depending on how much you might rage at the other person dying lol

author: pokashine
review: I can't even sum up my experience of this masterpiece without feeling like I'm doing it an injustice.It is SO. G*DD*AMN. GOOD!The creativity... the genius. The... AUDACITY to release such a ingenious game in this day and age!My GF and I played it.Then we finished it.Then we went back to unlock every mini game.Then we played those mini games for hours.Then we wished we could erase our memories of the gameplay and play it again.Then we cursed the fact that there isn't a It Takes Two, Too (2) out.Then we pulled out hair out because we haven't heard any work of a second game.I want to forget everything so I can play it blind again.Get it.It doesn't matter if it's not on sale.It doesn't matter if it is on sale.If you have ANYONE you can play with; partner, friend, sibling, parent... whatever.ANY excuse to play this game, DO IT!Do yourself a huge favor and PLAE DIS GAEM!!!

author: Sändra
review: ein wunderschönes spiel! die animation, die story und der sound gestalten das spiel so emotional das ich mehrfach zum taschentuch greifen musste. die minigames haben mich sehr genervt, solange ich verloren habe, aber sind ebenfalls liebevoll und abwechslungsreich. große empfehlung für alle die zufällig einen freund oder eine freundin haben sollten, mit dem man das spiel spielen können :)

author: Hedvika
review: There will always be a hole in my heart where couch co-op used to be, but this game really did a nice job of filling it. Fantastically made co-op with quality camera-work, the screen shifts from split screen to one screen seamlessly, it's honestly fantastic; You barely notice the transition until you're next to your partner. Story-wise it kept me wanting to play it, I was driven to keep playing so I could get to the end! Along the way were fun mini-games, hilarious easter eggs/references, and almost a showcase of every genre you could expect; like a testament to the skill of the developers. If you're looking for a charming story with incredible gameplay to enjoy with someone else, definitely pick this up.

author: Egg Chief
review: It Takes Two is a wonderful coop game that you need a friend/partner to play, the game does not have a single player mode. Thankfully you don't both need to buy the game, if one of you owns It Takes Two then the other can download a free version of the game and join you through that. It's mainly a platformer game, but it switches between a ton of different genres throughout its run. Game length is anywhere from 8-14 hours, my partner and I did a 100% run and that took us a total of 11.8 hours. The story is very light-hearted with quite a bit of adult humor thrown in there, the game also does have some genuine dark moments. Every chapter in the game has it's own gimmick that you need to deal with till the end of the chapter. Overall I'd say nearly every chapter is relatively fun! Sadly the last chapter is the only chapter in the game that didn't entertain my lover and I. The last chapter feels rather rushed, but the mediocre chapter is followed up by a touching finale in the form of multiple cutscenes. My lover and I both agreed that it's roughly an 8/10 game. I'd recommend playing it in small bursts of 1-3 hours at a time and just taking it slow.

author: MaximumADHD
review: I don't think I've ever been so emotionally touched by a game in my life. I constantly found myself with a huge stupid smile on my face, just absolute shocked at how much joy I was getting out of it. Not only is this one of the most beautiful polished games I have ever played, but it also unlocked a child-like sense of wonder and amazement in me that I hadn't felt in such a long time. The co-op mechanics are brilliant with an incredibly rich diversity of different mechanics and puzzles. There's just so much incredible technology and small details poured into every inch of this game.It took me a long time to find someone willing to finish it all the way through with me, and I did everything in my power to avoid spoiling myself to anything prior to completing it. If you have not played this game, play it through to the end without revealing any of it to yourself. The experience is that much better if you play it blind. I am so happy to have finally completed this, and I just want to give my sincerest thanks to everyone who made this game happen. It was an incredible heartwarming experience and I can't imagine anything else out there topping it.

author: Jer Berus
review: BOY-GIRL CO-OP recommended.  There are two playable characters: A husband and a wife.There are 25 mini-games, including a Chess mini-game (don't forget to pick "infinite time" while playing chess.)  It even allows the "En Passant" move!!!  My Polish friend was flabbergasted when I did it, thinking that I had cheated or something.  No.  It's just "En Passant".  I then sent her the Polish Wikipedia page about it.This is such a lovely tale of a couple at the breaking point and their counselling/therapy.  I really, really recommend this for couples and boy/girl friends as a co-op.

review: This is the best game I have ever played. The story is good. The artistry on display evokes wonder, euphoria and childlike glee at every turn. Level design is fantastic. There is a new traversal or combat mechanic introduced in every level. There are even entire game genre's paid homage to throughout. I couldn't wait to see what was next every time I started playing. Communication is a must have here. You can't truly play without a buddy, and you can't beat it without being completely in tune with your co op partner. This is a high fiving, gut busting, nail biting good time, and I can say I feel like a better person for having played it.  10/10

The story is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ amazing as well, I had tears in my eyes by the end of it. My steam says that I only played this games 11 hours, but it feel so much longer, thats how rich the game is. author: VLADOSAUR
review: I gotta vent first. Origin, which is very unstable was forced not only to me who bought this game but also to the person I played this with. So the whole 'Friend's Pass' thing makes 0️⃣ sense. And even when I made everything as needed for it to work, it didn't. Boooo EA, boo forever! There were also plenty of places on the map the characters got stuck but that's a minor issue.The thing that is special in this game is all about the gameplay elements that are constantly introduced, similar to how Nintendo does in 'Super Mario' games. They are unfortunately sometimes too short for a player to enjoy but the diversity of them makes up for that. You can catch yourself asking "Oh, what now?!" during the play, and that's a good thing here as it keeps it fresh and inviting. I would rave about the graphic but with the GPU prices, I'm stuck with the gtx 10xx that had a hard time keeping up with this game even at low settings. But I've seen it played on max settings on better PCs and it's gorgeous! So the co-op aspect, gameplay mechanics, and great overall graphics definitely check out. What didn't check out are the characters that I simply could NOT stand. I recall calling their daughter Sméagol every time she would pop up and do some dumb thing... Like Jeniffer... gurl, your parents are in a coma (probably) and you're running away from home, tf(?)! The same goes for the parents and Hakim. Lawd, I felt like they all deserved a ♥♥♥♥♥ slap! NOT Cutie III, Queen of the Magic Castle. Oh no, she didn't deserve a thing we were forced to do to her.In the end, it somehow felt underwhelming. The cheesy story met with the heavy subject didn't help. I legit sat there when the rushed end just happened and felt let down with the anticlimatic vibe. Still, would I play it again for the joy of the gameplay and the art? You betcha! There are tons of fun mini-games to explore and 'It Takes Two' is, despite all the issues one of the best couch co-op games in recent years.

review: There seems to be nothing brilliant, but the dynamics, idea and design are excellent.  Only you are bored with one mechanic, how it changes to another 😄 In the end, the game slows down a little, you feel that the gameplay of the end of the game was done just to finish the story.  This is felt in the last chapter, it is already hard to go through. We finished in three sets, but overall very cool. The best game about CO-LA-BO-RATION.

author: Severely Artistic
review: Played it through with my close friend. Well deserved Game of the Year. Let me first preface this with saying this is not a game meant for kids. Concepts like divorce and the effects it has on children is not for the faint of heart. The infamous "elephant scene" is viewed to be dark and turned a number of people away from recommending this game to others, but in my opinion those individuals overlooked the bigger picture of what the scene was meant to offer in terms of the story and the player's views on the overall narrative. That's not what I'm going to make as the topic of my review however. You can find a more in depth explanation on a 30 minute YouTube video essay or something like that.That aside, the game has a well-written narrative backed by incredibly unique game-play. Every level feels different from the previous and offers an experience not found in many other games being developed in recent times. I don't want to spoil anything in particular. So, to say the least, It Takes Two succeeds in offering a unique spin on the Platformer genre not found in other games developed in recent times.Level design is generally linear and easy to play through. I can't say I struggled with the game or really had any frustrating moments, although some parts did require a bit of finesse to get through. Overall very intuitive and easy to get a hang of alongside some small mini-games thrown here and there to compete with whoever you're playing with. They don't do anything to the story, just offers something random and fun to do every now and then. It Takes Two succeeds in all aspects of a co-op game. It is possible to play through one sitting, although it would be a very long sitting, with an average of 12-14 hours to complete. I guarantee whoever you're playing with whether it's a friend or a significant other that you'll have a joyful experience and take something away from it at the end.

author: Nunchimunchi
review: Highly recommend this game~! Played this in co-op and it was an absolute blast! Loved the little mini-games within the game and exploring everything around to find lil nooks and interactive crannies of the game as well (not to mention the commentary on the little things too between the two main characters). All-in-all, a very greatly made game and very enjoyable solo or with a friend.Only issues I have about this, is the signing in to play (Why make it so difficult to log-in or play the game even though it's available on Steam? Not to mention the creating of an account with both Origin and EA -.- ). This took a long time to set up initially and we ended up giving up the first time around trying to sort things out so we could play. Tried again the next day, and everything seemed to work much better. If this game could be made available through steam and only steam (no extra game launchers or accounts needed), it would make it much more easier for the player their self to enjoy getting into it better. Other than that, a wonderful game and enjoyable to play throughout it~!

It was very enjoyable finding the easter eggs and exploring each part of the map. I love the way the devs changed up the abilities regularly. Highly recommend.

author: Priazol
review: This is a great game to play with someone else, well you need someone else to play it with... But no worrries you get a friend pass for a person you would like to invite to play, so only one person needs to buy the game! Luckily I played with a great person who also didn't want to rush the game. We both didn't have time to play often, so we played once a week at times. And to confuse ourselves a little more we switched the characters each time we played again - it was funny to get used to one side of the screen again. I liked that there were lots of details in the game and you could tell there is a lot of love behind the game design. Storywise it was really interesting and well transmitted. ,,It takes two" became a sentence I frequently used with the person I played with to joke about something and it actually relates to good situations. Various jump 'n runs, 1v1's against each other, boss fights or solving small puzzles made everything more enjoyable. BUT of course it also helps strengthen a relationship. I was not too close with a friend when we started playing, but because it also needs communication, patience and sometimes a lot of patience ;) - it definitely helps in that way. Especially at the end of the game we took enough time to finish it. The 3d chess game was lots of fun, so we ended up playing it for some hours. One short moment of respect to a particular character:Rest in peace cute little elephant.Overall:I recommend this game to everyone who likes good puzzles, to play with a friend, to have a great time, to play mini-games and listen to a talking book with a neat accent.

author: Shrike
review: You are presented with a wide variety of stimulating graphics, encompassing many different environments which all challenge the players to hink out of the box and to work together in order to move onto the next segment.A gripping storyline with relatable characters that make you think twice.The mechanics are nothing short of superb, intricate detail is put into every frame and there is almost always something with which to interact.The game is brilliant regardless of if you are searching for mindless entertainment or something more mentally stimulating.There are some mind bending areas which will leave you wanting more as you move into the next awesome puzzle.This game has a huge variety of different experiences and mechanics, you will sure to be entertained from the moment you hit play. The storyline does follow themes of romance, but it doesn't get in your face at all.Grab a player 2, whether its a friend or your romantic partner and enjoy!

author: wandering_ent
review: Very fun and enjoyable game for couples (or anyone looking for a story co-op). Diverse gameplay, minigames, and challenges presented in each chapter. I love all the little nuances.As seen in the trailer, there is a spider section and it's somewhat time consuming (not terribly long but also not a short hop). If you can, I recommend playing this section with someone else or taking/giving the controller to the other player.Unfortunately my SO has bad arachnophobia and since we played online, we pushed through and it soured the whole level/game night. I haven't encountered any other possible triggers in regards to phobias specifically and if there were, it seemed short lived.There is a possible seizure trigger in a section of  It is exactly what it sounds like. The last section of the game is also rather trippy.It would've been nice to skip these sections if possible as neither contained much to the overall story. It was just game mechanics that were used once and never again.(I put spoilers just in case but I also kept it rather vague.)But I was intrigued by the fun mechanics and gameplay more than anything as opposed to the story. Despite all that was said above, it really is a solid and fun game for anyone looking for a story-driven co-op game. There unfortunately aren't many games out there like this so if you've got a friend or a loved one to play with, I highly recommend giving this a shot.I do wish there were more easter eggs. I was constantly looking for hidden areas. Gimme my eggs.

author: Zekii
review: Hands down, the best  experience I ever had in 15 years of gaming.Even though the game may look "casual" I think that it's actually better to have a little experience in games in general to really appreciate the game at its fullest. Not that it's hard, but not being comfortable with a controller can be confusing with all the variety of gameplay introduced.Except from that, all the different mechanics are just SO MUCH FUN ! They are easy to learn, the pace at which they change, the originality of them, EVERYTHING is exceptionnally well done !Few things to note:  - My friend's game (the Friend Pass) took 2-3 minutes to starts for some reason.  - The game force the split screen, which I personally liked, to explore and view his PoV or just to collaborate.  - Our highscore in the baseball game is 40, you know, just sayin'  - The entire game took  hours to complete (if that matters to you)I usually never leave a review, but It Takes Two is just surreal, the easiest 10/10 I ever gave !

author: MizManFryinP🍳
review: Let me prefix this by saying this game is NOT for kids. Don't get it to play with your kids.Visually speaking the game is one of the best I've seen. There is great understanding of color, composition and visual story telling that is very much felt throughout the game. The game plays mechanically as well as it looks visually. The puzzles are fun and creative and characters feel agile and responsive. Playing the characters feels like playing Mario to me personally.However. This game is *not* for kids, despite its PG12 rating. 98% of the game is absolutely kid friendly and genuinely lovely but the other 2% is completely out of place unnecessary cruelty.There is a scene in this game that ruined the game for me due to how cruel it was. Without spoilers, if you are sensitive to cruelty / torture then don't get the game. Mild spoiler on the scene:  . This specific scene in all honesty pissed me off so much because I never signed up to this. This game is rated PG12 and if you're sensitive to this sort of stuff it can be a little traumatizing. Of course your experience will vary but I for one think this scene alone should've took the game to 16-18+.  I am a 23 year old grown man and this was too much for me.This is such an absolute shame because it puts this big red stain on an otherwise absolute masterpiece. Seriously, who greenlit that scene? Did no one in the development team think it was completely out of place and unnecessary?Despite this genuinely ♥♥♥♥♥♥ scene, I can't say the game is bad. 98% of the game is a masterpiece, the other 2% is abhorrent and completely unnecessary.

author: Wolsk
review: It's rare that I write reviews for games, but this is legitimately one of the best co-op games I've ever played, and I feel it deserves one.  There is an impressive amount of content (even if you don't choose to find all the minigames and secret areas), and throughout the whole experience there are new mechanics and gameplay types introduced constantly.  No mechanic ever overstays its welcome (though I will admit some stages occasionally feel like they go on a bit too long), and thanks to the immense variety, I think anyone can find something to get excited about.There are some glitches and softlocks occasionally, plus you need to invite friends through Origin rather than through Steam, but outside of that I can't think of much to say negatively about It Takes Two.  If I had to complain about something, it's that the character development is pretty nonexistent for a lot of the game (and the main characters just come off like bad people) until a point where everything suddenly changes; it feels almost insincere when they start improving.If you've got a friend or a partner or just anyone who you'd be interested in playing co-op games with, this is a STRONG recommendation.  Hazelight has shown that they truly understand what a co-op experience should feel like.

author: BONSXI
review: What It Takes Two did Right/Good:*Great graphics* 9 Chapters; Each chapter takes about an hour or so to complete. The levels are well paced and the puzzles are good.*Different game mechanics for each “chapter” you enter. In one level May could have a hammer-grapple and next she could have a match launcher that explodes on impact.*Lots of Minigames; each mini game was very fun to play and I'm pretty sure there are 25 mini games total.*The Bosses are all unique and relatively easy to beat.*Dr. Hakim’s Book of Love saying “The Book of Love”.*Trippy Level design; I have no idea what drug the devs were taking but in the game, the best way I can describe it is “Honey, the kids are acid tripping AND i accidently shrunk them”. An example is you get transported to a pillow fort, it instantly transforms into a full functioning castle with people living in it. It's very trippy and I love it.* WE KILLED CUTIE!!!*Lots of stuff to explore and interact with; Surprisingly there’s stuff to do besides the story. Throughout the level, you will come across mini games, people to interact with, and smaller stuff to play with like an enlarged etch sketch.*Absolutely no in-game glitches that we came across! *Voice acting was great. *Awesome Platforming levels and action scenes.*Devs truly put their heart and soul into this game. I cannot exclaim the amount of detail they put into each and every level. Lots of creativity!What It Takes Two did Wrong/Bad:*Almost every cutscene jittered and was lower quality than the actual game graphics. Normally the cutscenes are supposed to look better than the gameplay, but it was quite the opposite.*May and Cody constantly bickering; I know that they are fighting and don’t love each other, but at times it got quite annoying hearing them fight all the time.*May’s voice actor; Don’t get me wrong, the voice actor is talented. But May’s voice was so annoying and whiny. *One Liners...*Dr. Hakim’s Book of Love's entire character was cringy and unpleasant to the eye.*CO-OP partner felt that they dragged the game out a little too much at the end.To be perfectly honest with you, there’s parts of this game that my CO-OP partner and I made 18+. All I’m going to say is the Sap Cannon XD. This CO-OP platforming game, filled to the brim with creative ideas and unique gameplay mechanics had me constantly entertained. I got this game for $30 and I highly recommend getting it while there's a sale. (Because saving money is nice)

author: ShiningBulb
review: THIS REVIEW CONTAINS SPOILERS OF THE GAME, SO IF YOU WANT TO PLAY THE GAME WITHOUT SPOILERS THAN DON'T READ MY REVIEW!Honestly one of the best games I've played. I personally love games like this and games you can play with a friend. Me and my friend were eager to play this game since it's the same studio that made "A Way Out", and we both loved that game. So we bought the game on launch. We hade high expectations of the game and me and my friend can say it did not disappoint.I could probably talk all day about how great this games is, but I won't. The game overall is great and if you and a friend are thinking about getting it, do it. Plus, one of you can buy it and then you can split the money between both of you, because only one needs to buy it, because of the firend pass.The story is great, lovely in fact. You'll play Cody and May, parents of a child. They are going through with a divorce, and the child Rose is sad about that. Cody and Mays spririts are transported in to these dolls that Rose has made. The story is really about them getting out of the dolls and back in to their own bodys. And to get out to their own bodys they have to take some sort of relationship counseling from a book, called Dr. Hakim. At first I thought he would be annoying with his humor and such, but it was acually kinda funny, plus the accent is a great touch and makes it so much funnier and better. In the beginning of the game Cody and May don't really like each other that much, they are annoyed of each other. So in the beginning of the game the dialog between the two is kind of fun because they roast each other. As they start to work together and communicate with each other, the dialog gets more humble, and they start opening up and talking about why their marriage isn't working. It's lovley to see their relationship develop through out the game.Gameplay wise, I can't find anything negative really. Some parts aren't as great as others, but they are still good don't get me wrong. You and your friend will decide which character you want to play, Cody or May. I played May trough out the game. Anyway, you'll play different part of, I guess you can call them stages, and on every stage Cody and May will have new and different abillites. In the first stage, Cody will have the ability to throw nails, and May have a hammer she can use. And on the next stage the abillities will be diffrent and so on. May and Codys abillities do work together so to complete most of the pussles you have to make use of each other and work together. This means that your experiance of playing the game will be a lot diffrent depending on which character you are playing. This opens up great for playing the game another time, maybe with someone else or with the same person again.I love the abillities and they aren't boring or something I can say I have seen before in a game. New and unique.I could go deeper in to gameplay but I would be writing forever becuase so much of the game is great. You can find stuff that's related to "A Way Out" in the games. I like that, it's nice to be reminded of a great game.So, my recommendation is buy it, it's worth every little penny. It's totally worth it for full price. Me and my friend could have payed more for it, becuase it was that good. For the great times you'll have playing this game, it's worth full price, if not more.

author: David0vić
review: This is undoubtedly a very creative, unique and interesting game that is worth giving a look if you're looking for a coop experience. I bought this game because of all the praise it's received and i do think it's a bit overrated. I think this game overstays it's welcome and is way too long for this simplistic gameplay. I think the game starts off great because it feels fresh and new but after a few hours you start to get the gist of the experience. Even though the game does a terrific job at trying to versify the gameplay mechanics, environments and level design, it still somehow manages to feel by the numbers after a while, mainly because the core gameplay design and loop is still there. I also think the difficulty is an issue, it's just way too easy and passive which i think is fine for a short game, but for a 10 hour journey, i expect something more to keep my attention for that long. I had a lot of fun in the first half but in the second half i was just wishing for the game to be over despite some cool levels and set pieces. The story also didn't work for me. I thought the premise was neat but it didn't do enough to keep me hooked or motivated. There wasn't that drive for me to keep pushing to see what happens next mainly because the story loves to wander and meander around without much of a direction. The end goal of the story wasn't very compelling either mainly because i wasn't big on the two main characters, they were just kind of there for me. With all that being said it's hard for me to give this a negative review because i did have a good amount of fun, probably 50/50 fun and boredom and i can't deny the amount of creativity and passion that was put in this game. It's very unique and unlike anything out there. Some of the puzzles and sequences where you have to cooperate with your partner to progress is very clever and sometimes makes you lean back and think 'how did they come up with this'. Also local splitscreen is pretty much dead so we should support games like this to help give it some life.6/10 (Decent)

author: Narcissu7F
review: ---ภาพสวย แปลกใหม่ สร้างสรรค์  ใครเคยเล่น Away Out มาเล่นอันนี้จะว้าวเข้าไปอีกระดับมีเพื่อนเล่นกดเลย ราคาเต็มยังคุ้ม ------ถ้าใครเคยเห็นรีวิวคร่าวๆอาจจะคิดว่าเนื้อเรื่องของเกมเหมาะกับคนที่เล่นกับแฟน หรือ เหมาะกับวัยเด็กรึเปล่าบอกตรงนี้เลยว่าไม่ใช่ มันเหมาะกับทุกเพศ ทุกวัย เล่นกับเพื่อน กับพี่ กับน้อง กับพ่อแม่ก็ยังได้ เกมมีเนื้อหาเกี่ยวกับปัญหาครอบครัว แง่คิดการใช้ชีวิตคู่ ผ่านทั้งไดอาล็อกบทพูดตรงๆ และแฝงเป็นนัยยะที่ต้องตีความเอาเอง แต่โดยรวมแล้วนำเสนอไปในทิศทางน่ารัก สดใส ไม่ซีเรียสอะไรใครมองว่าเป็นเกมแคชชวล co-op ตะลุยด่าน ซ้ำๆซากๆ ขอบอกว่าคุณคิดผิดครับทุกๆการผ่านstage ของเกมจะเปลี่ยนรูปแบบการเล่นของคุณไปเรื่อยๆ เป็นการเล่นเชิง puzzle ผสมผสาน action บ้าง ปนเปกันไป คุณจะได้ขับรถแข่ง เป็นจอมเวทย์ นักดาบ ดำน้ำ และอีกมากมาย แต่ละstage ใช้เวลาไม่น้อย และไม่นานเกินไป ให้คุณได้พออิ่มไปกับอุปกรณ์ใหม่ๆ นอกจากระบบการเล่นหลักแล้ว เกมจะมี mini-game มาให้เล่นแข่งกับเพื่อนเรื่อยๆ (มีโหมดให้เล่นย้อนเฉพาะmini-gameด้วย)งานภาพสวยจนคิดว่าPixar มาเองเลยทีเดียว คัตซีน ฉากแสงสี จัดเต็ม ใครชอบแนวๆดิสนีย์หรือPixar รับรอง ปลื้ม- เล่นคนเดียวไม่ได้- ใช้เวลาประมาณ 8-10 ชม. จบเกม นี่ขนาดเถลไถลบ้างแล้ว ก็ไม่ถือว่าสั้นเกินไป กำลังอิ่มๆ แต่ถ้าเทียบราคากับเกมในเกรดเดียวกันก็จัดว่าสั้นไปหน่อย (สำหรับผมถือว่าพอดี ลงตัว)- เล่นกับเพื่อนอะนะเรื่องping เป็นสิ่งสำคัญ ถ้าเราหรือเพื่อนเน็ตแย่ก็วายปวง แต่ปัญหานี้ก็ไม่น่าจะมีแล้วกับinternetในยุคปัจจุบันสรุป ซื้อเถอะ ผมซื้อราคาเต็มหารกับเพื่อนคนละครึ่ง เล่นไปฟินไปครับ

author: ANALSCHLAG
review: Gameplay BreakdownMy usual Gameplay Breakdown cannot be applied to It Takes Two, as it mixes-and-matches so many genres, making a full breakdown of each would prove nigh impossible, other than a spoiler as well.As main genres, ITT puts high emphasis on Platformer and Puzzle Game: in each stage, there will be multiple obstacle courses that often will need the combination of the two players' different tools or powers, in order to overcome them. The difficulty curve of such enigmas and platforming sections gently soars, first to accustom players to the new mechanics, and then leaving them free to use them at their full potential. However do not expect a hardcore challenge, as the game is more oriented towards an average / casual audience - which is fine, as it's not *too* easy, anyway.Secondary genres vary for each level, and in many cases they are unique, non-repeating sections with their own, specific gameplay mechanics. For instance, one of them will have players being able to manipulate their body size and gravity respectively, while another one will see Cody pilot an aircraft while May mans the turret to fend off attackers. Multiply cases like this for the totality of the game's duration, and the result is amazing variety.Minigames are found throughout the adventure, and put Cody and May against each other in small, competitive-oriented challenges. Also in this case, each minigame is unique and original, can be replayed unlimited times, and some of them will even change or become more difficult as the rounds go on. Winning or losing them doesn't give anything to the victor, they're just for fun's sake, a diversion. Certain side activities though, have unique achievements related to them.Sure, players can die during a boss fight, a platforming section, or any of the unique combat-oriented ones - although a game over only triggers when both are dead at the same time: the blessing of immortality allows both to quickly resurrect if defeated. Checkpoints are anyway very frequent and forgiving, even boss fights will checkpoint at every new phase's start, so losing progress in a frustrating way is not an issue.

author: Typo,
review: 【Honey, The kid Shrunk us】I ignored this game initially, but the experience after I started playing with my friend was unexpected.It is no exaggeration to say that this game is a milestone work of two-player cooperation. If it is a bit exaggerated, it may be called "the Mario Galaxy in two-player mode." Although many of its designs are not top-notch, and the storytelling is only entirely satisfactory, the ability to develop a two-player cooperative game to such a degree is itself a thing to be praised.Anyway, fxxk the Oscars.《亲爱的，孩子把咱们缩小了》当初并没有关注这款游戏，然而开始和朋友游玩后的体验是出乎意料的不夸张地说这款游戏是双人合作里程碑式的作品，如果夸张一点的话或许可以称其为“双人模式的马里奥银河”。虽然它的许多设计并不算顶尖，故事演出也只是中规中矩，但是能够把双人合作游戏开发到如此程度，这本身是件就值得被称赞的事情总而言之，qtmd奥斯卡

Would be surprised if the game doesn't win an award for creativity or just game play itself. Worth $40 and the fact that you can play with your friends with one purchase is also a plus in my books. 9/10

It's not unusual to get these little "Are you a real human" tests but normally they're one easy click and you can go on. In my case,  I had to choose between 6 or so pictures and click the one  which showed dices adding up to 14 for 16!!! times and holy f, that almost made me cry. After I'd finished this crap it told me I weren't fast enough and had to try it again. I really thought this had to be an April fools joke or something like wtf is this, do they want me to be a customer or do they want to break me and ahatter all my hopes and dreams??

author: Sourceless
review: I just finished this game and i have to say, this game is just amazing to play together with a friend or loved one. It honestly has it all. The best part is that only one person needs to buy the game for €40 and then two people can play. To me, the game is absolutely worth it's price tag, because you are buying one copy to play with 2 people. The game takes you to many different places and each place feels unique and fun to explore together. I finished the game in around 14 hours and enjoyed every last second of it. I honestly was sad that it was over in the end. I definitely will go back later to try and get all achievements.People are complain about Origin being involved, which is true. But honestly, you don't even notice it considering you just start the game trough steam, steam then starts origin in the background and just launches the game. I never even once thought that origin got in the way of things so i really dont get that people downvote this game just for that.. it's kinda childish to do that. EA made a great game here, and if you ask me, it's only logical to try and advertise you're own launcher a bit with it. At least they didn't pull a "Epicgames launcher classic move" and made it exclusive to they're launcher. People forget that that is a thing and im really glad they didn't do that here.10/10 game. Just simply amazing to play with friends.

author: Scenario
review: This game is phenomenal & blew all the expectations I had for it out of the water. The platforming is incredibly fluid & fun, and the puzzles & boss fights that you encounter in each of the different sections is incredibly creative & fitting to each sections' environment & overall atmosphere. The cutscenes & overall story of the game are frequently comical, providing plenty of laughs to the players while trying to repair this virtual couple's marriage. On top of all the perks of the gameplay, innovation, creativity & absolute fun that this game has to offer also lies the "Friend's Pass", which allows people who do not own the game to play with a friend who does own the game, at no additional cost. It Takes Two is more than worth the $40 pricetag, and I couldn't recommend it more.

review: This game was simply amazing.  I played it with my wife and loved every single glorious second of it.  The story was touching, heartfelt, and was a lot of fun to play through.  The puzzles were interesting and sometimes challenging, the scenery was stunningly beautiful, and the gameplay felt polished.Every single level had its own unique feeling and they all came together to put forth a world that felt well thought out, lifelike, dazzling in its imagination, and really made you feel like you were connected to the world and its characters.  My wife laughed like a crazy person at the squirrels, and she cried at one particular point in the game.  I, however, maintained my manly stoicism and most assuredly did not shed even a single tear.10/10 on this game.  It's one of the best multiplayer experiences I've had the pleasure of enjoying in years.

author: Xonifur
review: It Takes Two is a charming 2 player game focused on teamwork and trust. You take control of either Cody or May, whom are 2 parents having a divorce. Both characters have unique mechanics attached to them, but May is usually the character with lots of action and Cody is actually pretty supportive. Firstly, the game utilizes their focus on teamwork incredibly well. You never really feel left out when you play as either character because all the puzzles rely on using a character's mechanics together to make interesting plays as you progress through the game. Of course, as every game of teamwork must be, you can still troll your friends and force them to fall down cliffs or crush them with a hammer. Secondly, the game changes its mechanics constantly. At one point, you're using a hammer and nails together to lock things in place or smash things out of the way, the next you're using sap and a flare gun to make massive explosions together. The game never gets old and will evolve constantly. This is absolutely the game's strongest point, and they make use of most of their mechanics to an exciting degree. This game is absolutely very creative and even if you find yourself hating a mechanic you don't need to worry about it for too long because after about an hour you're met with a different one to toy around with. Thematically, the game is very beautiful. It takes place in all kinds of different environments and fantastical lands. There were times where you'd just hang out to enjoy the eye candy or admire the setting of some worlds you enter. Furthermore, the game does have a little bit of replay value. Most times, the character you pick gets a unique toy to play with that can change your experience of the game. For example, early into the game Cody will get nails that he can stick into walls for May to pole jump off of or he can stick them into boards for May to cross. May gets a hammer for smashing things or moving an object into place for Cody. The game also features cute minigames which are hidden all throughout the map for you to find and compete against each other with. Admittedly, some challenges are pretty biased in favor of one Character, but a lot are balanced pretty well for fair competition. This game absolutely is worth a try, and I'd definitely pick it up immediately even if it's not on sale. Your friend doesn't even need to purchase it. They just need to download the friend pass and they can play so long as someone owns the game. The game is also pretty long and entertained me and friend for a solid 10 hours before we actually even beat the game. Definitely worth a try if you're looking for something to play with friends or your lover.

author: Raptau
review: Honestly amazed at how this game looks, feels, plays, and manages to keep the gameplay fresh and interesting throughout the story. This is the best puzzle game that has been released in years.4/10 I couldn't murder the creepy book.

author: scout
review: This game is worth it's price! While it is a bit on the shorter side (with our first playthrough taking 12 hours), it had such refreshing gameplay and replayability.  It Takes Two uses mechanics that are familiar to games, but introduces them in unique ways that kept surprising us as we played through the story. The story had a good balance of silly and dark, and there were subtle changes in the dialogue between the characters as the story progressed, reflecting their growth. The characters are well-written and have a lot of personality to them, and they had their own unique skills to use to support each other. The game also contains a bunch of neat little easter eggs, and nearly 30 mini-games to play, some of which require you to look for. With all the secrets there are to find, and how interesting the level designs are as well as how captivating the art style is, a full, thorough playthrough can easily surpass 10 hours of playing, during which you'd never be bored.

author: TastyNachos
review: An amazing game. The best game that my girlfriend and I have been able to experience together. There are a couple of bugs or things like not making an animation if players choose different paths but its all very minor. There is a slight learning curve for those who aren't used to games in the platforming. But the constant checkpoints means its hard to lose interesting and the platforming flows enough for it to still be enjoyable. An absolute must if you find someone close to enjoy it with.

author: Wok Hay
review: It Takes Two is an incredible Co-OP only game from 2021 that is a must play for anyone looking for an amazing, if not the best co-op game out in the market right now. The game has you control one of two characters: Cody or May as you go through a magical version of your house in order to mend what it seem a too far gone broken relationship.The story begins with Cody and May announcing their divorce to their daughter. Obviously the daughter is incredibly upset by this and blames herself. She cries and her tears fell on some dolls and magically it transport the consciousness of Cody and May into those dolls. They are then greeted by this (in my opinion) funny character known as the Book of Life. He enthusiastically send the two of you off on a journey in order to fix your relationship so that Cody and May can return to their body. The story drives home some points on what relationship needs in order to be fix or work to begin with such as affection, willingness to work together, being a good partner, etc etc. The writing is alright with the story but where it really shines is all the interaction between Cody and May. Cody and May begins the story bitter towards each other, resentful, belittling, even bringing up the past and blaming each other. Through the game you will slowly see the two regain their affection towards each other, fall in love again, compromise and actually communicate with the issues they have with one and another. It is sweet but it is not a linear growth, you will see them progress and regress like a roller coaster but that is the best part about them. They're humans and flawed but they're trying. The two speak often as they're the only other characters aside from the book and the daughter so there is plenty of time to enjoy the interaction between the two, especially when they joke around or get competitive during minigames.Graphically the game is amazing. The colors and everything is vibrant and eye catching but not overly-saturated in comparison to games like modern Mario games. While retaining its cartoon-y art style that fulfill the purpose of making the  game feel whimsical and magical, there are also some very detailed textures and beautiful lighting that make things also give a sense of realism as well. I can't quite describe it but compare it to a high-budget modern Disney animated film where the art style still retain its identity while also delivering very highly detailed environments. There were multiple moments in the game where I had to simply pause and admire the view because of how beautiful it could get.As beautiful as the graphic can be, the gameplay outshines every part of the game. What appears to be just a platformer co-op switches up on you insanely often, touching on nearly every popular genre in gaming out there from racing to puzzle to shooters to even beat-em ups. And there is even more genres if you consider all the different minigames you can play with your partner that are completely optional. Typically you would worry about a game if they just simply jam all kind of different genres into one game as it can lead to multiple issues such as certain parts not being as polished or the game just lacking an identity, but it all just works like a cog in It Takes Two. The game also handles co-operative play insanely well where the two of you will not be just working together on the same puzzle, but often time than not the two of you will be doing two completely different objectives while helping the other progress. The game balance this really well cause at no point does it feel like the player playing May or Cody feel like they're carrying the other. As the title implies, it takes two to overcome all these obstacles and progress throughout the game. The game was never stale and always a pleasant to play. In terms of difficulty, the game is perfect for both casual and serious gamers. The game isn't so hard as so casual players can't pick this up to play with their partner but it also isn't so easy where it feels insulting and non challenging. This game truly is designed to be played by as many people as possible. Also for the griefers, it is also pretty fun to cause your partner to die in often hilarious ways.Overall, this game is probably my game of the year in 2021 because of how well crafted it is, especially as a co-op experience. This game isn't mind-blowing or that deep with innovative gameplay or super engaging story but because its just simply a blast to play with someone, whether its a friend, significant other, or family members. If you're looking for a good co-op experience, this game is a must play.

author: CrustyCadaver
review: This game just took the spot for my #1 favorite game of all time.  Every level adds new game mechanics to keep the game play from getting stale.  The level design was so imaginative, with a huge variety of beautiful settings.  The voice acting of the two main characters was top notch.  The game has lots of puzzle elements, but they aren't overly complicated.  It took 28.6 hours to complete the game.  The only minor issue was the camera controls in a few areas.  This is a "must have" game in my opinion.  Even though I just finished the game, I'm ready to play it again.
