author: Khan
review: ===PROS===+Beautiful animation+ Beautiful scenery - Practically each frame could be a high-res desktop background+ Intuitive gameplay - The controls can feel a bit "weird" at first with Capslock being one of the key movement inputs, but it doesn't take more than a couple minutes to get used to. You can always rebind, though+ Great co-op - Not just "you have another person there to talk with while you both effectively play single-player" - Your partner is vital in completing the game+ Voice acting is surprisingly good, but my standards aren't as high as everyone else's so YMMV here+ Great for couples and/or family - This is definitely a game you'll be seeing played by parents and children for years to come+ Friends pass, which requires only one of you to purchase the game for both of you to play===CONS===- Steam just launches Origin, requiring you to make/use an existing EA account- Aforementioned Origin has a slew of UI shenanigans to get through, primarily when adding/inviting your friend- No manual save function (sort of) - My friend and I kept getting stuck when one of us would disconnect halfway through, forcing us to replay up to that point with our fingers crossed. There is a workaround, however. Manually quitting via returning to the main menu right before the disconnect will allow us to rejoin and pick up without issueI imagine that this'll see the ubiquitous-ness that Little Big Planet did on the PS3. Highly recommended.

author: Spiff
review: Best coop game ever. The amount of detail, variety, and polish in this charming action-platformer is unmatched. I've never seen a game use so many mechanics so well and consistently switch up the formula. No section felt too long or overstayed its welcome. Not to mention me and my coop partner found ourselves taking time to enjoy the scenery. There is much to explore..minigames or small touches that elevate the game even higher.The whole package fits together perfectly. It's a major step up from A Way Out and Brothers, both of which I really liked. It Takes Two has taken the best ideas of both and ran with them. I will play this again. What a ride.

author: ABunchOfFruit
review: WARNING: SLIGHT SPOILERSIt Takes Two:Gameplay 10/10: As far as gameplay goes, it was extremely fun. Every chapter had a new mechanic that involved some aspects of teamwork and some aspects of working apart. And the game never dwells on one thing. Its one great mechanic after another and it keeps the variety and spark that makes you want to progress one chapter after anotherVisuals 10/10: Every single scene, every single backdrop, every single animation in the doll form was perfect. The scenery looked amazing, the characters gave life into every area, instead of just blank, non interactable faces. The visual style in the game just exceeded expectations and it was such a beautiful experience. Story 9.5/10: The story was very strong. From the start it established two believable main characters, May and Cody, and their attempt to get a divorce after some marital issues. The acting and character design makes you believe that they could never and will never not get a divorce, but the game allows them to slowly reconnect and regain the passion that they once shared. Almost every single bit of dialogue was perfect and I loved the way the characters, who were at one point so far apart, grow together to love each other again.Verdict:9.5/10One of the best games I've played in a long time

author: バイト | HelloImByte
review: This Game is probably, one of the best Coop Games out there right now.And I would say, this game is able to be on the same level, like the Portal Coop Mode and the Coopgame A Way Out (what is from the same developer).The Gameplay and LevelDesign, is very varied, creative, good balaced and satisfying.The Game itself is very polished and we didnt encountered any big issues or buggs so far.Every level itself sticks out, with his own core, design and own gameplay and innovation.This Game really likes to change up things.You can find Minigames, in every level, and sometimes even a bunch of them lined side by side in one level, your also able to replay them on the main menu, so that is pretty cool.I would recommend take your time with this game.The Characters and the story is well written and we also found a lot of easter eggs in the game, wich one of them has a conection to a game from the same developer team.From what I heared takes the game  like from 15 up to 18hours to beat. This Game brings creativity really to the next level,I only can recommend you, give this game a try. The cool thing is only one Person needs this game in his/ her Libary to play with his/her friends.With best regardsBytedotexe :)

author: Qain
review: What a delightful experience - Not without its kinks - It Takes Two FEELS like PIXAR: THE GAME from the very beginning, with the use of a very bright palette of colours, everything just pops out of the screen.I played this game mainly with a friend online and my girlfriend locally and, in both cases, it worked just fine. My friend is a veteran gamer, whereas my gf is pretty much DAY 0 noob and, despite the differences, in both cases we felt a degree of challenge, whether in the clever use of mechanics or just learning the grasp of jumping, double jumping, dashing while jumping, etc. With that said, my friend and I came to a few conclusions:The mechanics are quite unique in the sense that on each level, there will be a new mechanic to be used and exploited. Their implementation and the context in which they are used is just magical, to the point where at some points we were just saying "WOW" out loud several times as the game changed mechanics and perspectives constantly. However, after a few levels, we noticed a certain pattern where one character would serve as an instrument for the other, and this remains like so for the entirety of the game. In a way that is fine because you can always change players whenever you are going to play, but at the same time it would be nice if the roles were switched every now and then.The main theme of the game, or the trigger for the whole thing to happen (the two main character's divorce) could have been exploited much further. I don't think the game is made for children, mainly because of the theme used, that's why I believe it could've been exploited much more so as to expand on the character's arcs (otherwise there is not much growth on the characters). While there are a few key levels and mechanics which do emphasize on this topic, I still feel that, in their "casual" interactions (outside of a cutscene), the theme could've been pushed much better. Still, this is a very minor complaint.In the context of forced co-op (be it online or local), we felt the game was just a tad longer than expected. Specially considering we are two young adults (does 30 ish count?) who are juggling with work and daily life just to coordinate a time to play and finish the game. Some particular levels we feel could've been shortened out or changed so as to shorten their pace.With all of that said, the "negative" points are basically us being rather nitpicky about the game. It Takes Two could very well set a new standard on which co-op games to base themselves on, with great voiceacting, an interesting, though not fully exploited, plot, an EXCELLENT implementation of co-op through Friend's Pass and an art design and mechanics that kept us entertained for about 12 hours.Highly recommended.

It takes two, is a great addition to Hazelight Studios list of games. If you played their previous game "A Way Out" it has all the great co-op action from that but with even more unique spins and twist on it. This game has unique replay ability and lot of fun interactive worlds to experience and explore while playing though. Very well thought out and fun game with great competitive aspects as well with the mini games and random ways to mess with each other! Would highly recommend this game to anyone interested, also as a bonus you only need to buy one copy and it's basically a game you can place back to back and have unique experiences.

review: Here's the thing, the gameplay is good, the music is good and the visuals are pretty fun. The problem is the story. You know why Mrs. Doubtfire was great? This game thinks that two parents, who clearly don't actually care about each other, should be rewarded for tormenting their small child. A small child with the emotional range of a rabbit. Who cries once.The parents are terrible people and never address the actual things that lead  to their falling apart in the first place. But they do go out of their way to make their daughter cry and then never address that...

author: ❥OxH.
review: POSTED: 17 APRILI recommend this game for three reasons:1) Unique playthrough - you experience a different side of the game depending on the character you play2) Refreshing game mechanics - changes each level, mini games included3) Cute!However, there may be deal breakers depending on what you are looking for. The story is not compelling. It could even be seen as shallow. I also think it takes the topic of divorce too lightly. The game itself doesn't prove to be challenging...BUT it is still fun. Each level brings a smile to my face as there is some nostalgia involved and the visuals are appealing. I recommend this game for those who are looking for a chill co-op.

review: A really interesting game, without spoiling anything, all I can say is It is such a unique game with a mix of everything, I had a blast playing it with a friend of mine.The only downside to the game that I can possibly find is that you have to play with someone, it is nice to do, however it is a downside if you have no one to play with, even though there is a friends pass so you only need one copy of the game. author: Ben Storaro
review: 10/10! One of the best games I've ever played. Believe me when I say this is one of best Co-op games created. Everything is so creatively done and implements the co-op style perfectly. The theming of each chapter is amazing and the mechanics and gameplay is exceptional, I loved the voice acting and the characters throughout, the story was touching and emotional, the music and atmosphere is top class. There is a collection of 25 minigames to find and for the most part, they're all great fun too! I have no negative things to say about this game. Fully recommend to everyone to give it a go and play. Worth full price, took me 15 hours to 100%.

author: Crescent Rose
review: It Takes Two can only be described by one word. Creativity. The game bursts from it overflowingly! From swapping gameplays by the minute, to genuine emotional moments, to puzzle solving into heart pumping action! The game goes through many different styles as well never turning the breaks on! While the story won't actually fix a relationship and at times is predictable it still keeps you interested to the end never letting go! Not only that. On top of that the game is filled with creative, competitive and fun minigames from whack a mole, to a rythm game, to a snowball fight, to a snail race! These were super fun to find and add a slice of competition between you and your play buddy while not going overly serious! There are references everywhere to video games and entertainment media in general. This game was crafted with love and I cannot say anything else other then. Bring a friend or a partner. Sit down and have fun. Cause after all. It Does Take Two.

author: A Harmless Cat
review: It takes Two is a platforming action-adventure game that lives up to its name. Playing this one singleplayer is just not an option. Developed by Hazelight Studios as the "successor"of A Way Out, It Takes Two does indeed succeed at the already few things that the studio's previous co-op game could not. Faster, harder and somehow more enjoyable than the previous one, this is THE definitive co-op game you can play right now.+ An incredibly creative, rich and entertaining package.+ Unique gameplay, spread across multiple chapters, you won't encounter the same objective twice.+ Enjoyable music and general soundtrack, which fit the game perfectly.- Entirely co-op, that is not really a negative as the game is designed this way, but a good thing to keep in mind. You will need a friend to play it.- The story, which is not bad at all, but rather oriented towards children, or younger people. Due to my personal tastes and being an adult, I prefer deeper, more complex stories. Again this is very personal opinion and absolutely undeserving of being called a "negative", but for the sake of my review formats it is placed under that category.If you have two, then It Takes Two is for you, as simple as that. With its incredible ingenuity and entertainment, it is not surprising that this game is 2021's Game of the Year for most people. For me it falls just slightly behind Life is Strange: True Colors, which is my personal Game of the Year for 2021. Both games are complete opposites in reality, one had the most unique gameplay we've seen this year, or in a long time even. The other one had the best story of last year's titles. In the end, I take story over gameplay that is why True Colors edged for me. In regards to It Takes Two I give it a solid . Just remeber, you need CO-LLA-BO-RATION to get through this one.

author: panda
review: the graphics and the atmosphere pull the player directly into anowhter world.the little interactions, like mini-games, where ya fight against each other and the stimulus increases even more, is well done!you are drawn into a little fantasy world while mommy and daddy try to escape the world with many obstacles and teamwork - so trust and reliability are required in the game and among the players too - and "save" their marriage before the absolute decay.a story is told from the beginning to the end. how they abuse each other with mean words, tease each other (and so on..)and learn to love and to appreciate each other over the time again - cute development!i can recommend the game to anyone looking for an adventurous and romantic relationship story. you learn to love each other again with your partners flaws.the price of the game is quite expensive, but i would still say that this is one of the best games with coop i have played so far.

author: Tomatoshadow
review: What an adventure.  has to be one of the most fun experiences I've had in a long time. I can't remember the last time I played a game with a smile the whole way through. is a lighthearted co-op game that plays like a platformer for the most part, but introduces all sorts of new gameplay elements throughout the game. Along with your partner, you will be solving puzzles, fighting bosses, competing in mini-games and just exploring large zones, each with their own unique theme.If you're looking for a co-op game to play with a good friend, a significant other or someone who generally isn't into video games, this is it.Everything you do feels so familiar, yet it kept surprising me all the way through. There were so many segments whose inspiration I feel I could recognize, it truly felt like an hommage to video games in general. There was at least one very direct reference I didn't expect, but they certainly didn't make an effort to shove it in your face.It managed to feel nostalgic even thought it's brand new. I saw a ton of games that made my childhood in it: Donkey Kong Country, Rayman 2 & 3, Mario Party, Mario Sunshine, Zelda, Diablo. Whoever designed each segment clearly loves video games. If you are familiar with these games, you will love  and if you aren't, it will show you most of what video games can be.There was honestly a lot more to the game than what I expected. The first level introduces a couple new gameplay elements and I thought that was it. I was ready to play the rest of the game like that. But as soon as I got comfortable with what I was given, I was already in a new area with a new theme and new gameplay elements. Every time I thought I was nearly done with the game, there was more. I was looking forward to finishing the game but at the same time I was hoping it wouldn't stop delivering; And it did.Growing up, video games felt like they were made to be fun first and foremost. Everything didn't  to have a purpose or a reward and I think that's what I liked the most about this game. There are a ton of things you can interact with that don't do anything particularly meaningful or rewarding... They're just there. This reminds me of old PC adventure games where some of the  fun I had was to just click stuff and see what it would do. It encourages you to explore and try things.There are also a lot of mini-games that are only there for you to compete with your partner. You don't have to play them at all but you'll  to play them and win. I found there was a nice enough variety that it gave both players a chance to shine, even if they're not the best at video games in general.It's absolutely gorgeous. Every level has an insane amount of details. It made me want to look in every corner of every level, not just because I was hoping to discover something hidden but just to see how everything was built. You'll play as miniature characters in big, surreal worlds. You're going to see a lot of original uses for otherwise boring household items, interesting materials used to craft the world you're in.Every cutscene made me forget I was playing a video game and made me think that this very well could have been an animated film.Hazelight Studios managed to take everything that  did right and improve on it, while adressing everything that wasn't so great about it. I set out to play both games one after the other with my girlfriend, without initially knowing the two were developped my the same company. I can say with confidence that everything I didn't like about  was no longer an issue.My gripes with  were mostly with the dialogue and story. I couldn't figure out whether I was supposed to take it seriously or not.  makes it abundatly clear that it doesn't take itself seriously. It takes an overall serious subject and makes it fun and lighthearted.The dialogue felt natural and believable. Most of all, it didn't take me out of the game like it did in . This style definitely seems to suit Hazelight Studios better than the more serious .

review: Honestly one of the best games I've ever played.  The sophisticated evolution of co-op elements introduced in A Way Out, with spectacular and immersive visuals. If you dont... get this game anyway and get on reddit/community discussion and find someone to play with.  Don't miss this one!

author: Kamel
review: It took us 18 hours to complete. Much longer than I anticipated based on what I found online, but we loved every minute of it. This game has a style and character unmatched by any game I've played before it. The different scenarios are masterfully made with completely unique and new gameplay mechanics being introduced between each scenario.The only weak part of the game is the story/development between the husband and wife as time went on wasn't very well paced or convincing. As long as you can take that with a grain of salt that's easy to look past.Even with that said, thia game is without a doubt the best 2 player coop game I've played hands down.

author: mackatozis
review: The game is a third-person action-adventure platformer that follows the story of Cody and May, a couple on the brink of divorce who are transformed into dolls by a mysterious book. As they journey through a fantastical world, they must work together to overcome challenges and repair their relationship.One of the standout features of "It Takes Two" is its co-op gameplay, which requires players to work together in order to progress through the game. The game includes a variety of mechanics and abilities that allow players to interact with the environment and solve puzzles, such as the ability to control bees, use drills, and transform into various objects.The game's art style is colorful and vibrant, and the levels are diverse and imaginative. The voice acting is also well done, with convincing performances from the main characters."It Takes Two" is a charming and enjoyable game that is well worth checking out for fans of platformers and co-op games. Its engaging gameplay, beautiful art style, and heartwarming story make it a standout title.

author: LilRacko
review: **SPOILERS AHEAD**It Takes Two is an interesting concept: What if you were confined to the mercy of your friend? Will you be able to pass a level without them ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ you over at least once during a puzzle? Will they disconnect their controllers in rage over a dumbass platforming sequence, or completely ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ own you in a button-mashing minigame? During these 15 hours, we have toiled over these struggles as we watch the two main character ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ repair their marriage after a really stupid argument causes their gremlin daughter to run away. Like where the ♥♥♥♥ is she gonna go? I don't even think that bus stop she goes to in the ending is real, it's probably just a drop-off for the local human trafficking ring. I was laughing as the book tortured and cucked them, time and time again, from regaining their human bodies and getting the ♥♥♥♥ out of each other's lives. In truth, sometimes people aren't the right fit and no amount of forced Saw-esque therapy is going to fix a completely trashed marriage. The book understood this and used this opportunity to put them in a never-ending hell, and both May and Cody ended up getting back together out of sheer exhaustion. If I learned anything from this game, it's to:1. Never marry a British woman who owns a large tract of land in the middle of the country.2. Never conceive a daughter with this woman, who by judging the look of the daughter, may mean that your spouse is already a very close relative.3. Never own a red book in fear that it will send me through all seven layers of Dante's Inferno.4. Definitely buy a space baboon stuffed animal and name it Moon Baboon.Overall, a solid 9/10.(May)After we kissed in the game my partner and I had to resist the urge to pull off each others clothes and start passionately making out. It was hot. It was moist. But most importantly it took two. Just like this review, which was written by my partner above and me the account holder here. Also the daughter is really ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ ugly which can be off putting at times and the wife is British which is kinda ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ lame as ♥♥♥♥. She is also really mean to Cody the whole game so she kinda sucks(Cody)                                                                            Fortnite Battlepass (included)I landed tilted towers but cody started default dancing on May's corpse and she slowly faded into the sweet release that was death. Fortunately Dr. Hakim came and told Cody that it would be ok because the real treasure and love is the friends we made along the way.

In windows language is set to Chinese, the user can not choose the software installation location, more f*ck is, after switching to English although you can choose the installation location, but no matter how to choose, will eventually be installed in the C disk under the default location.It's not just about software bugs. It;s about EA's attitude.And I would say f u c k y o u EA. Tried and tried launching the app again and again, I finally realized there's no wonder many people play pirate EA's games. author: ルカ★マグロ
review: This game is beautiful. Not just in the sense of graphics, although that also looks quite good. It just evokes a sense of wonder and enjoyment every time we enter a new scene, get a new ability, or find a solution to the puzzle to progress forward. There's also a simple, but solid and wholesome story that ties all your experiences into a coherent flow.But the true gem here is the CO-LLA-BO-RATION! aspect of the game. And this is where it shines. So much depends on your partner, and even though that sounds a little daunting, especially for very independent or dominant players, the reward for successful teamwork is incredibly satisfying. Just be patient and trust your partner, it's not as impossible as it sounds.The best part of the game for me, though, was how you can even eat a town into food shortage.

author: Aerothorn
review: I cannot recall the last time I found such an irritating game so delightful, and such a delightful game so irritating. Really wish that Steam had a "mixed" rating for this one.To wit: It Takes Two is a co-op adventure incorporating platforming, puzzle-solving, and light combat (including boss fights). It’s surprisingly full of content, and all of it is polished and has the small details that indicate a labor of love. Over the course of the game you’ll explore a wide variety of genuinely beautiful environments, and each stage gives your characters different asymmetrical abilities and tools, to the point where It Takes Two feels like playing a succession of separate games with a shared control scheme. The design has clearly benefited from extensive playtesting, such that every element is accessible even to people who don’t regularly play video games. The downside of that accessibility is a certain lack of depth in every new mechanic it introduces, but this is solved by the constant retirement of existing mechanics in favor of new ones. It’s a brilliant solution to the challenge of building a game that appeals to both casual and enfranchised gamers. And, of course, video games are almost always more fun in co-op, which further elevates the experience. This is the delightful bit.The irritation comes in the fact that, rather than playing the sort of silent protagonists you’d often find in this sort of game, the two players embody Cody and Mae, a deeply unhappy married couple who spend most of the game needling each other, trading blame for their myriad failings, and generally being insufferable. This is not a clever Battle of the Sexes tribute; it’s time spent in the company of people who loathe each other almost as much as they loathe themselves, and have neither the wit nor self-awareness to trade proper quips. This is exactly as much fun as it sounds. Cody and Mae’s sole redeeming feature is that the other principle character, an animate book who communicates primarily in hip thrusts, is even worse, and the protagonists are never more relatable than when the book shows up and they briefly stop squabbling to go “Christ, not this guy again.”A lot of video games have unsatisfying and unambitious narratives, but these are typically conveyed in isolated cutscenes or exposition dumps in games that otherwise “focus on the gameplay,” where the narrative is simply there to communicate the game’s objectives. It Takes Two is the polar opposite: Cody and Mae will not shut up, and will constantly chatter over and comment on every single thing that happens on screen. I’ve never played a game with more vocal protagonists.To give credit where credit is due, It Takes Two isn’t phoning it in; the writers seem to genuinely want to tell a moving story of a troubled family finding a path forwards aside from the “easy out” of divorce (if that framing bothers you, you’ll find you have a lot of company). And it does have its moments; a now-infamous scene involving a plush elephant is an excellent slice of horror, and it’s true that Cody and Mae become at least somewhat less irritating as they learn to like themselves and rediscover what brought them together. Unfortunately, that really only happens in the last quarter of the game, and by that point I had long since tired of their company. The entire plot also rests on the premise that their daughter (who approaches Stepford Wives levels of implausible perfection) is so dumb that she doesn’t notice that both her parents are in magically-induced comas as they lie splayed on a couch, and assumes they’re just ignoring her.

author: BuzzkiLLington
review: Wow... this game has totally blown me and my girlfriend away. My gf before playing this game had no experience whatsoever playing video games, yet she picked up the controls within 30 mins and non stopped laughed and had fun. This game is definitely a good entry point for getting into gaming, she is even creating her own Steam acc now and is getting a computer. I honestly can't remember the last time a game made me smile and laugh this much while also being totally obsessed with the game, also spending time with someone special while playing this game makes it absolutely memorable. I have never played anything like this in the 15 years of my gaming life, this game has pretty much touched every single genre and put it into one.I don't usually purchase games unless they are on a sale, but this was well worth the original purchase price. It is an absolute joy to play, the story is fantastic, the mini games are so damn fun and competitive, very impressive gameplay, the exciting secrets, the Easter eggs are really fun, its immersive, has a gorgeous soundtrack and is an absolute bundle of fun! We can defo see ourselves replaying this gem in the future. The graphics are beautiful and I thought the lighting was bloody stunning. The developers should be proud of this amazing game, (not EA though lol).If you have someone you want to get into gaming, or you just want to have an absolute ball with your partner or friend, pick this up. Take it from me, this game is %100 worth the money, 11/10 you wont regret it in the slightest.

I had such a blast throughout my 15 hours playing this game, and I honestly couldn't recommend it enough. The way that each character's unique abilities compliment one another...the sheer variety of levels, the chase segments, the callbacks to other games...It Takes Two is perhaps the best co-op game I've ever had the pleasure of playing. To anyone who enjoys platform/co-op games; it isn't even a question - buy this game. I had such a huge smile on my face from start to finish.(I also had a snowball fight with my co-op partner for like a solid half an hour. Totally unnecessary, but I have zero ragrets)

author: Nightserg
review: and give me a follow on twitch if you liked my review, it really helps me out. It Takes Two is a casual but wonderful coop experience, a game that always comes up with new gameplay mechanics to keep you and your coop partner entertained. 👍 +Gameplay mechanics always change with each chapter to keep things fresh from start to end.+A visual treat, with different and unique locations.+Great overall sound design.👎-Incredibly easy, with little to no challenge at all in regards to platforming and puzzles. -Main story is nothing special. It Takes Two is a story about the divorce of a couple, and how their kid through magic and with the help from the Book of Love will help them get back together. It's a simple story, no plot twists, nothing really special. You know how it ends the moment you start the game. What is special about it, sorta, is the small parts of the story that happen while you're exploring the magical world of your house and its surroundings and how you're fixing your relationship with one another. The story starts with you and your other arguing while your daughter is trying desperately to help you get back together which sadly fails. She then goes back to her room and starts crying and somehow, never explained, through magic you two become dolls and are teleported to a twisted reality of the house you live in. The Book Of Love, comes to her aid and forces you both to deal with your relationship through several trials or chapters, each bringing you back closer to one another. It is nothing really special about it, so don't jump in the game for the story, It Takes Two is more about experiencing something, hell I'd even argue this game would fit better an actual couple rather than playing it with your friends and most will see it that way which will make it less appealing to a lot of players. Story rating: 7/10You play as either Cody or May and the main genre of the game is platforming and puzzle-solving with a bit of combat in between. I'll start with the worst aspect of the game because really there is just one, the difficulty. Unfortunately, this is a casual game, a very easy to play and get into no doubt but it will make a lot of its mechanics irrelevant. To put it straight, you cannot die in the game, sorta. If one if you falls down the pit you are brought back to life instantly or if you fall in combat or other events you can resurrect yourself easily by tapping E. If both of you should "die" at the same time, the game has a ton of checkpoints, even in mid/end boss phases that you'll never truly feel punished for it. That means a lot of the platforming events such as avoiding traps and whatnot become pointless. That being said, the very easy difficulty won't matter much if you jump into the game with the right expectations, even more so when the gameplay mechanics always change. What I mean by that is, in each chapter, you are given a set of tools, unique for each character and these tools will help you traverse the maps, solve puzzles, and progress through the level design. The coop aspect is extremely important as each tool will be used in combination with your partners. For example in the snowy chapter, you are given half a magnet, the blue for May and the Red for Cody, which is positive and negative and you will help each other push or pull obstacles for one another or simply traverse chasm by "attracting" to one another with the magnet force. Now imagine that in each chapter you get different and unique tools and you'll see why the game never really gets boring. It's a shame the difficulty is so easy because there are some really nice boss fights that could've been so much intense but alas, as you cut through its 10 to 15 hours all these awesome moments are more visual spectacle than gameplay challenges. There are some 1v1 moments called couple challenges where you play unique and fun minigames which can certainly prolong the experience if you wish. As for the split-screen thing just like in A Way Ou but probably more so here, it's pointless if you play online. You will almost always see what your partner sees and I get that it's a creative choice but it's not a good one, to be honest, and it's only good if you play on the same device. Gameplay rating: 8/10Straight out the bat, the first tunnel you go through or when the first event song starts playing, you'll notice how incredible they are. I was honestly shocked at how great the sound effects were and how they sounded unique, different, and accurate as you jumped and went through different places. There was clearly a lot of effort put into that and even the music, as you go through the last chapter, you'll be in awe. I think the final chapter of the game is one of the best visual and audio moments I've experienced in gaming. It felt like a Pixar/Disney movie so huge props to the team that pulled that off. As for the voice acting, while it has some cringe moments they do a great job at acting out their roles, especially The Book of Love. Audio rating: 9/1090% of the time it feels like you're actually playing a game straight out of Pixar or Disney animations. It's visually incredible and some set pieces will absolutely stun you. The character models, especially the ones you play look very detailed, the world, the level design, and how it all seamlessly fits together is truly an incredible work of art. Each chapter will put you through unique places, from snowy areas to a toy city that feels like it came from an RPG. But such visual performance does come at a cost, and there's going to be moments where the framerate will tank heavily but those are very rare moments luckily. There are some issues with connectivity and the second player might experience delays and lags so beware of that.Graphics, performance and tech analysis score: 9/10So is the game worth it? Hell yeah, it is. It's a wonderful coop experience, even if you play it with a friend rather than your lover/partner and while the difficulty is very casual-like it should not stop you from experiencing this work of art.

author: Oiljacker
review: It Takes Two was an experience unlike any i have ever experienced. The cute character models, clever platforming and evolving gameplay spell out a game that will make unlikely to ever be bored of. You need a friend to play this game with, I played it with my brother and had a blast. Its a family friendly game, so if you are looking at a way to bond with your gamer kid who has no time for you, this is an awesome way to do so. The game often changes according to the story. At one point it hands you with guns to shoot down a bunch of pests, at another time gives you a sword and magic to fight off guards in a castle. The story of the game is beautiful and gives a lesson of appreciating the people around you. It revolves around a couple, Cody and May who are getting divorced soon and Rose, their daughter, stuck in the middle of it. Rose wishes for them to be friends again and then you get into tiny dolls and try to get back into your body. Simple enough, but along the way you meet friends and foes, and cute creatures too. Its a great game and certainly one of the best of 2021.

author: esteban
review: This game is one of, if not, the best game I've played.                                                                               14/10I kidnapped my friend and made him play it with me, and that may be the best decision I made this year because the enjoyment and entertainment we got from this game is unbelievable.The game takes you through a vast variety of different terrain and environment. Every single chapter feels like a different game with new game mechanics, surrounding, theme, puzzles, adventures, the type of game you're playing even changes, it goes from the normal 3rd person, to 2D platformer, to mmorp, to dungeon crawler, to flying mechanics, to swimming puzzles and so much more.The story captured me and the cut scenes kept me involved and made me feel like I was really in the game itself. The music was perfect and in the final chapter, it was everything. I haven't felt this good after finishing a game, the whole experience was just so rewarding.I truly want to thank everyone involved in the development of this game for bringing such a masterpiece into the world. I really do appreciate everything you've done.p.s. there are so many different mini games and interactive elements that are just such a delight to interact with. p.s.s. I checkmated my friend in chess in it takes two.

author: Gilford
review: From the makers of A Way Out, a co op only experience where you only need 1 copy of the game while the partner plays for free, It Takes Two is an action puzzle platformer with emphasis on cooperation rich with an *abundance* of content. The roughly 10 hour story adventure is filled with so many varying minigames and gimmicks so there's never a dull moment. It's exciting, it's daring, innovative. There's a lot of passion put into the game and it shows. It's like playing through a Disney/Pixar movie with all the charm and soul it's known for, and you do it all with a friend. As far as platforming and puzzle solving goes, most puzzles require timing and full cooperation but it's nothing too big brained given enough time but it's engaging all the same. Platforming is fluid, some of the best I've ever come across by far and very forgiving as both you and your co op partner have infinite lives which allows for great freedom of exploration. Story is very heartwarming and charming. Ending left me satisfied. The pacing was rather cliche but ultimately enjoyable. The Friend Pass System is one of the best features I've ever witnessed with regards to gaming. One player owns the game, partner plays for free. Wanna try the game out? Both players download the friend pass and try out the first chapter for free. It's brilliant. One of the best co op games I've ever played in terms of overall quality and fun factor. Thank you for your authenthic genius, Josef Fares.

author: Insanewaffle
review: A really interesting, well thought out co-op game. Each chapter is fresh and exciting, with massively different settings and worlds each one as charming as the last, with references and Easter eggs strewn about everywhere. The puzzles are mixed up constantly so nothing feels repetitive, yet they remain thought-provoking and enjoyable to complete. The action set pieces are great, one mission you'll be flying a plane made out of underpants, the next you'll be battling toy knights as a wizard. Overall, I can feel that a lot of love went into this game, and if you have someone to play this with, I would highly recommend it.

author: StupidSexyLeon
review: Just finished this masterpiece.Having played both Brothers and A way out, I wasn't a stranger to the work of this developer, but it still managed to surprise me, in a very positive way.- The game is absolutely gorgeous: there wasn't a single area or level in the game where I wasn't impressed by the sheer beauty around, and it makes you feel fuzzy and excited at the idea of digging deeper into this almost childlike view of the world.- You get to decide what to do! You want to rush through the game or examine everything and participate in all the minigames? No problem, this world is your playground!- There's plenty of different gimmicks through the game and the gameplay is so fluid and ever changing that it's very hard to get bored even for just a moment. There were some unexpected moments that really stick out and that I am sure will remain in the memories of the players for a while!- The story in itself is very simple, but the good part here is the way the two main characters grow during the  adventure and how the relationship evolves.- This is not really a negative within the game in my opinion, but my partner found the game a bit too easy. In my opinion, the game is not excessively hard because they wanted for every type of player to be able to enjoy it and not just the hardcore ones. If you are looking for a harsh challenge however, this is not the game for you.- It is pretty easy to guess in which direction the story goes and how it will proceed overall.TL;DR: the game is loads of fun, it's extremely beautiful and will grant quite a few hours of enjoyment. A must play with your partner and/or friend! :)

author: WannaCuppaCoffee
review: Okay, I do realize that this is going against the grain, but y'all gotta know what you're getting into. It is a beautiful game, and they did an amazing job of making it look as good as it does. Fully immersed in the world, I'm 100% here for that. What I'm not here for is these pieces of garbage that are the "protagonists". I don't think there's been a point where I haven't looked at the both of them and gone "what is wrong with you?" There isn't any redeeming qualities of the characters. They keep doing things to their daughter or to each other and there's no apologizing, no recognition of the things they've done that may or may not have been traumatizing (IF YOU KNOW YOU FREAKING KNOW). They don't have any qualities that make me root for them or their choices. Now, onto the farce that is the writing. The story itself is good, it is, but there are absolutely UNNECESSARY things that the characters do that add nothing to the story. It's just for the jarring tonal shift to make them come across as horrible people who make horrible decisions. Plot twist, didn't need any of those occurances to understand or know that. Whether or not the story gets better after the climax is irrelevant. Be prepared for this game to test you on a lot of levels. Long story short, if you make the characters insufferable, why on earth would I want to play it? Don't play this with your significant other if you want them to actually want to play games with you. Devs, you guys make a beautiful game. You need to do better on making the characters worth playing as, as well as working on some specific scenes. I shouldn't leave a game feeling extremely sad and horrified at something I've done when I didn't get the choice to opt out or just not have to participate. At least make those parts something you don't have to play, or even come with some type of warning.

author: Average Bay Leaf
review: let me start by saying this is a very fun game to play. The levels are engaging, and game play is always changing. The art style is beautiful, and the scenery is more unique one level to the next. That said, as much as I enjoy the game, the writing of the story is pretty terrible. It feels like there is very little character development throughout the game, and there is one scene in particular that completely ruins the lighthearted nature of the game.           (SPOILER ALERT) There is a scene where you and your partner gruesomely murder a very nice sentient toy elephant, because of a theory they had to turn back into humans. They rejoiced after killing this creature, and making their daughter cry, even dancing in her tears. Instead of showing remorse for what they just did, they are pissed off that it didn't break the spell. They have no reflection of this terrible act, and move on like nothing happened. This is terrible writing in my opinion, and one of the worst moments I've experienced in a game. It is rare that a game makes me feel truly terrible, and changes my emotions beyond a surface level. Just as a comparison in COD MW2 there was a terrible/controversial level where you are undercover with a terrorist group. The difference here is in COD you have the choice not to shoot anyone, and as ♥♥♥♥♥♥ as it was, you were a pawn following orders. In this game, the terrible murder is unavoidable, not shown with any negative feelings, and was planned out by the main characters on a loose theory. Long story short, I don't recommend this game for kids anymore (even beyond the cuss words, and overarching themes), and even don't recommend it if you are emotionally sensitive. It is fun, but this one scene put a bad taste in my mouth regarding the main characters, and really lowered my opinion of an otherwise great game.

review: I played this when it was release. I would just say it's a must have game. Super fun co op experience. I just wish they add a dlc later which includes collectibles in each environment. author: Regrozenah
review: A fantastic game about genuinely terrible parents.There is a  level that is nothing but flashing colours, and there was no warning prior. , but this has no mention of it?  If I had known about this prior to streaming it, I might not have as I know at least one person who watches my streams that has epilepsy.If you aren't susceptible to epileptic fits, then i'd say this game is a must play.But if you are, I  recommend this game to you. Especially given that there's no noticable way to skip the level in question. So while this game is honestly really well made and super fun, i'm going to give it an actual  due to this. The lack of a warning, at the very least, is a mistake that could actually hurt people. This is something that should have been called out and rectified on release, and the fact that I've seen almost no-one mention it is actually kind of disappointing.

author: AK
review: This game saved my life.I am 69 years old.My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

author: Neensxo
review: It Takes Two is hilariously fun! I love co-op games that have replayable value as I'd likely be playing it with multiple friends and this game has certainly got it! The game went on a little long, but it benefited me since I had to play it with another friend, so by the time I played the first part again, it was like I was playing it for the first time. Totally worth getting! Remember friends, if you end up purchasing it, you can play it with friends who don't have it! They just need to download the friend's pass so your frugal friends have no excuse but to try it with you! If you're still unsure about whether its worth it to purchase, please consider my pros and cons below.Pros: Its a story based game, so you really become invested in the characters. Lots of different obstacles that rely heavily on team work and cooperative gameplay, so its certainly a great challenge.Each level is new and exciting so it keeps you wildly entertained.The mini tutorials help each step of the way, so you don't feel lost.Easy to pick up on mechanics and controls feel smooth.Mini games in between levels that keep your competitive spirit up. These games can be played infinitely as well.Easy to navigate chapter selections so when you leave and come back, it won't be difficult to start where you've left off. You have the ability to switch characters at the beginning of chapter selection or resuming your saved game. The great thing about being able to switch characters is that you can replay a chapter and try out the unique gameplay mechanic that the other character has.The level designs are ABSOLUTELY beautiful and creatively done.And lastly, has a great message and positively hilarious!Cons:Went on a little long.Although 99% of the controls were smooth, there were some stages (particularly the ones where there's a lot of movement), the controls were a little sticky. Story can be predictable and cliche.Dialogue scenes were sometimes too lengthy. Honestly..look at the cons. I was pressing to try to find cons. HahaAnyway, I hope you end up getting it. x Take care!

author: Tiramisu
review: Simply put, its one of the best coop games Ive played. A pretty rare occasion that I come away thinking I really wouldnt have minded paying more (Keeping in mind I got it 60% off!)From the name, and likely you already know, It takes two, takes two. It is splitscreen regardless of local or online, and the friend pass means you only need 1 copy to play it online.Its a nice mix of puzzle platforming, with an approachable level of challenge to both. Neither myself, or my not-the-best coop partner, were stuck on anything for too long. Interestingly, because of our setup atm, we played without voice chat (he doesnt have a mic - ordinarily we would be in the same room - and having just moved to a new place we are not even on the same floor.) So, if we failed on a boss for eg, without saying anything to each other we just tried again and generally had figured out what went wrong, and then worked together to succeed with many 'nice!' moments.Game ran fine, and looked very well. In fact part of what made it a blast was each location never overstayed its welcome. The environments all look top notch with great variety too. And each new location was accompanied by a new gameplay mechanic to keep you engaged. On top of this, there are mini games all over the place which you can quickly revisit from the menu too once you discover them. Brilliant stuff.The story is fine. Its about a failing marriage, which makes for a change from monsters/zombie and good v evil etc. The lead female did come across overly whiny and the child has a very punchable face IMO, but whatever! They are making this into a movie - which is neat, but I cant say Im counting down the days. Also, it was kinda funny that by the end I found their voices were so well paired with their dolls vs their real selves.Enjoyed it from start to finish, would not have felt bad paying full price honestly. Huge thumbs up :)

author: Jane Doe
review: While the game has an excellent visual style and complimentary audio engineering, the puzzles and gameplay itself really leave a lot to be desired. They will give you a gimmick for each level and fail to revisit that same gimmick in any capacity. In that respect - the game could have really benefited from a 'tool belt' system, allowing players to re-use tools and gimmicks from other levels in order to add depth to the puzzles. I imagine the game was intended to be extra casual for this omission alone.I'd still recommend the game just because of the friend pass system and length of the game being quite reasonable, just maybe not at full price.

author: ttv/Excel_Xesient
review: The second game from Hazelight, the dev from “A Way Out”, this time with more colorful and cartoony approach! I never play A Way Out before, but seeing everyone playing It Takes Two and seeing a glimpse of how beautiful the game is, I immediately bought the game at full price. Didn’t regret any of it!You only need one copy of the game to play together with your partner. And it uses a dedicated server as far as I know, and I have low to zero connectivity issues. The game did crash for both of us one time, but never happen again.You are playing as Husband(Cody) and Wife(May). Your marriage is on the verge of the end, but your Daughter(Rose) makes a wish that both of you can reconcile and fix your marriage. Through the help of a magical love book (Dr. Hakim), both of you turn into a living miniature doll! To revert the magic, you must follow the guidance of Dr. Hakim on what to do to fix your relationship with your partner. To be cooperative, to be understanding with each other, listen to your partner,  spare your time for each other, to reignite the love deep inside!Along the adventure, you gonna keep bantering with your partner about everything, and that is when we start to see the reason behind the divorce decision. But along with those, you also rediscover a little thing about your partner, that made you love them. A reminiscence of memory you spent together, from the silliest, dull thing, to a romantic one. Overall it is a heartwarming, hilarious, and joyful experience that you never gonna forget.At first glance, it looks like a Toy Story game, where you shrink and inanimate objects came alive. There are not a lot of enemies to fight with, but there’s a ton of puzzles and you need teamwork to do all of that, including defeating an enemy. Segmented with chapters, and each chapter has a unique theme that gives you a whole other experience that feels like a brand new game.The control move you can do is pretty basic, and you got a special item on each chapter to use, and you got a different item with your partner. It is predetermined on what you get on who are you playing as. Even tho the item does a simple thing, the application on the game is so genius and so varied, making solving a puzzle is not a daunting task, but a fun way to experimenting. The game is 3rd person view and sometimes there’s a shooter segment, but it still quite comfortable to play it with a controller.You can find dozens of minigame along the way, that you can procrastinate with to compete with your partner to determine who is better. You can play as long as you want, and even replay it from the main menu once you find it. There are also a few easter eggs to be found, and a fun achievement to unlock.This one is one of the main reasons that made me bought it. Not only is it rendered beautifully, but the art style is so cute and fun! They go hardcore on details and with each chapter with whole new themed, you never gonna be bored with it. From a simple garage, into a snowy field, underwater, and another magical world you dive into, be prepared to be awed by it.The music overall is having a cheerful atmosphere, knowing this is a fun and joyful game. The one that takes the trophy in my opinion is the voice cast behind the characters. With Cody and May being the ones constantly communicating, bickering, and joking, their character is really shown by their voice acting. And Dr. Hakim, it’s a either love it or hate it situation with Dr. Hakim, but in a good way! No matter what you feel about Dr. Hakim, he is a character that keeps lingering in your mind till the end of the game.Final ScoreIt is the best game I played so far in 2021. What really impress me is as my experience playing it with my partner, we do bickering in real life like Cody and May while playing it, and at the same time, we also being competitive while playing the minigames, also all the silly things that we can to in the game. All the experience Cody and May get in the game, in a way, also reflect to us as a player. Our feelings are mutual with Cody and May, and I think that is intended by the dev, and that’s what makes it’s a great game.

author: Breakfast Syrup
review: Really fun game mechanics, but absolutely abysmal writing. The moral of this story: if your marriage is falling to pieces, suck it up and stay together because otherwise your daughter will be sad. Overcome all obstacles and resolve conflict with violence and destruction. Despite how it looks, this ain't a cutesy, heart-warming game with healthy messages about love, cooperation, and supporting one another. It could've been so much more.

author: Simpson
review: I am playing through this game with my brother and although we have not finished it yet, after 3+ hours we can comfortably say it's already one of the best games of 2021 and one of the best coop games of all time.We played A Way Out (didn't finish it yet though) and while it was very good this game is on an entirely different level. The voice acting, the graphics, the art style, the controls, the game mechanics and the story (so far) are a 10/10. It feels almost like playing through a Pixar movie or playing a Nintendo-quality title, it's honestly that good. The basic controls are insanely tight and easy to use, up there with the best of platforming games. Every level introduces new game mechanics that only last for that level, and they're all very fun and never outstay their welcome. The characters are all very well done so far as well, and the voice actors have done a great job. The amount of detail in all the levels is also mind blowing.Neither I nor my brother have had this much fun playing a game in a very long time, it's a blast. And you only have to buy one copy to play through it. It's worth every penny.

author: lynxthecat
review: One of the best - if not just - the best couch co-op game that is available right now, especially if you can play with your second half. Story is charming, sometimes funny but also very serious at times - just when it's needed and multiplicity of ideas and mechanics is freaking stunning. You never get bored and each level is different. Lots of mini games. Lots of great references to other titles and genres. Creativity of Hazelight is mindblowing. Add to this really beautiful music and you'll get a superb experience. No wonder the game won GOTY 2021 on The Game Awards. Whoa!Josef Fares, you're the man!Also, f*ck the Oscars, hahahah!!!

author: Stabby McStabStab
review: There is no surprise why  has received many accolades including GOTY at The Game Awards. Outside of Overcooked, Mario Party, and a handful of other co-op games, there's few that muster the sheer amusement and belly-laughing joy brought on by this game.First off, the game's levels and characters are beautifully designed and incredibly functional.  The worlds are immersive and really creative.  There were so many times during our playthrough that my wife and I remarked to each other how cool our surroundings were.  There wasn't a hint of a glitch or technical sticking point throughout our 18+ hour experience.The real star is the diversity of game mechanics on display here.  From levels underwater, flying through the air, using magnets, teaming up with flammable goo and fire, transforming into a potted plant... the list goes on.  Each area introduces a fun, not too difficult to learn or master, ability set that keeps things fresh throughout this 3D platforming action / adventure.The worst part of the game, in our opinion, was towards the middle of the story where things took a dark turn.  Naturally stories have conflict, and they need to pile this on to fulfill the character arcs, but we just had less fun in that middle section.  In the end, the redemption arc makes it somewhat worthwhile, but slogging through what you undoubtably know will be a dead end before your characters realize themselves was a bit morbid and felt like checking something off of the list.  I was hoping to see some kind of return to the character you had wronged in the end of the game for some closure, but it never happened.  Oh well.In the end, this is a fantastic game to play with someone you know will be up for the adventure with.  You'll have fun, you'll get frustrated, you'll yell at each other, you'll laugh until you cry, and you'll eventually beat it knowing you had a great time doing so.  It's all about CO-LLA-BO-RATION!9 / 10 would summon the gyrating book again.

author: Hellsknight
review: I played through this game with a friend in a different country (East Africa - Israel) and i'm surprised to say there was no real lag as such, just a half second delay that was easy to compensate for. Only one person needing to own this game makes this such a worth while purchase too. In terms of the level design this game was amazing. My only knock against this is the writing and story being quite cringe with the main characters as well as the plot progression.Note - If you have a vision impairment, this game does work with magnifier and also includes text-to-speech for menus. A lot of the levels may have contrast issues for people with various color blindness, but sharing this co-op experience with someone else who has normal functioning eyes means that they can guide you.

author: Timestamp
review: Gameplay & Level design: Every level is extremely well made from start to end. The puzzles are challenging but never frustrating (apart from the Helltower, but that's optional). Every piece of furniture or jumping platform is a well made asset and placed perfectly. Nothing seems out of place and it's like living in a Pixar movie. Truly a work of genius. My favourite level has got to be the Time Town. Followed closely by the Dungeon Crawler level. Plot: A good 20+ hours of co-op playtime. It hits the right notes on its plot all the way through. The story involves two people on their quest to fix their relationship, while transformed into toy dolls. You get super powers in each level, and each power is unique and fun. They relate to attraction, spending time with each other, and the passions of each other's life. Gardening for Cody and Singing for May. The design for these concepts is truly stellar, and they work it into the story so nicely. From breaking the ice in the ice level to, literally, break the ice on their attraction again; and caring about their passions and supporting each other in what the other person loves to do, it involves the game in the story of the relationship well. Truly one of the best stories I've seen of a game, and I give the writers props for actually keeping a grip on me all the way through.Sound: Sound is A+ and all music and effects are spot-on. I think sound is underrated in most games, but this one has a truly triple-A sound direction by Gustaf Grefberg and Kristofer Eng's original tracks. Like the Pixar movie the game is inspired by, this sound track could be in any Hollywood picture. I loved the music of the finale chapter, where it was all about May's singing, and I was relishing in the creativity of the designer's imagination, as the superpower of May's singing was changing to the beat of the 70's guitar, 80's techno and all the fast paced on-rails races has soundtracks I'd listen to in my own time. Wonderful.Overall: Hazelight Studios is a great company and I fully expect masterpieces from them in the future. This was truly a game I did not expect to be blown away by, but this game blows its EA sponsorship out of the water and shines for the creators behind it. One thing I want to mention is that it has all forms of homages to other games, it has a full Dungeon Crawler level and side-scrolling platformer components, even a Street Fighter clone level fit with dodging and shoyukens. One of the best games I have ever played, and fully surprisingly too. If this isn't up there for Game of the Year in multiple awards I'd be shocked. 10/10

review: Incredibly good co-op game. Wish there were more like it! It's challenging in some areas without being brutal, and so long as one person if alive you never truly fail so it's supremely forgiving.I rarely write reviews, but I cared enough about this that I felt compelled to with this game. Honestly, the reason I originally got it was because I love playing co-op games with my wife but it's frustrating to have to buy the same game twice just to do it. Now that I've played It Takes Two, I can confidently say that not having to buy two copies is the least in the long list of reasons to get this game. Seriously, get it.

author: -[EUTW]- GiPPO
review: TLDR: buy this game!This is hands down the best 2 player split screen game I have ever played. I played with my girlfriend and we both liked it.It Takes Two was definetly made with the level of passion we see very rarely in today's games. Thank you Hazelight! Time to replay it with switched characters :)Pro:The story is great and impactful, with right amount of humor and references (which are also in game mechanics, characters and level design)Game mechanics are just brilliant. It changes on every level, so it doesn't get boring, it feels like you are playing a completely different game every time there is a new level. Also it creates a wonderful synergy between the two characters. You NEED to work together in order to complete the tasks, but do not worry, you WILL enjoy it very much. Although there are some rather difficult parts when you may need to start the sequence over and over again, it doesn't feel frustrating. I cannot put my finger on it, but it just doesn't make you rage at all. It feels like just the right amount of difficulty, forgiving checkpoint system and "death".Oh boy. The level design. The level design is just from another world. It is detailed to the last piece, looks astounding and just like the mechanics, it changes all the time. It never gets boring. Coupled with the well written soundtrack it creates an unforgettable experience.Cons:The only negative thing is the character (couple) development's pacing. It felt a little bit slow up until close to the end.Cody and May are a bit too stubborn. However the pro in this con is that it doesn't feel "cliche-y", it is not black and white, thus it is more real. I just feel there should have been a better balance in pacing.BUY THIS GAME!

author: Pandania
review: SUPER BIG PLUS: Only ONE of you have to buy the game for you to be able to play since this game has a Friend Pass download possibility. Story:Has an amazing story line, basically catches you immediately.    Gameplay:Fun and very interactive. This game had every genre of games. Boss fights, abilities, platform and lots of puzzels. It fits all, and its done very, very, very well. Its an absolute MUST play with your significant other or best friend.  Visuals:Absolute stunning visuals, and beautiful screenshot worthy scenery. Difficulty:You need to be somewhat of an experienced player, since there is so many form of gameplay. Not the most difficult tho since the game will somewhat help you. Overall an amazing game, very fun and pleasant to play, you literally forget the hours while ingame. My boyfriend and i do not understand how so many people end up breaking up after or during the game, if anything it brings you closer since you are forced to communicate and work together. We LOVED it. (We literally did not want the game to end. It was so amazing and fun!)

author: MACHENE
review: One of the best gaming experiences I have had in a very long time. A fun, story driven journey unique in its execution, with engaging and interesting puzzles and abilities, It Takes Two breathes life and creativity into every aspect of this game, giving the players something truly memorable. TA masterpiece of the cooperative genre, It Takes Two is a must-buy for those looking for a fresh and enjoyable cooperative experience with a best friend or significant other. I was doubtful of this game when it came to winning Game of the Year. After playing all the way through this game and seeing the wonderful gameplay, narrative, and moments it has to offer, I see now that the award was well deserved.A wonderful gaming experience, I give "It Takes Two" an 8.5/10 and I look forward to more from Hazelight in the future.

author: KittyKaut
review: The game would've been fun if we were actually able to play consistently. First issue was getting origin to actually launch the game. Then origin kept saying we were both offline and therefore could not invite each other. When we finally were able to get into the game it ran well up until the first boss battle in which my Player 2 kept crashing under 'Low Level Fatal Error'. Even after troubleshooting that issue it still crashes no matter what we do. I bought this game after having my BF mentioning wanting to play it but this entire game has been frustrating just to even start. I don't even want to touch that game anymore in case I go over the 2 hours and can't refund a game that doesn't even work.Update: Finally got the game working and completed it. The game itself was fun and it never felt like one person got all the cool tools. If the point of the book was to be hated the entire story then they did it right because we both hated the book the entire time. Another issue was the input lag or just complete lack of input detection especially when jumping. My view of the game hasn't really changed after completing it as it was an absolute hassle just to get it to work every time we wanted to play.

author: Steelheart
review: It Takes Two is an example how a great multiplayer game should be done and it is one of the best I have ever played. The developers managed to get all the aspects of the game right and the result is impressive and enjoyable. Let me start with the story, which is both serious, lightweight, sad and funny at times, it is a very nice cocktail and they balance it well, so none of these dominates too much and goes out of proportions. It is about relationships in general with its ups and downs, sometimes literally, being it a platformer :). Excellent narrative and characters, well crafted and diverse map design with gorgeous graphics and game mechanics that change from chapter to chapter, I must give special credit how creative they are. The map design allows for exploration in some chapters before pushing forward and there are in-built mini games you can discover and play together before progressing through the main story. They are excellently crafted and very enjoyable, a lovely addition. Boss fights are great, not too hard, fun and rewarding.The game has two characters and they do not only differ by the looks but every chapter they have a different arsenal of skills, tools and weapons. The main motto of the game is "collaboration" and you really need to interact with your partner to get through the levels. This imbalance and diversity works well and gives the game a very unique variety, a very nice design choice instead of a copy-paste approach. This also provides room for replayability, where you can switch the characters and have a totally different experience playing it. I cannot pinpoint any specific negatives, for sure I liked some chapters, design choices and weapons/tools better than others and did not enjoy all the mini games but this is very subjective. I already mentioned the game is not particularly hard, so for those looking for a challenging one, apart from the jumping and some trickier parts it is more on the pleasant side. I also felt some parts of the narrative were a bit dragging and not that engaging.Find a partner and play it, you will have fun for sure and it might also get you to think about relationships, which is not bad from a video game :).

author: Weyland's Here
review: Truly deserving of GOTY 2021. The game is spectacular - like, every aspect of it. Visuals, gameplay, feel, platforming, writing, music, audio. Everything. Each level is a memorable experience, each one giving you and your ally unique mechanics to tackle as you platform and solve puzzles - and all of that is wrapped in a unique romantic comedy story that ties everything together. The only real complaint I had at the end was that it ended, but I guess it can't really go on forever, huh?This game is a genuine work of art and manages to make every minute fun and whimsical and loaded with surprises. Don't do yourself a disservice by skipping this game, it's genuinely wonderful.

review: It's insane how many game mechanics this game has within it. It almost feels like a waste when just as you think you're getting hang of one mechanic it's already on to the next one. An absolute must play - game designers wet dream.

author: Rotlaust
review: ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ what a ride it has been! I am only about half way through the game and I cannot wait to keep going. An absolute masterpiece of a game, a co-op experience unlike anything else out there. The hardest laughs I have had in a game and a shared joy between my co-op player and I that is simply unparalleled. Every level plays like a new game, the mechanics change, you interact with the world differently no sooner then it starts to get stale. No game has ever worked so hard to keep you interested, motivated, and wanting to experience what comes next. I am completely floored by how genius every part of this game was made. You will go from platformer to 3rd person shooter, to top down dungeon crawler, to co-op flight and many more all in the span of a few hours. And the craziest part is that it all feels great! Every level is a new mechanic that keeps the gameplay fresh and engaging. Every level is a new part of the story building to expand on the interaction between the main characters and their daughter. It is a true cooperative masterpiece that deserves all the respect and praise it is receiving. Some puzzles are harder than others, but you will never feel completely stupid, just smart enough to get your way through them and on to the next part. Puzzles actually require communication and collaboration to complete, which believe it or not, is not common in most "coop" games. Each character has their own function, purpose, role in the game that requires that visual or audible communication is had. there is no obstacle that can be done as a solo player.  Brilliance. The story works because it's relate able, grounded and part of many peoples lives. Screw what any media outlet says about it, there is a story, it plays a role, and though the theme (divorce) is not unique, the method in which it is told, the style in which you experience it and everything in between are absolutely genuine. This dev studio is a gem, a company that I hope to stick around for a long time giving us the greatest coop experiences on the market, raising the bar for AAA companies to show what can really be done when you have a team of passionate, talented and motivated people collaborating on a project that they all feel actually matters.  They should all be proud of what they have accomplished, I only hope that EA see's this for what it is and does not smother it like every other great dev studio they have ruined. As a student of game design, and someone who has worked at Disney studios, games like this are rare. You should be proud Hazelight, you have made your mark on this brutish, uninspired, and greedy industry. I look forward to seeing where you take us next!

author: ♫ƒrágílé♫
review: Nowadays it's rare to find games that focuses on split screen co-op and are actually good. It Takes Two is a gem, an instant classic that prioritizes storytelling and keeps you hooked with it's unique gameplay. What's more is the gorgeous visuals and graphics throughout every level, it genuinely brings every scene to life. It Takes Two is definitely a game to play with your significant other, family, and or friends. Thankfully then, if you've already purchased the game your second player can play alongside you for free. Make sure you both have an EA account and Origin, you'll be needing them.This game is worth every penny spent and is easily deserving of it's Game of the Year title!

author: Llamanoodles
review: TLDR: love the game but it Origin login through steam makes it crash and loose progress making it not fun.We love the game the plot is cheesy but the game play is super fun. What really puts a damper is that this is not operated by steam but makes you go through Origin and and it crashes and looses your game progress. Each time it crashes you loose about 1 hour worth of progress. In the 5 hours played so far, it has already crashed twice right before the boss level and I am taking a break from redoing the third chapter to write this review. At this rate, we may not finish the game if it keeps crashing or drive over during a pandemic and play together locally instead of the online mode.
