review: Played this game with my woman, took about 30 hours to complete without grinding for any extra content and a tad bit of exploring. We loved every bit of the ride! From "accidentally" dropping me into a pit of lava to epic snowball fights, hardcore parkour and beaming at each-other when solving a puzzle, I loved playing this game and seeing her fall in love with it, too. Truly a beautiful experience and well worth the buy, even off-sale.Well-earned 9.9/10 (where's my ping function like in Portal 2, bro'h?)

author: Naisa
review: This game is probably one of the most brilliant games ever made. Not to mention it's made by one of my all time favorite developers who made Brothers: The Tale of Two Sons. I thought some of the puzzle mechanics were similar, to which I found out that it was indeed made by the same creators. The story is cute and pleasant and the game style has so much variety that it's enough to keep you occupied for hours. The only downside is that you must play this with another party.. it would be perfect if they added a single player option somehow.

author: Chipserz
review: It Takes Two is an excelent game from the same developers that came out with the fresh take on co-op games, A Way Out. It Takes Two features a fun platforming co-op experience with many refernces to other game series and genres such as rouge-likes and fighting games. The fun of It Takes Two is playing with a friend or loved one and experiencing this game's story together, as after all there are moments throughout the game where it does indeed take two to complete certain tasks and objectives. The references in this game are also very nice and interesting as they keep the game feeling fresh with different gameplay types, I won't dive deeper into those gameplay differences because I feel those are best to be left a secret, all for the experience of discovering them! It Takes Two is a great game that revisits something that games of the past used to do much more often, which was co-op gameplay, this game not only features great gameplay as a co-op platformer, but it also incooporates a deep (by today's standards of bland stories in anything that isn't a JRPG) story that makes sense for the characters in this story that themselves incorporate into the game's setting very well. Overall, I would definitely say this game deserves all the praise it has been getting, and I highly recommend keeping an eye out for developer "Hazelight" as their future is looking bright and I personally can't wait to see what they create next.

author: Ubbernaut
review: Coop perfection.From the presentation to the sheer variety of environments, challenges and even gameplay - the game is an absolute delight through and through. The sheer love, care and creavity the developers have poured into this lil' gem shows and it's something I cannot recommend enough for anyone still on the fence whether to buy it.

author: TheTitaniumDragon
review: It Takes Two is a co-op 3D puzzle-platformer game with a great variety of gameplay over the 14 or so hours it takes to complete it. You play as one of two members of a married couple who are getting a divorce, but a magical book of love intervenes, trying to force the two back together. As such, the entire game revolves around cooperative problem solving in a fantastical shrunken-down environment.The core cooperative gameplay of this game is quite decent. It is a 3D puzzle platformer at its core, with the main goal being to overcome various challenges to reach a destination, rather than exploration. The game is entirely linear, but it takes the player through a wide variety of environments, and does a good job of mixing things up.The main “gimmick” of the game is that you gain powers in each area of the game. In one area, one player might have a nail, and another a hammer head; this can be used to both nail stuff down, as well as to swing around from the nails using the hammer for the purposes of traversal. In another area, the characters are given silly guns by squirrels to go fight wasps, with one shooting globs of sap and the other being able to light them on fire and make them explode. Still later, you gain powers like the ability to shrink or grow, or walk on walls, or various other things.All of these are used to solve various environmental puzzles, usually revolving around traversal, but sometimes trying to make things line up or break something or accomplish some other task. These tasks vary considerably, and the game avoids repeating too much by changing up the gameplay not just between levels, but oftentimes within levels as well.This is a game that is afraid of the audience getting bored, and it generally does a good job of avoiding it; while a couple levels do linger a bit too long, generally speaking, it does keep things fresh.The fact that the players must work together constantly works really well; this isn’t a game where one player can just solve everything, both players have to work together to get stuff done. It’s a great coop game, and can be played both online and side by side. Interestingly, regardless of which way you play it, it is always played in split screen mode – the reason being that it is often necessary to see what your partner is doing, and often helpful for helping each other figure things out.Best of all, you don’t even both have to own the game to play it! Only one player actually needs to buy the game; the other player can join in via the friend’s pass version of the game, which makes it pretty ideal for sharing it with another person.If there is a complaint about the core gameplay, it is that while it mixes things up a fair bit, it is never really THAT great. It is always decent to good, but it never really reaches the point of greatness.On the flipside, however, the plot and story are rather weak. The protagonists actually have a good reason to split up, but their daughter doesn’t understand what is going on and is upset by it. The book is basically a product of their daughter’s distress, but unfortunately, it ends up not working out very well story-wise, as while the problems the characters have are brought up, they are never actually addressed.This is a huge lost opportunity, as while each area is supposedly addressing some sort of issue they have, none of these areas actually address the issue – playing inside a cuckoo clock is a cute way to represent that they never have enough time for each other or for doing the things they want to do, but the actual story never actually presents any sort of solution for the fact that one of the characters is working too much to spend any time with the family, while the other resents the lack of time they have with them (and frankly, does a rather poor job of being a house-husband).The problem is that the game sort of acts like there is some sort of progress here, even though none of it makes much sense as a means of actually overcoming their real issues with each other. I would have liked for the game to either resolve the issues in some way, or at least present a potential solution, or else have the characters be like “None of this has anything to do with actually solving our problems!” and have it all end with them being like “Nope, we’re getting divorced anyway.” The ending of the game isn’t particularly good or earned, and while it is a bit ambiguous, it’s not all that great.In all fairness to the writing, though, while the overall plot is lousy, the actual dialogue and situations are often amusing, and there are lots of funny moments where bad things happen to the characters and they jab at each other or lampshade funny things that are going on or make bad puns. There is a bit in the middle which is just pitch-black comedy as they try to “murder” one of their child’s toys in order to make them cry, thinking that their tears will help them break the spell, and the whole thing is really amusingly messed up.Overall, this is a great game to play together with someone; the puzzle-platforming works well, and there is some nice cooperative problem solving that isn’t overly difficult and gives you plenty of chances to chat while playing. But be aware that while the gameplay is competent enough, the story is not going to blow you away.

review: Undoubtedly the best game of 2021, one of the most creative works of fiction, and the new Standard for Co-Op-Games (like Half Life's Alyx for VR-Games). One of the few games I would recommend gamers and even non-gamers alike to play at least once in their lifetime. An honor I can bestow on only a few games.An unforgettable adventure.

author: Left-Handed Hamdog
review: The weirdest, darkest game I've ever played that isn't outwardly Horror-themed.  Between the sheer high-pressure cooperative gameplay and genuinely unnerving art direction and certain events, you will feel pressed.  It's a hell of a lot of fun to play with a close homie though, particularly if you've played other games with them before.  Definitely worth the money if you have anybody to sit down and go at it with.

author: Slaskeslask
review: Needs EA Origin in order to play the game. And even after my friend and I went through the hell of installing and creating EA accounts, it wouldn't let us add each other as friends, leaving us unable to play the game together despite sitting right next to each other. Known fixes to this issues includes disabling your firewall and antivirus. Yeah, no thanks.I'm sure the game is great, but it's a shame that they have EA as their publisher, forcing you to use their broken software to launch the game.

author: ConconZzz
review: I will recommend this game for sure. In many aspects, it's a great game, and it certainly deserve the best game of 2021. I like its level design, player tutorial, pathfinding, and so on. Especially for a two-player game, they really have to find a way to emphasize the importance of cooperation. This was a very difficult job and design because the two players' abilities had to be complementary (like a hammer and a nail). And, the level design has to be perfectly utilized in the design of the levels. I think all these things are reflected in the game wonderfully.Personally, I don't like the perspective the game offers about love and marriage. My parents got divorced a few years ago over something. And often two people decide to separate and it's not a momentary gamble. Even if there is mutual understanding and two people are TRYING to work out together, the core conflict is not resolved. Maybe I'm a little too subjective, but some of the views about love in there make me uncomfortable.Other than that, it's a good game.

author: Petrroll
review: Quite possibly the most creative game I've played in a while. A lesser developer would stretch each chapter to a full game and/or rehash things a bit more. But not here, every stage is different, and there are so many little details everywhere. Not a fan of EA but gotta say, 10/10.#elephantDeservedBetter

author: Polkaroo
review: I do not recommend this for anyone. Do not get it to play with your spouse. Definitely do not get it to play with your kid. Cute graphics and clever puzzles in kids toy environment lure you in at first. Then things start to take a dark turn when one of the characters gets the idea to kill a favourite toy. You assume it's just some kind of tension that will get resolved before long. But no. It then goes way way off the rails and the puzzles become about dismembering a stuffed elephant while it cries and pleads to not be hurt. If you are the kind of person who got a kick out of pulling legs off living things when you were a kid, or you have kids locked up in your shed for kicks, maybe you could tolerate this. The game creator is clearly an example of this type of person except that you are the one being damaged for his kicks, and paying for it no less. The premise of playing as a struggling couple was neat and the programmers did a great job. But like all the worst Pixar movie moments, nobody stood up to the boss and said "WTF? No."

author: Prince Warhero
review: Wow that was an amazing experience. One of the most fun games i have played. Takes the meaning of Co-op to the next level.Handcrafted visuals and amazing graphics with so much level of detail. Every single level was memorable and well done.  The clockwork level was my favorite visually with all the moving pieces and lights shining off them. Sounds, lighting etc everything top notch technically. No performance issues or anything ran so smoothly 2k maxed out with a 3070. Surprising how much they can achieve even without RTX.It's a lighthearted story about a broken marriage couple who start fixing their mistakes for their kid. Divorce is a serious issue, but the game isn't trying to explore it deep, it's just told in a breezy way which i liked very much. There are also some really fun side stories and characters that adds charm to the game.Gameplay is the star of the show.. There are total 7 chapters each with multiple levels and not a single moment felt boring. Every level is designed for coop , you discuss with the person you are playing with and solve puzzles. Every single level has some new mechanic/idea from the start till the end. It's not a challenging platformer , its more of experiencing cool things at same time some level of thinking together with buddy to solve the puzzles. Each character gets a different power in each level so we have to coordinate with the other to solve the challenges. All levels will make you go "damn that's so cool" with its design and mechanics. The controls, animations everything is just soo tight and snappy. My personal favorite was the Rose's room level full of cool toys with stuff like dungeon crawler wizard combat, shrinking power, gravity boots, ship combat , circus levels etc there is just so much.It's just so loving and perfect game that's fun throughout. There isn't a single flaw/issue i had with the game. Also thank's to devs for the Friends pass so if one person buys thats enough to play with their buddy. Kids or adults, even non-gaming audience can play this game and enjoy it, a great way to introduce them to gaming too. 10/10 GOTY contender . Sets the bar for platformers !

The corny metaphors, puzzles and challenges are entertaining, the artwork in the game is amazing, and there's always something new around the corner to keep you engaged. author: Trent Booty
review: i review games on steam after i 100% complete them! check out my reviews to see all the games i have completed!it takes two is a co-op action-adventure platformer developed by hazelight Studios and published by EA that released in march 2021. similarly to their first game "a way out," there's no single-player option, and only playable in either online or local split screen co-op. the game itself is basically a romantic comedy. the developers did a great job introducing cool new mechanics for a single part of the game only for it to be tossed away in favor of a NEW cool mechanic, that alone is just one of the many great things about this game, but i don't want to spoil any of it for you because this is truly one of, if not THE best game to come out in 2021.

author: Sam_Bonnet
review: This is the best co-op game I ever played, so much so that I don't mind going through Origin.- Every Chapter is completely different (not just in looks, but also in mechanics that are specific to chapter)- The game play is so varied, you never see same Idea twice and it always moves on to the next thing before something gets boring- Boss fights are awesome with multiple phases that are completely different- You have the option to skip all cut-scenes which is always appreciated for people who just want to play (Story is meh)- You can play with different friends after playing it with one person (They just need friend pass)- The game is very optimized with zero latency issues (I only have 8 gigs of ram and had no issue running in max settings)Tip: If you downloaded friend pass to test the game out, you do not have to download the entire game after you bought it (You can continue playing within friend pass itself, progress is saved too)(Download game to receive all the achievements earned at once)TL;DR Fantastic game where you can tell the devs really had fun making it. Can't wait for their next game 10/10

Mini games are fun and interacting with the environment can be funCons: * Way WAYYY too easy - should have a difficulty slider (if it could be harder it would be an easy 9/9.5)* Plot is obviously stretched out longer than it should be* Context behind chapters is so dumb at times but because the worlds are so beautiful, you forget that

author: Mr_Grey_Guy
review: A wonderful game, not only because of its story - which I haven't finished yet - but also because of its sheer unique design elements. Playing this with a friend, since you of course can't do it without one, is great and awesome. You gain the possibility to not only torture each other but also to help each other in unique and interesting ways. Solving puzzles is nice and not too complicated, especially with the included splitscreen which I personally really, really enjoy. But, of course, that is not all. The creativity the devs must've put in this game is impressive, since not only world design is awesome itself but also game mechanics are. The story itself is incredibly good and has a unique point of view by showing what our two lovely friends are going through and how they are changing on behalf their new presented environment. Coming back to the world design, I must admit that I can't really find the matching words to explain how generally impressed I am by it. It is - at some point - a childish world of course but on the other hand a sheer complex one with much puzzles to solve and many stories to discover. It is - I would say - a wonderful mix out of childhood memories and entertainment for everyone in  a matching age. Character design in connection with the world design is also incredibly well done and the overall "cuteness" of all these is awesome too - especially a few characters are still burned into my mind. However, even though the game seems funny and awesome at first, there are some dark sequences which I barely could pass because of their violent characteristics. A perfect example for such scene would be - everyone who played until here probably knows what I'll say now - the elephant scene, which I don't want to speak further about... This scene though really triggered my feelings of guilt and I was terribly disgusted by myself for passing such. But these specific scenes, however, are really giving the game a special turning point and character, since it is not only influencing you in a positive but also in a negative and sad way. So, regarding that I personally do not have anything to complain about it, since everything is basically matching up in a perfect way, I can totally recommend it! Your money will be spent right!

author: matheod
review: The game is very nice. It have a lots of different gameplay and a good duration. Around 14h to finish it (or quicker if you have a better partner :D) while playing at most minigame.However, I often get ejected from online (and it's not the fault of my network) which is very annoying because the game have no auto reconnect. If the server have a 1s issue, you get eject from the game and you have to restart from the last checkpoint. Luckily there is lots of checkpoints.Also we are forced to play online because the game doesn't support LAN which would have avoid me trouble with their network issue. I also wonder if this means we will not be able to play the game when they close server in a few years (i don't know if it's a specific server for the game which will close one day or if it's a general server for all origin multiplayer game).Also the game force user to use Origin which is a very bad move from devs.So the game is nice, and I recommand it. However, because of network issue and also because of the origin obligation I will give it a bad review. But you should absolutly buy it and play it !Also only one of the two player need to buy the game :)

author: Nab
review: Impressive production of a collection of casual minigames. This is not a game to beat, just entertainment. About as challenging as watching netflix. Depending on how you consume games, especially coop, that might be a good thing. I had some fun, but it was entirely an forgettable time.Things gone wrong:- even the standalone multiplayer friendpass app runs in split screen. smaller field of view is already annoying but more importantly: no need to communicate which pretty much defeats the purpose of coop.- The protagonists are unlikable, stupid and obnoxious. The 3rd main character is just unlikable and obnoxious which is fine. but ticking all the boxes for the players.... nah- hold 'Y' to fix relationsship. Why don't I try that more often on Tinder?- any situation can be resolved by applying gratuitous amounts of violence. Still not resolved? more Violence!- pretty but empty filler sequences - rail sliding without interaction, run through this empty corridor, etc

author: Bear
review: + lots of content+ very good visual- oh dear, the narration \ character speech is so stupid, sometimes I have to remove the headset- the characters sometimes acting inconsistent. Once want to kill an elephant who begging for her life and screaming, 5 minutes later they have bad feeling about some stationary pigs who carried into the butchery- the game is overhelping, and the characters shouting what has to be done, even before you would have time to look around in the room. No help hint settings. - the third party access is painful, the origin client is painful, you update steam, update origin, update the game, oh boyAltogether it's a very good game, it's stunning how much visual design work is in it, and how much you can explore\discover even outside of the main quests. There are lots of things to jump to, hang on, look for - if your game partner lets you to.But the characters are so painful, I wish there were an option to silence them, or turn off the roleplaying, or whatever.

author: cimmee
review: Absolutely great game! I'm such a sucker for co-op puzzle/adventure games and getting the chance to play this with my boyfriend was an amazing experience!We ran through it at a steady pace - getting to explore and have fun while diving through the levels consistently - it never felt like things were too challenging but occasionally tricky enough where it was still enjoyable. We played with the friend-pass as we're long-distance and the controls were very responsive, hardly any lagging (provided you have good internet).The game is absolutely beautiful and so many times during a cut scene we would mention how this would make a fantastic movie and it'd be a great experience to even watch that alone.All in all 10/10 game and I look forward to replaying it to complete those extra achievements we fell short of through the first round :)

author: Robospider456
review: Wow. What a game. Absolutely stunning visuals, and thrilling gameplay. This game only comes with one major flaw: it doesn't last for 300 hours, but I could sure play it that long. Every time a new concept is introduced I enjoy it thoroughly, and every time a new segment begins, I'm sad there's no more of the last one. Grab a friend, put on your puzzle pants, and GET THIS GAME.

You can headbang your way through all of the boss fights without much penalty for death. But I suppose that's a good thing given the target audience.

author: Naksutam
review: I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

author: Tyrodos
review: I don't often leave reviews, but this is one of the best games i've ever played. It's mind boggling how this game allows 1 person to purchase the full game for another to access the entire game. I would EASILY say this game is worth the full price PER PLAYER. Detail and game play:Each and every level is unique and detailed down to every pixel. Boss fights and mechanics are challenging but not tedious. You may wonder why the hell this game is 40GB in size, but when you play it for yourself you will understand why. Each chapter and mini chapter is like a whole new fantasy world, each new mini chapter is a genre of any famous genre of game. You have abit of Tekken, Crash Bandicoot, Little Nightmares, Dance dance revolution, Dungeon Crawling, Fantasy RPG etc.Character development:Dr Hakim, the book responsible for helping fix your relationship is an extremely lovable character played perfectly. You run into new characters in every chapter which the game does a fantastic job of creating a bond between you and them really pulling your emotions in and viewing life in their position. It does a great job in making you feel terrible about what has to be done, really displaying how much emotion it pulls from you.Overall this is the best Co-op Game puzzle game released till date and i would highly recommend purchasing it. Story: 10/10Detail 10/10Character development 10/10Overall 20/10.Seriously well done developers.

author: JOE ROGAN
review: This is probably the most fun and touching game I've ever played. The gameplay is constantly evolving keeping the game fresh and you are at no point bored with the story. This is perfect to play with friends and probably ends up winning game of the year. There are so many references and cool easter eggs and the world is beautifully built both visually and gameplay wise. I can not recommend this game enough, definately worth the price!

author: thepolishone28
review: The most creative and gorgeous game I have played in years! Im playing with a friend while another friend watches and helps us out with the puzzles and he's still having fun. This game keeps you entertained the whole way through - each level is completely different in theme and mechanics so you constantly have to learn something new. Some chapters feel like a completely different game. And the level design and little extra mini games they put in this game are genuinely hilarious at times. Cant recommend this game more!

author: Ghost
review: When I got this for me and my friend to play I knew nothing about it. I thought it would be a quick 3 hour or so time waster that would give us something to do.Instead what we got was 13 hours of pure hilarious fun and enjoyment.This game is a masterpiece. Everything from the character development to the level design to the easter eggs from other games was absolutely fantastic.We laughed and cursed while doing stupid ♥♥♥♥ to each other like in Portal 2. 10/10The entire story was wonderful from beginning to end .... 10/10The mini games were a nice break from the story to sit and do something odd and eventful. 10/10The animations, music, levels, puzzles, and chapter arcs were fantastically made. 10/10One thing I was really surprised by was there was very little to no bugs that we ran into. 10/10I am so glad that I ran across this game. I would be willing to play through the entire thing again and again with every one of my friends who wants to play it and I would buy them the whole game as well instead of using the "friend pass" just so I could keep supporting the developers. This was an amazing ride from start to finish. We loved every single part of this game (except one sad part ...you'll know it when you get to it... we still feel horrible).I have one question for the developers though ....... WHERE IS THE FAMILY DOG..... I MUST KNOW WHERE THE GOOD LOOKING DOGGO IS FROM THE VIEWER PICTURES. Overall this game is amazing and everyone should definitely give it a try. You wont regret it at all.

author: DestroyerOfComputers
review: I'd recommend this game if it wasn't for Origin being required for online multiplayer.You can't invite steam friends, and you can't have Origin already open when playing through steam (it literally closes it then RE OPENS ORIGIN THROUGH STEAM). The game itself is great fun. Getting it running? Not so much. I wasted probably half an hour trying to get it to be playable with a friend that I had on my steam friends list. Neither of us use origin much because of how bad it is, but we decided this game looked fun enough to play together to be worth it.Origin search for friends? Terrible. Only way they come up is through email. We tried name and (apparently case sensitive) Player ID both and they results in nothing. Tried email resulted in them showing up right away. Added, then they didn't appear on friends list. Restarted Origin, restarted It takes two, and they didn't appear. Had to Task Manager + End Process for both for friend to appear on friends list.Please EA, just stop using your DRM. It's horrid, and Origin is bad.EDIT: They just updated Origin and deleted it in order to give the EA App installed on my computer.It Takes Two now requires 95% of my GPU. My GPU is a Nvidia GTX 3050. The recommended for this is a GTX 980, for context. That's on the starting screen for It Takes Two. How? I can only presume the EA App and It Takes Two are so badly optimized (and/or have such poopy anti-piracy programs in them) that it's requirements are a GTX 4080.

author: Mario
review: It Takes Two is a decent co-op platformer 6/10The focus of the gameplay, platforming, gets repetitive after the first few hours. The game would have benefited from being shorter. The insane variety of gameplay is both a lot of fun and very frustrating. The best mechanics are too often short lived, while long bouts of the game have little going on.  I would consider the story, characters, and dialogue to be mediocre and often cliche, though the dialogue did give me an occasional chuckle. Overall I thought the "message" and narrative were mismanaged, leaving me feeling nothing about the characters or story. The game is a lot more fun if you don't take it seriously.The graphics are top-notch and the environments are often very impressive, though I do wish they were more engaging. The game feels like an Unreal Engine showcase meant to impressive the general public. While overall a decent experience, not a gamer's game and not something I ever wish to revisit.

author: Roma
review: It Takes Two is a phenomenal, unique co-op game unlike any I've ever played, with varied gameplay and a compelling story. My girlfriend got it for me for my birthday so we could play together, and it was really fun!! However, given that we're in different continents, we had to rely on the online mode- which was downright unplayable an alarming amount of times. There was a constant lag in our games, but it especially made timing based mechanics a nightmare and certain bosses impossible to beat (I called in my sister to help me play these parts, as there doesn't seem to be issues with local mode). If there wasn't the timing issue, then the game was suddenly disconnecting her (may be related to the Friend Pass?). Unless you're playing together in local mode, I don't know if I can recommend this game because of the sheer number of issues we encountered- which is unfortunate because it was otherwise a delightful and fun experience.

review: DISCLAIMER & VERY MINOR SPOILERS!Other than that, the game is a masterpiece of variety and accessibility.14 hours worth of content, all varied, all high quality.Seriously, the gameplay variety here is astonishing, just about every chapter has different mechanics, from shoot-em-ups, to 2D combo fighters, Diablo style hack-and-slash to rhythm games along with 25 mini-games and even a few more side-activities and a couple of neat Easter eggs.This game really is a high-standard for coop games, Hazelight finally nailed down their specialty.Looking forwards to the next one.

Played with my partner and there was not a single moment where frustration overtook fun, it was fun throughout the entire game and I had no complaints halfway through and have no complaints now that I've finished it. I could certainly see myself playing it again and switching characters because there is SO much to explore that we even missed through our 19 hours of playing. I am in awe and this is one of my absolute favorites I've ever played now. It felt just so smooth and enjoyable. I just have no other way to say PLAY THIS GAME! It is SO worth it and the friend pass alone is just so generous! Blew co-op gaming out of the freakin' WATER!

Apart from the mini-games, most of the game was a linear grind towards more disappointment. If you both enjoy story/controller games, this could be really fun, but for us, this wasn't the case.

author: Ogonsan
review: Honestly, considering all the positive reviews, I had to write this.First of all, the fact that you need Origin (the EA platform) to launch this was a very bad surprise. The gameplay and puzzles are extremely straightforward. There are lots of different things to do, but each sequence is awfully simplified. I would describe this game as "an accumulation of very dumb mini games".The story is about "cooperating", but if we're honest, there's barely any cooperation at all. You do the actions that they tell you on screen, and your friend does the same thing. As there's dual screen, I don't think I ever needed to say "oh, could you give me that object next to you ?" (even though my friend is not an English native and we really struggle to understand each other sometimes !). We knew exactly what to do almost all the time, because the game is designed to be a smoothless experience.The most fun moments were the platforming parts, that were well made. But the rest, in my opinion, doesn't have any flavor.I didn't enjoy the character designs either and most jokes are cringe. Maybe a fun game if you play with kids. But if you are two adults that want a coop puzzle game, I would not buy this game. Instead, I would recommend playing Portal 2 coop. There is no comparison possible between those two games.

author: Gametrap
review: I played the game with my friend through friend pass, and have purchased it solely to review it because i do not understand how it won game of the year or has so many positive reviews.                                                                                                                          Both of the parents are terrible, selfish people that the game makes me care less and less about as the story progresses. Neither of them have much character besides being horrible parents, the mom is the breadwinner and the dad likes plants and is forgetful. That's pretty much it for character development. The book is an annoyance that tries to solve their relationship by making them do things together(with unskippable cutscenes that I really want to skip) instead of talking about their problems and possible solutions like how normal people solve their differences. The child I feel sorry for, but her character is not very developed, so I don't really feel for her besides increasingly sorry that she has such parents as the story progresses. This game made me feel sad, for the girl and that such self centered people are lauded as good parents.                                                                                                          All the mechanics are variations on click this or you click and I click, they are a pretty cool at first but the game never delves deeper into them, it just switches into a new one and resets the difficulty on the puzzles, never to bring that mechanic back.    The difficulty would start at the right level, telling you how to use a new thing, and then teaching you a couple new ways to do it but would then plateau there until it started from the easier difficulty with a new mechanic. Some of the mechanics were very fun(the goo gun) but none ever carried over to another level and they always got boring as the difficulty stopped increasing. Usually in a game they introduce new mechanics as a way to solve puzzles in different ways, or once there are several tools to use they have different ones in different parts of the level to mix it up. This game was a straight path all the way through, there was one right way to progress and the game made it pretty easy to see. That's not an inherently bad thing, as the squirrel level showed, but for the rest of the levels it got very monotonous as the the rooms stopped increasing in difficulty and just made you show that you knew how to solve the same problem just with a couple things changed.    The bosses were one of the few high points of the game, they were decently hard and were actually fun. They took the basic mechanic and made it a harder to execute or had new things to deal with. The toolbox was the one time me and my friend died this game. When playing this it made me a little sad though, cause if the boss was this fun and had a twist on the basic gameplay they know that people like it when they mix up how a mechanic can be used to do something, but did not include any of these concepts on the rest of the level design.                                In short: this game told a terrible story about horrible parents that should indeed divorce as it was holding my hand through puzzles and then made me torture an innocent creature in order to progress(literally the only reason I didn't quit there was because this won game of the year so I wanted to see why). The few high points did not make up for the rest of the monotonous game. It make me question my worldview that this won game of the year and so many positive reviews and the only negative ones are about the client.    If anyone wants to play a real puzzle for two people play We Were Here(the first one is free) there is a real two player puzzle, with actual communication needed to solve puzzles, which in my opinion is the reason two player puzzles exist.

If you're like me, and your significant other isn't as learned or skillful in video games, this is also perfect. The awesome mechanics and still somewhat challenging game-play kept it interesting for me, but was still easy enough for my wife. 10/10 Would buy, play, and recommend again!

author: Emu
review: I'm not gonna lie, I wanted to like the game. I really did. But I stopped playing midway through and gave up. Underneath the cute art, it just felt long and repetitive. I thought playing for ~6hr would be a little over half of a story game and, if it wasn't, there would be some sort of character development, but it really drags out with the same thing-different level concept: get item, work together, master challenge, reset with different items in a different level and start again. The characters also just kind of annoyed me. While my game partner and I didn't enjoy it, two other of our friends did, so I guess it really depends on what sort of things you like. As they say, to each their own.The game overall quality wise is well made, but I guess just not for me. The biggest advice I can give is to watch a video of the gameplay first before you buy it to make sure it matches your tastes/expectations.

I highly recommend playing with your girlfriend / wife as it is more of a family game than having fun together with friends.The level design is cool, the graphics in some areas are stunning. The overall score is .We've managed to make 100% progress, but on the clock it takes hours. Be sure to research each step if you wish to do so.In the beginning, the game is really sad and terrible. In some of the opening chapters there is an elephant, that has been damaged so much ... This game reminds me of a "Toy Story" movie in which we look at the world from the perspective of a toy.- gameplay,- graphics and level design,- plot and personalities,- puzzles and boss fights, can look like "souls-like" genres if you're out of luck.- strange bookman, which we called "pablo"; he is very annoying- huge fps drops in some areas.

author: menace
review: BEEF WELLINGTON RECIPE :STEP 1Heat oven to 220C/fan 200C/gas 7.STEP 2Sit the 1kg beef fillet on a roasting tray, brush with 1 tbsp olive oil and season with pepper, then roast for 15 mins for medium-rare or 20 mins for medium. When the beef is cooked to your liking, remove from the oven to cool, then chill in the fridge for about 20 mins.STEP 3While the beef is cooling, chop 250g chestnut (and wild, if you like) mushrooms as finely as possible so they have the texture of coarse breadcrumbs. You can use a food processor to do this, but make sure you pulse-chop the mushrooms so they don’t become a slurry.STEP 4Heat 2 tbsp of the olive oil and 50g butter in a large pan and fry the mushrooms on a medium heat, with 1 large sprig fresh thyme, for about 10 mins stirring often, until you have a softened mixture.STEP 5Season the mushroom mixture, pour over 100ml dry white wine and cook for about 10 mins until all the wine has been absorbed. The mixture should hold its shape when stirred.STEP 6Remove the mushroom duxelle from the pan to cool and discard the thyme.STEP 7Overlap two pieces of cling film over a large chopping board. Lay 12 slices prosciutto on the cling film, slightly overlapping, in a double row.STEP 8Spread half the duxelles over the prosciutto, then sit the fillet on it and spread the remaining duxelles over.STEP 9Use the cling film’s edges to draw the prosciutto around the fillet, then roll it into a sausage shape, twisting the ends of cling film to tighten it as you go.STEP 10Chill the fillet while you roll out the pastry.STEP 11Dust your work surface with a little flour. Roll out a third of the 500g pack of puff pastry to a 18 x 30cm strip and place on a non-stick baking sheet.STEP 12Roll out the remainder of the 500g pack of puff pastry to about 28 x 36cm.STEP 13Unravel the fillet from the cling film and sit it in the centre of the smaller strip of pastry.STEP 14Beat the 2 egg yolks with 1 tsp water and brush the pastry’s edges, and the top and sides of the wrapped fillet.STEP 15Using a rolling pin, carefully lift and drape the larger piece of pastry over the fillet, pressing well into the sides.STEP 16Trim the joins to about a 4cm rim. Seal the rim with the edge of a fork or spoon handle.STEP 17Glaze all over with more egg yolk and, using the back of a knife, mark the beef Wellington with long diagonal lines taking care not to cut into the pastry.STEP 18Chill for at least 30 mins and up to 24 hrs. Heat oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6.STEP 19Brush the Wellington with a little more egg yolk and cook until golden and crisp – 20-25 mins for medium-rare beef, 30 mins for medium. Allow to stand for 10 mins before serving in thick slices.

author: Dalkavuk
review: This game is the one of the best games I have ever played. It may seem like a childish game with its setting and the main events but there is a certain grimness behind that naïve world (you can check the negative reviews for that part). Even though frame of the story isn’t spectacular, enjoyable dialogues and story elements make it more than fine. Unexpectedly, game has some great songs and these songs have a great harmony with the levels. The most well-made part of the game is level design. None of the levels have the same mechanics with each other, other than a tiny platforming mechanic. Every level offers you a different experience and each of them is different for different characters. Because of that, you can finish the game twice without getting bored. Plus, game length isn’t short for sure (it took us 16 to finish). Sadly, game requires Origin account for at least one person but you can play with Remote Play too. Our problem with Friend’s Pass, which is the system to play with only one purchased game, was the only problem with the game which we were able to fix it. Obviously, I definitely recommend this game to everyone (maybe not for the people who want to play with their children).

author: The very same Mikaela
review: It Takes Two is a co-op game about married couple that is on the edge of a divorce. The only thing that keeps them together is their daughter, Rose. She cries on the toys that looked like her parents and they turn into dolls. Rose asks a very annoying book of love (that will follow us during whole game) to help her parents become friends again and that’s where our adventure begins.The  of this game is amazing. We travel through different locations that mean a lot to the members of the family. We explore places that help us see each other in a way we saw before. All areas are different, so you’ll never get bored of same decorations. The  of the game is unbelievable! How many times we stopped to enjoy the beauty of the world around us. The  is wonderful and doesn’t distract from gameplay.In overall I would recommend this game for everyone. You can play this game with your kid (though he may not fully understand the main idea), with your other half (nice opportunity to spend time together and remind your first joint impressions).

author: YouMakeMeASandwich!
review: This is a co-op game for exactly two players.Game provides ¬12 hours of light cooperative gameplay which is not repetitive - different scenes, different mechanics, lots of different minigames. This and the distribution model when only one person have to buy the game is a perfect combination that makes this game really good.Players will encounter lots of well-designed scenes(levels) and easy versions of various genres e.g. platformer, various race versions, TPS, flight, slasher, puzzle, bullet hell, etc and a million ways to die by the hand of your teammate. Most of the time game is in split-screen mode which seems to have no synchronization problems,There are some negative things:1. It is hard to say what is the target age of players - the game has a story which is too dumb for adults and too hard to be understood by children. To me all the cutscenes were annoying and we did not found a way to skip it(maybe there is one). However the story is sometimes so absurdly dumb that makes it laughable, but that's rare.2. Controls are made by a sadist. Have you seen somewhere else walk/run switch binded to CAPS? Well, at some parts of the game it changes to shift. There is autoaim auto camera focus things that you CAN NOT!!! turn off. When you need to press buttons for notes it is not buttons that are nearby - it is Q, E, and a Spacebar. Movements in top-down mode is just ♥♥♥♥ up as much as it could - good luck on not dying after dash. Most of the game beating the poor controls design is times harder than beating the location (EA - Challenge everything!).3. Game launches through origin which is bad an inconvenient, you have to own an account there and your friends have to be added there too, It sometimes drops the connection for no reason, but the saves are made locally so there will be no problem in resuming the game when the server is back, Overall ingame bugs are rare and insignificant. Twelve hours of gameplay ends exactly when it exceeds the fun part,At least movement keys are not random and they don't rotate too often.Good except for the dialogues.Game is easy and it is meant to be that.Very nice, in fact that is the strongest part of the game implementation,High quality.Most times everything is very good, but there are things like wrong animation direction for swinging, reflections which does not represent original objects and lots of other minor physics fckups. (People who had no childhood AND skipped physics classes should not design swinging!)Ok, nothing to mention.Ok, nothing to mention.Ok, nothing to mention.Story is poor, dumb and absurd.27 different minigames including chess - would've been a perfect addition if not fckdup controls which ruinsa third of the total count. Still very good.Big scenes has a lot of interesting interactive objects.

author: GRADE F
review: Josef Farez and his incredible team did it again!It Takes Two is one of the most, if not the most, imaginative game I've ever experienced.The game is jam packed with various game mechanics, gimmicks, tender and thrilling moments.Not to mention it has some of the most jaw-dropping environment designs.The way the game unfolds in telling how to fix a relationship through examples via game mechanics, which later makes May and Cody gradually have a better teamwork is handled brilliant. It is both bombastic and subtle in certain moments.A very story-driven game that takes its time to tell its story, pays attention to the importance of environmental storytelling and not be super melodrama in telling a "divorce" kind of story. It Takes Two is arguably Josef Farez' masterstroke, a remarkable achievement from the director and team who made Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons only 9 years ago.

author: Hunter
review: Incredible game to say the least. Took almost 15 hours to complete and not one time did I get bored or feel like the game was dragging on too far. Every level and section in each level is different and incredibly creative. Was a rare genuine gaming experience to have in 2021 with how poor game launches and micro-transactions are. Didn't encounter a single bug in the game or any issues. Zero micro-transactions as well which is awesome. There is also 25 different mini games you can discover throughout the game that add to the depth even more. From slot cars to full on chess, its really well done. Must play for anyone who wants a relaxing gaming experience.

author: kittmint
review: I've played tons of games varying from different genres and even have my own personal favorites but this, this game just has a very special place in my heart. I don't even have anything bad to say about this because everything is just so beautiful and carefully done by the developers from animation to story to level designs. Even the soundtrack is outstanding.I played this before via the Friend's Pass and finished the game with my boyfriend. This kind of saved our relationship the same way  From start to end, I find myself falling in love with the story and its characters and falling more in love with my partner as the story progresses.So what was the best thing to do? Buy the game for myself and play it again with him just so we could experience the adventure once again.Some of the things that made me love this game:In general, I think this game really deserved winning GOTY. This was too well-made. With a game length of more than 12 hours (our first playthrough was roughly 17 hours) and only worth $39.99 (PHP 1799)—I got this at 63% off sale while my boyfriend bought it for its full price—this is unexpectedly  a cash grab despite being published under EA. Not to mention the FREE Friend's Pass.TL;DR Buy it. Play with your loved one, a friend, or just anyone you want to enjoy a wonderful experience with. Definitely a great bang for one's buck.

author: N4te
review: If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.Ingredients:1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter2. 1/2 cup white sugar3. 1/2 cup brown sugar4. 1/4 cup water5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon6. 1 pinch salt7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced8. 1 pastry for double-crust pieDirections:1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

author: Pogi
review: It takes two is an ambitious game. It really wants to do a lot. There is no doubt that the art style is absolutely its highest point. There are so many interesting environments with different themes that are absolutely a joy to experience. However, all other game components of It Takes Two were rather poorly executed and made the game, despite its great presentation, a very mediocre experience. Let’s explore why.The story of It Takes Two is something that most of people recognise as a low point of the game. Therefore I do not intend to spend too many words on this topic. To me the quality of the story wasn’t really that important as the game is primarily a co-op platformer - a genre in which the gameplay is an absolute king and the story is just a nice bonus.Though I must mention that I do not remember a game where the story would so actively ruin my enjoyment of the game as It Takes Two did. The two characters that you control are just horrible. They are toxic and one dimensional. The game has many cutscenes where you basically just watch these two characters arguing in intense and less intense situations. One throwing really bad jokes and cringe punchlines, while the other bitterly reacts to everything. Virtually all the dialog is delivered in shouting so everything hits even worse. But what really ruins the experience is that characters’ shouting comments continue into the gameplay.For me, a big reason why couch multiplayer is awesome is because you can share great moments instantly with someone next to you. You solve problems together and share the joy of beating a boss or figuring a difficult puzzle out. You discover new environments and feel mutual thrill in doing so. But it is hard to form your own experience and opinion when in-game characters just interpret everything you see, before you can even process it yourself. Characters in It Takes Two just wouldn’t shut up. They keep telling you how you should feel about stuff and that aspect alone ruined a big portion of the game. It truly took away most of the wonder that game has otherwise visually successfully created.Luckily I discovered that there is a setting, that lets you mute all the in-game dialogue. I can’t describe you how big of a difference that made. We still played with the subtitles on, but I think it wouldn’t hurt to also turn these off as you will have much more interesting experience interpreting everything that is going on the screen.Next let’s talk about the gameplay. It Takes Two is a 3D platformer. The character movement feels nice - it is fluid and responsive. Although I think that the move set is too powerful. Right from the beginning you get dash, wall jump and double jump. Although thats fine, the powerful movement set pretty much makes the platforming challenge obsolete. Timing and making precise jumps is almost never a challenge. You just fly through stages and ultimately fail to appreciate all the visual spectacle that the game throws at you.The other aspect of the gameplay is cooperation mechanics. Each level introduces new tools that our characters use. One has ability A and the other ability B. Together you combine these abilities to get through the stage. But no matter the provided tools, the task is always a version of one character moving / placing platforms, so the other can then jump across. After that the other opens some kind of doors so the players meet and together move to another stage. This kind of gameplay is repeated thorough the game, but with different coat of paint. And by the end of the game it really felt rather stale.Another problem is that the game keeps introducing new mechanics and abandoning old ones. As a result, you don’t really feel any kind of progression in terms of feeling more powerful and skilled compared to the beginning of the game. Maybe they should make double jump and dash as permanent upgrade that you acquire after beating a certain boss. And maybe they should let you keep the tools you acquire thoroughout the game. This way the puzzles and obstacles could be more open ended and you could use a combination of tools.Some of the tools were definitely better than other. For example, I really liked the snow globe magnets, collaborative garden fights, Space level mechanics, and fight with boats. But all these cool concepts get replaced instead of being built upon. Some of them get abandoned so quickly that they just feel off and out of place for such game. For example the biggest offender was the lame castle wizard section.Because of the hectic gameplay, intrusive story and lack of any meaningful progression, the game felt rather boring despite beautiful environments. In fact all the environments were changing so quickly that I always felt somewhat rushed to experience them. And because of that, I failed to connect with the game. I understand that there is the market for such games. In fact I think it’s a great game for casual gamers and kids. But it really lacks depth. It’s mostly just a visual spectacle.I invite you to check my Best local coop games shelf if you want some more couch multiplayer fun. I am always looking for new and exciting titles.

author: Min
review: It forces you to install EA.app, and automatically set it to open when you start your PC, without your permission. Even if you quit the app, there's still a process called EA background service running. This EA.app comes with the game also seem to be some kind of crippled version of it, if you try to login with your EA account it automatically quits after verifying your password. So the only way you can open the EA.app and disable launching when PC starts, is to open an EA game from Steam and alt-tab into the EA.app then do so in settings.

author: Seachelle27
review: I really enjoy playing these types of puzzles games with my husband so I was able to overlook quite a bit. The characters are constantly arguing and taking shots at each other. Fine i can deal. The puzzles and the atmosphere were super fun rather Little Big Planet-esk. However...there is one task you must do that made me feel internally awful and could not complete it. We shut off the game and uninstalled it... **Spoilers below***********************************************************************************************************You are 2 parents getting a divorce and you get shrunk into these 2 dolls. You come up with a plan that if you can get your daughter to cry then her tears will turn you back to normal. Sooo you decide you need to break her favorite toy which is a sentient elephant queen that is crying and pleading with you not to kill her because she does not want to die. She gets stuck and you RIP HER LEG OFF. As you are dragging her to the edge of the shelf, to throw her to her death, her ear gets pinned and I'm assuming you also rip her ear off but at this point I said no and shut it off. Meanwhile, this ENTIRE time the elephant is pleading and crying with you to stop. I really wanted to see this game through but it was too much. Good luck!

author: IzzySkr33min
review: Hands down one of the best coop experiences I've had to date. I felt like I was playing a mix of well polished Mario Party mini-games that helped drive a narrative story about a married couple who are going to get a divorce. Their weird ass daughter uses voodoo and turns them into the figurines she made of them that she plays with. Asking Dr Hakim (A Love Book) to fix her parents broken marriage you embark on an epic journey of grand proportions. Together with your coop partner and lots of "COL-LAB-ERR-A-TION!" you just might help save May & Cody's marriage from collapse and reunite  a family on the brink of a catastrophe.  The graphics were nice 8.5 out of 10. The gameplay was excellent 10 out of 10. The music was okay 8 out of 10. The story was good 8.5 out of 10. It took us about 12 hours start to finish with no rush. 9 out of 10 game! A must play experience at least once! One of the best coop game experiences to date for me. I really enjoyed working together with my friend who played on friend pass. He gifted me the game for my birthday and he played it for free right along side with me! He loved it just as much!*** Cannot be played alone! Must have a coop partner. Must use the Origin launcher to invite your friends. This allows for a multiplatform crossplay experience. You can be on PC and your coop partner can be on another platform and you can play together. This does not affect the score of the game in any way in my opinion. ***

author: Rentago
review: The relationship between the man and woman is shallow and uninteresting. The gameplay and minigames are fun though and for a coop game it is very enjoyable.See the problem we run into is that the Devs don't want us to hate the characters, but at the same time they need to have SOMETHING wrong to justify the whole main issue of divorce. The reason they are divorcing? Petty issues like May being too busy with work. Honestly their relationship seems pretty normal and in fact has very little in the way of any real problem. Their daughter is perfect, Cody and May are typical parents who aren't dealing with financial or any real hardship in general. So they decide they need to divorce, a serious ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ decision and one that can ♥♥♥♥ up a child's growth for no real good reason.So the daughter who is reasonably bothered by this sudden decision to dismantle the family makes a wish that oddly ends up being granted magically. So now were in a magical world filled with challenges that require May and Cody to work together to get through. Most of these reveal just how petty and shallow May and Cody are and their relationship drama is really just a lot of nothing.

author: DragonSpark
review: I'm genuinely torn on this game. On the one hand, the gameplay is masterful. It will take you on a tour of various genre of video game, from ARPG to Ace-Combat dogfighting, to street-fighter 2D brawling. The game looks gorgeous, and takes you through beautiful miniature setpieces.However, three levels in, it becomes apparent that the story and the writing is... weird. At the heart of it is these two characters, which are just profoundly unlikable for most of the story. They are childish and nasty with each other and do cruel things to the creatures they encounter, largely without justification. I wasn't rooting for them. I didn't want them to get their happy ending. And the way their relationship does heal in the final act seems really shallow, focusing on things like being supportive of gardening or singing, as opposed to more fundamental- real flaws- in their relationship. But despite how shallow the identified causes are, they get back together, probably? It really seems like the people who wrote this game didn't want to engage with the real questions of divorce and parenthood here, and when they came close, decided to brush the hard topics under the rug, instead of grappling with it. It definitely soured the experience.

You can't look or dash in <direction>"Now let's talk about the main characters. OMG, the Daughter is a victim, the parents need to die, and PLEASE let CPS take that child away from the toxic self harming unwell people who claim to be her parentsThey both are the villains, there isn't a happy ending, I am SO DONE with this game's evil parental figures being "saved" They. Are. Failures. Parents fail. and I need a follow up where the daugher is successful and her parents are still terrible rejects of society. Game is good, characters are bad, and yet I don't feel bad. The doll bastards deserve the purgatory they are doomed to

author: Nanaki Sai-Sensei
review: This game... It made me feel things. The level design is perfect, you don't feel like the puzzles are just in the way by being overly easy, but they're not that difficult that you lose immersion or get frustrated by having to look things up. Rather than feeling like most co-op games where someone just falls in with your story as if you could do it without them, both the player roles are important. Highly recommend it to anyone looking for a story-driven game with a friend. PS: I would rather have taken the cookies, Your Majesty

author: Mothfia
review: The most inconsistent plot I have ever seen. I played for 8 hours and felt like I accomplished nothing. At least 30 minutes of my recorded playtime was purely dealing with the loading time, lag, and crashes this game had. I'm not running this on a low-quality computer, so I know it wasn't the fault of my hardware.It took a few minutes for the game to load each time I'd open it, and a few times it wouldn't open at all. My half of the screen went black a couple of times, and the audio was about 10 seconds behind the visuals for several parts of the game. The controls were buggy, and combined with lag, it was difficult to accomplish anything.On to my main issue. There is a part in this game where you spend around an hour and a half working towards killing the daughter's favorite stuffed elephant. I did not enjoy playing through knowing that killing the poor elephant was the end goal, but I kept going through in hopes that the player characters would change their minds and realize how messed up their plan is. However, they did not. You have to rip that poor elephant apart as it actively begs you to stop and if you'd like a hug. The characters feel no remorse for what they've done, and have no regret for what they've done and how upset their daughter is over this.That entire thing ruined the game for me, and was absolutely unnecessary. I got this game under the impression that it would be a fun co-op game to play with my boyfriend, but we both left this disappointed and feeling like it was a waste of time. The graphics are pretty when they're fully loaded and not suffering from frame drops, and the gameplay prior to the unfair killing of the elephant was nice; but overall this is a game of bugs, unjustified horror, and complete lack of comprehensive storytelling and progression overshadows that.I want justice for Cutie.

That said, the level designs are fun and gorgeous and it is a very fun game...right until it feels like a drag to finish and that's why I can't recommend it.

author: OuchCouch
review: Loved this game! Played with a good friend of mine and we both had a blast. Loved the mini games and the different interactive elements. My personal favorite part were all the different movement abilities. Throughout the whole adventure you're constantly leaping, flying, swinging through the air. its awesome. Amazing set pieces throughout the game as well. Way more voice acting than i expected there to be. Only real negative from me is i didn't love the story of the game. The main plot is fine i guess, although cliche,  but the way its acted out by the two characters throughout the game was pretty cheesy and didn't feel super authentic to me. That being said its not enough to lessen the experience for me. The actual gameplay is that fun.Gameplay - 9/10World Design - 10/10Story/Script - 4/10

author: Jay
review: Playing this game was a blast.  Not just because it's a decent game, but I am playing it with a really awesome girl.  The puzzles aren't easy, but also not irritatingly hard.  The boss fights are challenging but don't distract from what this game is really about... spending time with the person you are playing with.  I do feel like the game is pushing the wrong message: "Stay in an unhealthy relationship because it will make the kids happy."  If you are in an unhealthy relationship it's creating an atmosphere of toxicity for the kids.  But I get what the game is trying to do, and it works.  At $40, it's worth it because your partner doesn't have to buy their own copy... really nice of the devs.Edit:  Oh, and the hardest boss in the entire game is the Camera... I don't know who designed the camera system but it makes you want to pull your hair out on some obstacles.

author: xopap
review: The game has a totally linear structure without any choice options. And the characters you are playing with are absolutely despicable, it is really hard to have sympathy to them. This issue is sugar coated with fun and engaging gameplay for two people. Solving puzzles and riding all the roller-coasters is indeed well executed. But this cannot out-weight the unacceptable actions that you have to do while playing this game. The storytelling is psychopathic which makes you play psychopathic characters without any options to choose their actions. Culmination of this is an infamous elephant scene, we stopped playing because of that. Killing puppies is not something that people should be forced to experience in a game, especially when the game pretends to be family-friendly. Absolutely unacceptable.

author: m.neumann.1980
review: The game is great, unfortunately EA is not.I have been playing the game in online coop with a friend. Both of us have good internet connections and decent PC's Here are some of the issues we ran into:1. One of us losing connection to EA servers ending the game (loosing lots of progress since checkpoints can be rather far apart).2. The game goes out of sync every now and then interestingly the game treats both versions as true which is really problematic in situation where both players have to control things together. E.g. trying to avoid a rock that one player sees on the left and the other on the right will be like a rock on the left and on the right. When running into those sync problems some boss fights get impossible3. Poor testing (bugs and design problems). We had several occasion where the game bugged out  (e.g. get stuck in a wall) and we had to restart, again loosing a lot of progress depending on where the last checkpoint was. In one level one player has to move a wall for the other player to jump on multiple times. While the wall is moving it does not "exists" tying to jump on it will lead to falling through it.

author: RUSні PEACEда
review: I received this game as a gift. Before I heard lots of pleasant reviews and recommendations about this game. So I couldn’t wait to play it. After 10 hours spent in this game I understood why it took so many GOTY awards. It is perfectly designed, sound is incredible, lots of interesting mechanics, it doesn’t have story gaps. So I sincerely understand people who gave this game lots of appreciation. It surely would be an 11/10 game for me too, except one thing. (Spoilers ahead) All of it was unfairly ruined by the moment with an elephant. It was pointless, rude and cruel part, that leads to…nothing. It didn’t help to solve the problem of the main characters, it wasn’t fun or entertaining, it was just horribly disgusting scene of killing the most attractive toy in game. Which message or experience me as a player I should’ve received? Or it was just cruelty for cruelty? Just because? And it is so unfair that I was forced to do it. Why wouldn’t give player a choice at least? Or someone in gamedev team just thought that I will be a brilliant idea to actually tear apart one of the helpless and kind toy in game? (And what about vacuum cleaner eyes?) What’s wrong with you guys? How it got PEGI 12 rate? No gory details? Hello? I would like to watch how would react 12 yo child to it? When you are reaching family divorce and child’s trauma topic and then putting this pointlessly rude part that cannot be avoided. How many people will end up their evening crying and cursing everyone who created this game? I cannot refund money for it and I cannot finish it, though it was really great adventure ‘till the moment. What a beautiful move. Thank you a lot Hazelnut studio for absolutely torn to pieces, spoiled and meaninglessly destroyed experience.---Игра была получена в подарок. Наслаждались в коопе, действительно игра заслуживала то внимание и награды, о  которых трубят во всех игровых сми. Мне тоже она заходила до тех пор, пока мы не дошли до момента со слонихой. Только один вопрос: зачем? То, что с ней происходило не решило проблемы главных героев, не привнесло новых механик, не было ни смешным, ни забавным. Это было просто отвратительно неприятно. Я не могу продолжить игру, как и не могу рефанднуть за нее деньги. Хотя она была весьма достойной до этого момента и мы бы с радостью её закончили, от этого еще более обидно, что весь мой приятный опыт и наслаждение игрой было бессмысленно разрушено ненужным моментом, который не несет абсолютно ни-че-го.

author: DARK§PACE
review: I really wanted this game because it looks great, but before I had a chance to actually embark upon the quest, I discovered to my dismay that there is in fact no solo play option whatsoever! I naturally assumed you could play by yourself if you wanted to and the other character would be controlled by an AI (a simple enough concept, right?), but unfortunately this isn't the case. I don't like the fact that I can only play with a non-imaginary sentient life-form who likes me (partly because I have no human friends and partly because my guinea pig has no opposable thumbs), and that's why I've decided to request a refund.Beats me why they couldn't incorporate a single-player mode for the more, shall we say, socially challenged gamer (last time I checked, most genuine gamers weren't the most socially viable humans anyway: that's why we became videogame addicts in the first place, isn't it?!), but never mind! If you're given both options on similar titles such as  why not this? I really don't appreciate being left without that option, and this whole "Friend's Pass" thing seems pretty suspect to me; I mean, since when did game publishers (ESPECIALLY EA!) want to actively encourage a whole horde of life-sized ragdolls to play their game without paying for it? If it sounds too good to be true, it usually is.Anyway, lesson learned. I guess I should've paid more attention to the title because it really does take two [humans] to play!

review: TLDR: i was disappointed and think it is overrated to ♥♥♥♥not going to lie i was quite disappointed with the game, especially after hearing so much about it and how good it supposedly is. the hype has basically ruined the game for me as i was very let down.i will say as of writing i havent finished the game but i dont really want to either. i personally dont jell with any of the characters and just find them all annoying. and the gameplay is extremely linear. basically you have to follow this corridor, solve a really easy puzzle fight a boss, next level.the settings for each level are quite good and are nice to look at. but not being able to explore much of it is a bit of a letdown, for example the daughters bedroom (i cant even remember her name).i dont particularly think this game is bad, but i dont think its that great either. i definitely think that it is overrated and i dont think it deserves most/all the awards it has gotten. maybe its just that this game isnt for me, but i would not buy at full price, i got on sale at 50% off, but i still dont think its worth that much. anyway thanks for reading

review: Me and my girlfriend just finished playing It Takes Two and we had a blast! The game is full of quirky, lovable characters and the storyline kept us engaged from start to finish. The gameplay is varied and challenging, but never frustrating. We especially enjoyed the co-op mechanics, which require teamwork and communication to solve puzzles and progress through the game. We highly recommend It Takes Two to any couples looking for a fun, heartwarming gaming experience. Plus, the dialogue is hilarious - we found ourselves laughing out loud multiple times during our playthrough. Overall, It Takes Two is a must-play for any duo looking to have a great time together.

author: Jonah
review: I enjoyed this entire game.That said, sometimes I enjoyed how fun it was and sometimes I enjoyed how bad the writing was. Spoilers to follow.But man, the game is just a really fun puzzle/combat 3D platformer with constantly changing abilities that keep each level fresh, and with lots of fun little minigames to try to best your partner in (which are honestly only fun to learn, not to ever come back and play again). Finishing at 13 hours, this game was the right length for what it was.Also, thanks to the publisher/developer for the whole "you only buy one copy" thing. Way easier to do that and tell your friend to download the free game and get going then either having to convince them to buy their own or gifting them one and making them feel like they have to play or they wasted your money. This was a good system that I appreciated.

author: RogueLyfe
review: Like A Way Out, Hazelight studios once again proves that they can't write a story or characters worth a crap- but also proves that if you're creative enough, artistic enough, and fun-minded enough, it genuinely doesn't matter one bit. This game has a ridiculous story, with terrible pacing, terrible characters that are extremely unlikeable, no development whatsoever, and massive continuity issues. But it literally doesn't matter. Because Hazelight makes the best gameplay mechanics, levels, and environments that I've ever seen in a co-op oriented adventure video game. Not to mention just how awesome it is to have adventure games that are two player. As I said in my A Way Out review, this game is so mechanically sound and fun that I really have no choice but to highly recommend it. It can be frustrating to coordinate with your partner, but this game is great. Just as a mechanic gets old, it is replaced by a fresh mechanic and a new environment. There is plenty to explore and everything just feels so big and so open, despite being linear. It has very tight platforming and controls and I only ran into two glitches in the entire 13 hour playthrough. This is a fun game. Not to mention how much I love the fact that you only need one copy of the game, which is always great. Such a great experience.
