author: bobnmike
review: This game has a very strange difficulty curve. Many games operate by introducing a mechanic and then going deeper and deeper into the uses of that mechanic or introducing new ones on top of the old ones, progressively getting harder and forcing you to learn and master the mechanics to proceed.In It Takes Two, the bar is constantly being set back to the beginning, with very few mechanics carrying over. While this by itself isn't a bad thing, and I think the rapid changes in mechanics works especially well in the first two chapters, the way the rest of the game is designed made it feel very flat by the end.Most of the abilities you gain end up just being a different flavor of clicking on something when the game tells you to click on it, without much thought or creativity being required. All the other abilities and mechanics seem to stay surface level, so when I did find one I liked, it never pushed the boundaries of what was possible before the next chapter began and I was back to square one.

author: SkySpeed
review: Do not buy, unless you two have unlimited free time to set up the gaming environment, and also, it is not recommended if you are on a international long-distance relationship which does not guarantee a PERFECT network condition.First, is that it takes a huge amount of time setting up the computer environment for gaming.There was confusion about the purchase, whether it's one buy, the other play for free, or one buy, the other needs to buy as well. This confusion is frustrating because it wastes so much time for the two. While one is downloading, the other does nothing but waiting, not to mention that the game is 50G, not something you can just buy and play without a fuss.Second, is the complexity of EA-Steam bundle. The EA's origin requires "the platform client overlay enabled", which is to say that you should not only acquire the Origin's account, not only for you but also your partner, who don't know much about software and have to depend on you. Also, it requires that you must launch the game from Origin, instead of from Steam, where you bought it in the first place, so as to allow Origin in-game service, which is also a prerequisite for online gaming. Complicated and frustrating. It's like you queue up for a whole day just to see a show that lasts for 5 minutes, which might not be interesting at all. All these software settings and account setting just kills all the fun.Why didn't I just bought it from Origin in the first place? And why there is not any clear clue what should I do regarding this special two-character game?Most importantly, is the unfriendly design of autosaving points. The saving points are mostly located at crucial story points, such as after a boss fight or after ending a long journey to somewhere. However, this type of autosaving point is rather disturbing when the two players are located in different countries or regions, in my case, one in Hong Kong and the other in mainland China. Whenever one's network condition got poor, the whole gaming session is automatically terminated and we had to play the whole part of the game all over again from the previous saving point, which might account for at least 15-minute work. Imagine all the 15 minutes' hard work suddenly vanishes, and how it might irritate us. Not to mention that the story-telling animations in the game CANNOT BE SKIPPED. We had to watch the animations all over again, which is totally a turn-off. If both got perfect network condition then it's totally fine, but the design of the gaming is downright inconsiderate towards many of us who do not enjoy an all-time stable connection, but it can be solved by allowing manual saving at most points of the game, such as in the game “Death Stranding”, one could save the game whenever you want as long as there is no threat nearby. This makes players feel so secure that they wouldn't worry about their efforts going in vain.Frankly speaking, if your time is really limited and is on long-distance relationship, stay away from the game. There are far better things you can do with your partner than trying to even launch it. Thanks for reading.

author: SquashingChocolate
review: This game requires EA / Origin platform to play it, and that platform is absolute garbage. Barely functional.Update: After literally 5+ hours of troubleshooting to make this game work, I can review the actual gameplay. That doesn't change the fact that the EA / Origin platform is awful, buyer beware.The story is a bit predictable but pleasant. As far as a narrative-driven game goes, it moves along pretty well with decent pacing. The gameplay is pretty simplistic, and excessively forgiving. If you mess up it barely punishes you at all, in either combat or platforming. But to keep it fresh, you are frequently getting different special abilities that fit the narrative. The cycle of learning and using new abilities keeps it from getting stale, since there isn't really any challenging gameplay to keep up the intensity. This game is very friendly to people who aren't into games that much.Based on the pure gameplay, I'm not so sure about "game of the year" kind of accolades. However, a co-op only, 3D platformer is a really unique idea, and one I would love to see more of. I think the concept is great and could hopefully lead to some really fascinating co-op games in the future.

author: Zeke45
review: Silly me, I thought it would have matchmaking. Instead you have to invite Origin friends. I barely even have any Steam friends -- I regularly turn down friend requests, three out of four times. I couldn't care less about "collecting" Steam friends and the thought of having Origin friends is in the negative digits on my priorities. I have real-life friends and don't hang out with them to play video games. We actually socialize, and not on "social media." Imagine! When I play co-op games, like most people, I just accept the random matchmaking. In fact, the randomness is part of the fun. I want to venture out into the wild, not be in my little "online friend bubble." Sheesh.This is obviously a niche "multiplayer" gaming concept that happened to click this once, judging by the popularity. But there's a lot of gamers such as myself for whom it's not going to suit their style.

If you can get it to work I hope you have fun, it seems like a lot of people are, but this just left a sour taste in my mouth.

review: -You have to install Origin-This game has no integration with Steam. You cannot invite friends through Steam. You need to use Origin.-Origin doesn't work initially. You can't add friends. You need to google how to make it work. This involves finding the origin.exe, opening that, making your status invisible, login out, and logging back in. Or at least, it worked after trying that. About the game:Pro:-Nice graphics -I am able to play it with my wife who rarely agrees to plays any gameCons:-As far as I am in the game, the game is completely linear. -The game offers no challenge (well, my wife struggles with it. any harder she probably wouldn't play. so this is almost a pro)-The premise of the story is kind of unique but somehow, the characters feel cliche and without depth. author: dibmoa.g
review: Even though the mechanics are changing too fast and there is actually not enough time to get used to the mechanics, this fast pace of the game is amazing.I always play split screen games with my partner and "It Takes Two" was one of the best! The collaboration is very nice and the game needs a lot of coordination and communication which is great and actually make sense.Lots of different environments and mechanics and boss fights. They really put effort on this game. So much fun with playing with a friend yet the puzzles are not that hard and always clearly obvious and the story is kinda boring. Of course I am not a good judge for the story as I skipped all the cut scenes. I can tell that unfortunately some mechanics are explained in the cut scene and it becomes a little difficult to understand the changes if you skipp them.

author: SwampDragon
review: The game's premise seems to be about saving a middle-class, suburban, Disney-marriage from failing by teaching the protagonists to work together (completing certain tasks). There is a didactic message here, in a childish black and white sort of way, but it's buried under layers of cheese and cliche. In fact it's hard to know who this game is aimed at. The various allusions to domestic life (like breaking the vacuum cleaner) doesn't feel like it's aimed at children. However, if you're an adult and your marriage needs fixing then I doubt you'd be playing video games together. If you're thinking of buying this game to play with your other half, then watch some videos or something. Make sure it's for you (I didn't because I didn't want spoilers). Both me and my significant other decided to refund after an hour or so because we just couldn't relate to it. It's hard to ignore all the above and focus on the game play (I am aware I haven't mentioned the game play) because they are inseparable.PS. It's ok to divorce, people grow in different directions. Staying together for the kids is, and always was, a terrible idea.

author: fredd1e
review: If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.Ingredients:1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter2. 1/2 cup white sugar3. 1/2 cup brown sugar4. 1/4 cup water5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon6. 1 pinch salt7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced8. 1 pastry for double-crust pieDirections:1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

author: Somethingroyal
review: There are a lot of issues with the story of this game.  The characters are utterly unlikable.  But mostly, I can't recommend for anyone to play this because seven hours in,there is a point in the story where you torture another character, then have a celebratory dance in the tears of your own daughter and there is no way to choose to not do any of this.  The game has no discussion about this afterward about how maybe they did the wrong thing.  The characters do not feel remorse about it, only stuck on themselves and they move on to the next point of the story to "get their bodies back."  At this point, their daughter would be better off with them in an eternal coma and sent off to another person to live with than to have to stay with either of this self-centered narcissistic deadbeats.  I regret this scene being seven hours in so that I can no longer refund the game.The gameplay is fine, but the story just makes you feel like ♥♥♥♥.  Find another game unless you want to be an emotional masochist.  Buying this was a mistake and a waste of money.

author: Ouroboros
review: This game being Overwhelmingly Positive is a good indication of what is wrong with the (gaming) world today.In general, the pretty good visuals, thanks to the Unreal engine, serve only to cover the fact that it's all been done before. Seeing the same tropes from earlier games again, and the ever present hand-holding, makes you slowly die a little bit inside, with the final nail being the aiming reticule sliding onto the target when you aim near it.Add unlikable characters with no redeeming qualities, plus the elephant scene it seems - didn't get there actually, we watched the scene online, we gave up hope for this game during the wasp levels -  and this game deserves perhaps 3/10.

It also doesn't even provide much game time- i'm half way through the game at 4 hours.However good quality of the game is the ability to do remote play (only one person needs to get the game), and the art style is quiet pretty. author: lightheaded
review: Otherwise a brilliant game, but the overall script is a incredible disappointment. I am dumbfounded by how terrible it was. I thought the ridiculous understanding of love and companionship of the Book character was satirical, and the characters would somehow emerge with a mature resolution to their situation. But no. Instead, it embraces this wholesale. With an added stupidity of "oh no the child blames herself and ran away". WHAT??? I can't remember when I had a piece of media pull the rug on me this hard. I mean, everything else in the game was so beautifully made. The stunning world design, the fresh gameplay mechanics. Even the close detailing of the script, the little dialogues, the acting. It is as if you took a disinterested middle schooler's writing assignment and produced it with the best team of professional artists. You think: "surely, something good is coming at the end". And then the ending is just. abrupt. and stupid. And tarnishes the whole experience.Anyway, I still have to recommend it, since the parts that make up this disappointing story are still brilliant. Just brace yourself: there is no payoff at the end. The plot really is that stupid. edit: I am changing the review to "not recommended" just to give it some contrast from all the adulation.

author: tflicky
review: This game is a perfect game in every way. It one of my favorite games of all time. The only problem is that you have to kill an elephant who offers you hugs, will listen to your problems, and calls everyone their friend. You rip off the elephants leg and tear off her ear then push her off a cliff to her death. I like dark humor but I think this was a poor attempt at trying to make a dark joke. They make her cry for help and make you feel evil. The game also plays distorted music in the background and the main characters seem to be unphased after killing the elephant. Once you are done killing the elephant you find out you killed her for nothing. Everything else about this game is fantastic but this terrible scene deserved a bad review.

author: farfallavendetta
review: I am baffled by the good reviews for this game. Sure, it's a fun way to pass the time with a friend but the story is complete garbage and is insensitive to any child who has had divorced parents. Mrs. Doubtfire did it better.  This game wants to be for children but has some inappropriate content, and one of the most disturbing scenes in a videogame to date that was incredibly cruel for absolutely no reason (the elephant scene). The writing in this game was so awful I was yelling at the characters half the time. Some levels were fun to play, others were frustrating. It seems like the developers had a bunch of ideas for levels (some of which were pretty creative) but couldn't think of a coherent way to link things together. If this is on a discount, maaaaybe pick it up but it's not worth it for full retail price.

author: Free-Kill
review: If this game stopped at the two-thirds mark and had a completely different story, it would get a huge thumbs up.---The story is so bad that it becomes genuinely pretty distasteful. An arguing husband and wife are getting a divorce and are making their daughter sad. The daughter casts a spell on a book of love that turns the parents into dolls on the premise that they need to learn to be friends again - The book of love becomes a creepy, sexually aggressive guide through this endeavour.The whole start of the game we were thinking (hoping?) that this was going the only sensible way - the divorcing couple realises that even if they aren't in love any more, they can still respect each other and take care of their daughter. And the book of love, who is SO awful and pushy and obviously bad, is wrong about what they need and the couple rejects its simplistic, degrading view of relationships.But nope. The book is actually a good guy the whole time, and the simplistic and degrading view is presented by the game as correct. It's childish, pointless, unnaunced and insulting. If you've had experiences in your life with going through divorce, I would imagine this game could be genuinely upsetting with how pathetically it tackles the topic.---Gameplay is a lot more positive. Couch co-op is a bit of a lost art and this game nails it - In each act the two players get different, complementary powerups and use them in clever and creative ways to tackle the obstacles presented. It's challenging enough to be engaging, and yet still not so hard that you're likely to get stuck for ages. You can play this with a partner who isn't as into gaming as you are, and you'll both have a great time. That's hard to do.Controls are tight, mechanics are varied and the pace is kept brisk enough that ideas don't overstay their welcome. Playing through the acts is a fun jaunt and it is well suited to occasional play sessions of a couple of hours - perfect for date night.UNTIL the last third of the game. Very, very abruptly the game adopts a crawling pace. Acts take way longer, with less variety and way more repetition. It is so bad that in the final act of the game, one of the characters comments to the book of love about how endless and repetitive the task list is.---Unfortunately between the horrendous conclusion to the story and the dive in quality of the gameplay in the last third, the game leaves a really sour taste in your mouth. It may still be worth it to many because before that point, it's genuinely great - Certainly if you love co-op games then you may be delighted to see that there's a developer putting so much good work in to create a great co-op experience. Just don't expect it to last.

author: Neos5x
review: It is absolutely insane to me that a game that was released in 2021 and is literally unplayable by yourself doesn't have cross platform functionality. The only reason i bought this game was because i thought i could play with my friend who has it on the xbox one. After we both install it, we come to find out that even though i have her added on EA and she's on my friends list and in my xbox party through my xbox game bar, we're unable to invite each other in-game. I tried getting the xbox game pass and re-installing the game through the xbox app rather than steam, i thought that if i did that then i could invite her since we're friends through xbox and it would work better than steam but that didn't work either. I finally did some research and found out that this game simply just doesn't have cross platform functionality.I know you're probably thinking i'm stupid for not doing research before buying the game, but i was under the impression that it's no longer 2015 and the developers of a game like this that strongly advertises the whole "Play anywhere with your friends with the friends pass" aspect would by default know that there are way too many different gaming devices now a days and the chances of everyone and all their friends having the same console are very low which is why a beautiful thing called CROSS PLATFORM FUNCTIONALITY was invented. Yet the devs decided this isn't necessary to implement into the game upon release or update it to have cross platform functionality in the 2 whole years since this game has been released.The game itself is amazing, i played it for hours and had a blast on split screen on my friends xbox one, which is why i was so disappointed to find out that the only way to play it again with my friend is if i either buy an xbox solely for this game, or physically be at my friends house. It's an amazing and very fun game and surprisingly challenging in some parts, but until the devs decide to put in the work to make it function with other consoles as is expected of every co-op game in 2023, it's unplayable for me and will just be collecting dust in my library unfortunately. Please update for cross platform functionality

review: This game is probably a 3/5, but I gave it a thumbs down since for some reason you have to use Origin to play it... It doesn't really bring anything new to the table gameplay wise. It's story is predictable and the dialog is pretty cheesy at times. There's very little challenge here overall, and it often feels like its geared towards very casual players. All that would be fine if I wasn't constantly fighting the autoaim using m/k controls. Overall its pretty akin to a 10hour cutesy Disney movie.

author: Peet Fics
review: It's unbelievable how this game got universal praise... Winning awards, let alone game of the year at multiple outlets. It's almost hilarious how it won family game of the year. It's at most fine. I imagine this game runs and operates fine in local play but online I experienced constant rubber-banding with my co-op partner's character. I've seen the characters go into the walls of wall-jumping platforms. Even if this game was fully functional online I couldn't recommend it. A game with okay mechanics is ruined by some of the worst writing I've ever seen in a game.I'll say the game is very beautiful, the platforming is serviceable and the mechanics are interesting at times. I never found them very challenging or stimulating and never found myself getting stuck but, I get it, it's a game that kids can play so it's not gonna have the hardest puzzles in the world. Really, they made a janky Mario game and put it in co-op. That's all I can say that's positive for me.To fully explain why this game is getting a negative review, it's entirely the writing. While the characters are well-performed, I hate them both. The beginning of the game details how the two primary characters are going through a divorce. The magic of their daughter's tears turn them into a couple of dolls that have to go on a journey to figure out how to turn themselves back. Basic stuff. Except for the fact these characters clearly hate each other. They cannot stop insulting one another and barraging eachother with baggage. Constantly whining, crying and bickering. I don't care about these characters. So much so I didn't even want to finish this game even though there's no challenge to it. For more details about this, I'm going to go a bit into the plot so censored spoilers ahead to read at your discretion.  If the game had given me the option to completely ignore the characters and the story... Maybe I'd recommend it. But I have no idea how this game got this much praise. It made me laugh maybe once.  But the fact that the game is just okay with a bunch of little stuff to do that doesn't get incorporated into actual gameplay but instead just a little side thing to mess around with makes this whole experience feel shallow and rushed. Also, how'd this game get a family-focused award when there's a scene of a character repeatedly shouting expletives? If the story was better, I'd say it'd be worth a brainless playthrough, but honestly, the plot and characters drag this whole game down. I bought this on sale and still feel grifted by the reviews. If this sounds like your thing, go for it, but this one was a gigantic disappointment for me after seeing all the praise it gets.

For those who enjoy the game, it 100% has replayability, whether you or the other player trade characters, or if you want to trade on what tasks you do the second time around. It also has fun, little mini games all throughout that are fun to go back to sometimes. I also really enjoyed the boss fights, the different creatures you fought with their special abilities was for sure my favorite part.All of that aside, I thought the game was WAY too long for what it is. I played with a friend, and both her and I were dragging our feet at points to try and finish. The game has, like, three different endings, and it's not good when, you think the game is over, and you're like "Finally!", but in actuality it's only 1/3rd of the way done. Also, about the story,

author: BRICKKCIRB
review: Its rare that a game comes around that has a wide range of diverse characters that are all awful. Its the story of of two people who should absolutely get a divorce. A know it all hypocrite and a bumbling idiot team up at the behest of a curse from an extremely annoying character in the shape of a book. They go off and meet all kinds of annoying cast and make boring attempts at dialogue while being morally bad people. The game seems to go out of its way to show them as awful, in one instance they have to work to stop a tyrannical despot who also ends up having been withholding resources from its people. Anyway, they side with and rescue the despot, blow up the resources, and call it job well done. Gameplays okay.

author: RedCelt
review: I played this with a close friend of mine and it was a very fun experience. More fun than I've had in a long time. That, however, does not translate into this being a good game.I can only describe this as being something between amazing and appalling on nearly every axis. Character animations are fluid and high detail, yet are often repetitive and un-engaging. Controls are consistent and responsive, yet somehow sluggish and awkward. The world is filled with amazing intricacy with optional areas to enjoy, but transitions within the world feel jarring and moving throughout it is unsatisfying. What this ends up resulting in is a very high focus on the negatives without a sound ability to identify specific portions to criticise. Couple this with a decent number of references to other classic games and this is a fun game for experienced game players to burn, but otherwise a lacking experience gameplay-wise.We found during our nine hours of play time (mostly focused on progression rather than side-activities) that the game lingered on for far too long with both of us agreeing that it probably should have ended four or five hours in. This is odd given game expectations nowadays. Gameplay is quite varied with a number of genres explored that keep the experience fresh. However, most sections have mechanics that last much longer and outlive their initial welcome. This is not helped when mechanics between the two players are often asymmetric (by intention) but are biased in variety and enjoyment towards one of the players. I often felt as though my partner got the better end of the stick, especially when puzzles usually involve taking turns in platforming rather than full cooperation. There are exceptions, but they were few and fair between.Probably the most ludicrous and often berated by the two of us was the story of this game. In concept, the idea of a slowly splitting couple slowly reconnecting after being turned into miniature dolls is an interesting take on cooperation. However, this quickly turned into characters continuously blaming each other for one half of the game before heel turning into loving one another in a manner that seems jarring and forced at a shallow level and mentally concerning the deeper we explored this relationship. This is not helped by a B plot in the story following their daughter exploring the house alone which, combined with the aforementioned animations being simultaneously good quality but lacking direction, nullify any kind of sympathy felt for that character throughout the story.It feels tough for me to be so harsh on this game. I can see the time and effort placed into this. I love some of the innovation and concepts that could have been explored in such a game. But it fails in execution and left me wondering something that no game should leave me feeling: If we enjoyed parts of this game so much, wouldn't we be better off playing separate games that executed on those well instead of this which only brushes upon it? For that, I do not recommend this game for those who wish to enjoy a game with their friend. However, those who are critical and like to examine games as they play them will definitely find fun in It Takes Two.

author: vonSeiten
review: Well, normally I would recommend this game, it is a nice coop 3D platformer (with just regular flaws like camera positioning). But: the kinda second stage has a theme, which makes me not recommend this game. The enemy faction, so to say, are wasps - and this goes along with lines by the main characters like "why have you not "cleaned out" (aka burned) the hive before" and it sets a tone as it would be totally okay to burn wasp nests in real life. I know it is a game - but still, promoting that it is okay or "normal" to just destroy and kill social insects en masse is such a bad tone. Wasps among other social insects are often endangered, and furthermore they support and help us humans by reducing agricultural pests and, hey, the even hunt mosquitos. Dont get me wrong - the issue is not that you fight wasps, it is this casually set tone of portraying social insects beside bees as something that we should kill and exterminate. Especially in a "family game" that is even further out of place.We live in times of biodiversity decline and dramatically shrinking insect populations. Having a fun game setting such a tone is a big let down and a quite saddening approach.Oh yeah - and it forces Origin DRM on you.

author: Bastel
review: Indeed, you shall see wonderous landscapes, listen to funny quotes, struggle to find the right pace with your teammate before making progress at a steady pace during this game.You might stop at some point to listen to the soundtrack - and after a few seconds, come back to the game, as it is not that memorable. (with the notable exception of the very last biome of the game and its weird dancers)After a dozen hours of play, you might end up saying to yourself "What a great moment I just lived with my best friend, and it was also super cute" (playing with someone you're not divorcing makes the game more enjoyable), as you're approaching the final cutscene.HOWEVER.It is only at this very moment that you're able to realize the truth depicted by this game's story.Once you wrapped everything up, after hearing 167 times by any of the characters that the divorce is done, after seeing both of them acting despicably in consequence, you end up (spoiler) NOT divorcing. They keep being married and live happily ever after.But at what cost ?Your main foe is that bloody gaddem trouble-generating Book of Love and its sadistic avatar, the infamous Doctor Hakim. You keep on overcoming every challenge the Book places in front of you, and yet HE makes you face more trials, more objects to gather, HE forces you into coming back to a relationship both of you heavily want to end ; basically, HE is making your puppet life as distressful as it can be.And yet, after being ridiculed by the bloody gaddem nerve-racking Book of Love and its enraging avatar, the script ends up making everything HE desires, not both of you. You do not divorce. You do not hear any of the arguments from any of the characters. You're being forced into loving each other after an endless ordeal, and you praise the scumbag for this achievement in the final cutscene. Hakim blesses you.So yes, it was fun, it was creative, I enjoyed several gameplay sequences which were truly entertaining and captivated me until far in the game.But when I think of this game, the one and only memory that comes crystal-clear to my mind is that depressing end.Please consider making both characters burn the book, happily divorce and get Rose at their respective new homes one week out of two, it will also make ground for the writing of a sequel, for which I'm sure lots of couples would gladly pay.If not, you can always avoid finishing the game, it's still quite entertaining between the beginning and the end.

author: Vincent
review: Could be fun but they decided to feed us with "THE MESSAGE" and also to make it tiresome.Long version:First of all it could obviously be a fun game for couples. But couples usualy mean people with different skills, platforming experience that look for relaxing game to spend the evening - rather than repeating same moves over and over and having monkey dexterity. Additionaly the camera moves are flawed and makes the platforming part even more tiresome.But above is not the main problem. My wife lost the interest in the game in first two hours, because of unlikable characters and PC bs. She was tired of another PC story showing another man as a clown and pannicking house-husband that jammed the vacum cleaner and couldnt repair it or even carry it to repair..... and his family-sustaining "stronk and succesful" wife being unpleasant bi**ch all the time because that somehow makes female characters "stronk" in XXI century. Oh yeah and she is "engineer" as well (I mean - whatever - but game reminds us that couple of times so lets repeat that again...) and that obviously makes her the only person able to fix the vacum cleaner because..... I dont know - all engineers do that? And thats just the beginning of the story.And no, its not the point that me and my wife are some "traditional roles" lunatics or that woman cannot sustain family, be engineer etc. Its hard to explain but both characters are just so unlikable that you dont want to follow their story. Their conversations are not serious, not funny, not even funly-absurd. Just iritating. Its clearly visible that its another crude and pointless woke signaling - like in Battlefield V and hundreds of other games and movies. They could make it all neutral, funny, interesting etc. but instead they decided to go for THE MESSAGE. So no thanks.

The game isn't really punishing so you can play this with pretty much anyone - except...We REALLY both disliked the protagonists. The mom and dad are both horrible people who go out of their way to insult and demean each other at every turn. Even when they're in what's essentially a life and death situation they can't even hold back their insults for even a single cutscene. The kid is clearly the most adult person in the room when these two ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ are around.So playing this with another adult is cringe because you can't get into the story and characters and playing this with a kid feels questionable to me. I've watched the infamous "elephant cutscene" and I agree with everyone thumbing this game down for this. Both of us play m-rated games regularly but this pixar'esque setting makes certain boss finishers feel weirdly brutal.Also confronting your kid with another kid's parents' divorce right from the off feels at least a little weird to me.

author: Nightscloud2
review: This game is amazing.....but it could have been legendary. This game will remind you of all your favorite 3D platformers, it has some serious Sonic adventure 2 vibes with rail sliding, its got gravity bending mechanics that will give you mario galaxy vibes,   its got references. The movement mechanics feel fast and smooth and I cant wait to watch speed runs. There is a good amount of content, I'm 5 hours in, and we've been moving pretty quickly, but when i watch the trailer i see we still have quite a bit left. Difficulty is pretty low and so long as you don't both die you'll respawn. Mechanics are mind bending at times, with looping rails, flipping gravity, and at times has a very cinematic feel. Caution if you dizzy easily. so..the bad? As I mentioned before this game will give you fond memories of your favorite games until you realize......there's nothing to collect. Its completely missing the "collectathon" aspect normally found in 3D platformers.  You "find" minigames that are basically on your linear path and hard to miss. But there are no coins, rings, jigsaw puzzles, stars, moons, feathers, music notes, Gold Bolts, apples, bananas, orbs, charms, or anything else for that matter. and thats really...really sad. I would have had no issues paying full AAA price for this game if it had those mechanics. The story maybe difficult for some people considering it covers a sensitive topic, divorce. This might be painful for some that dont want to relive those memories. Games like these almost dont need a story at all, honestly. The entire story could have been modified as brother and sister, or best friends, and some other event shrunk them down while keeping all the core gameplay mechanics. lastly, EA is the worst publisher for this game. Sony, or Nintendo would have been so much better. at least if you would have went with one of those publishers, you'd actually have a real IP that would last decades. Look at Sony with crash bandicoot, sly cooper, spyro, ratchet and clank, jak and dexter. this would have fit nice. Nintendo, would have been great it has a nintendo feel to it. Look at what EA has done to medal of honor, starwars battlefront, need for speed, command and conquer, SSX, burnout, sims, battlefield...etc etc... EA destroys everything it touches. EA will abandoned this and never look at it again like they do most of their IPs. I really feel bad for the devs.

author: Friedrich Nietzsche
review: PROS: the art style is really good and the game is varied and very creative. It is designed to introduce your girlfriend who has never gamed to the medium, and does a good job at it. It has a little bit of everything: platforming, puzzles, shooting, flying, minigamesCONS: if you have any experience with games at all it will be very easy and it can get boring, as the challenge is non-existent. The story is also really childish and not  important, so the plot won't make up for it.The game is in forced split-screen, even though you are playing online. This makes absolutely zero sense because you don't really need it (voice chat is enough), and it should just have been a toggle. I'm on a laptop with a small screen, so this hurts the enjoyment a lot, and it's even worse because it would be such a simple fix.For me this is the deal breaker that made me leave a negative review, I'll be happy to change it if the devs decide to remove split screen.

author: agwiaz
review: This game is beautiful and has a wonderful world, but it's also pretty boring in terms of gameplay. It's not challenging, the puzzles don't make you think, and it just pushes you through a pretty much linear path, with no real choices.Some of the minigames are pretty fun, some of the story is pretty funny, and even a few of the events are somewhat fun. The gameplay is lacking. It feels more like an interactive video than it does a video game.It would certainly be a very good choice for introducing someone to videogames who had no experience. And again, spectacular visuals.I just didn't find it that fun to actually play.

author: Bruck
review: This game is ruined by a few things that are probably unrelated to an otherwise well designed and made game.   For starters the developers have never had a girlfriend sit down to play a game with them if they think that fighting with origin, and watching long drawn out non-skippable cut-scenes about divorce is a great way to spend a date night.  I get that you want a theme for the game and all of your puzzles, that's awesome, but the acting and cut-scenes are not "That" great and they are quite cringy - just let me skip them.  Lastly, while trying to skip them I started the first chapter over again which is 90% cut scenes, and well - yup GF/Wife was done, Please give this game to a few couples and they will help you fix the beginning experience to allow for quick start - date night style activities.  Camera control was also a bit challenging for a non-gamer and required a bit of patience.Next week, I'll give it a try again, will update review if I can get to the wonderful looking action shown in the trailiers. I just really hope the cut-scenes are not as large of a part of the game as they are in the first chapter.

It just feels like they gave up on the story halfway through the game, and it just nosedives in quality. The rest of the game is just average, and uninteresting, at best.

author: kaoskonfety
review: Trigger warnings? Child abuse, torture, and a general broad meanness between the "protagonists". Don't play it with your young children unless you've given it a run though. Seriously.I sat down for a quiet night with my partner over a well reviewed award winning game about a couple on the rocks, and working though it in a fantastical setting. I ended at 7 hours having listened to hours of the most servile and mean spirited bickering (somewhat expected, but gods these 2 are petty), several beautiful vistas, and charming art sets, a handful of literal eye sores (I suppose flashing warning should have made the list) a dozen different play styles across "hit and miss" and some fun to "simple but annoying to execute" puzzles. We ended play shortly after dismembering our daughters living and talking and screaming and pleading stuffed elephant over a couple of minutes of scenes and "mini-games". This ending in our daughter weeping over its parts, while we cheer the scene. We promptly run off disinterested when it turns out making her warm tears fall on her stuffed toy we destroyed while she is reeling from her parents talking divorce doesn't magically solve their magical problem. I get the bickering, setting characters, sure. I can almost forgive the literal eye sore levels. But I do not want these 2 parents to get out of this, I definitely do not want them somehow fixing their "relationship" - whatever that may have been or will look like, and I certainly got blindsided by the extended fantasy torture and overt child abuse. These 2 narcissists need to split, and their child be raised by someone who does not see them as a piece in a game of one-up-manship. We're probably going to finish it, and I may edit this review it it blows me away how they turn it around. But I can't picture it.As a 2 player platformer: pretty good, solid portal 2 vibes everywhere. Mostly intuitive controls. Pretty zany, almost all fun.As a story presentation: Do I think there should be games that seriously tackle being in a mutually traumatic relationship, child abuse, reconciliation, forgiveness, hope against darkness, the nature of love in the family, and all this great literary *stuff*? Hell yes. But that is not what was on this games box, and its not here at all except in a deeply dreadful way. "Mummy and daddy must be together for the children" is the only leg its story is trying to stand on, and its pretty obvious 10 minutes in that is a bad leg, and short while later its pretty clear that the rot has set in.

author: ZalSC
review: Where do I even get started?My husband and I beat this game in ten hours. I have never approved of a game under 20 hours being sold for so much money. I realize a lot of successful franchises do this (I'm looking at you, Uncharted), but that doesn't mean it's good practice.For that reason alone, I would not recommend this game at full price. While there were a couple of really fun levels in there, I didn't actually like the game. Here's why, without plot spoilers. Only gameplay spoilers.1. You have to install Origin in order to play. For those of you who don't know, Origin is a more intrusive, less intuitive, and less popular game platform similar to Steam. I already had it, but my husband had to install it. (For a game he only played for 10 hours)2. The characters are completely unlikable. May, the wife, and Cody, the husband, are both annoying, petty, selfish and shallow people. There are points in the game where they demonstrate that they're actually bad people. Like, borderline psychopaths. But there are no consequences. And the damned book character is the reason I will uninstall this game and never look back.3. The story has a really, really unhealthy idea of what good relationships are made of. It tries to sell the idea that love solves all problems, and that collaboration can repair broken marriages. The following mentalities are encouraged by the game: - It's fine to blame your spouse when you fail to pursue your passions, because apparently it's your spouse's responsibility to push you toward the things you enjoy. - It's fine to blame your spouse for spending too much time working, even though that's the only thing enabling you to be a stay-at-home parent. - It's fine to pressure your spouse into doing something they don't want to do, because you think they should, and they used to like it so they should obviously still like it.[11:12 PM]4. The gameplay is very linear. Some people like this style of game, but I don't. Every level is basically running in a straight or even curved line, jumping over obstacles, and figuring out puzzles. There are a few more open environments thrown in, but since you are not rewarded for exploration, you tend to ignore it.5. Cutscenes, cutscenes everywhere! There are even cutscenes for your cutscenes. Any time you could have actually been introduced to a cool new environment through exploration, instead you get a cutscene showing it to you right before you get there. This completely nukes the game's overall swift pacing. Your camera is even stolen for three-second cutscenes to show you an objective you were already aiming for.6. It's really hard for me to figure out who this game is actually for. The "humorous" dialog was punny at best and juvenile at worst. If you like minion memes made by your grandparents, I'm sure it was hilarious. That's not my genre of humor, and this game was full of that. Yet there was also swearing thrown in at random, and at least two scenes that were shockingly f-ed up. The sudden tonal shift from "ha-ha fart joke" to "holy crap, that's literally murder" was completely unexpected, and while I enjoy some very dark and shamefully edgy jokes, it felt wholly unwelcome in this context.I won't fault the game for how easy it was, because I think more of a challenge in this type of co-op game can actually cause fights that ruin the experience. It really tried to spice up the level variety too. And a few of the puzzles were great fun. I'm glad my husband and I played, but I would not recommend this game for anyone with emotional sensitivities, immature mindsets (children), or vulnerability to very bad relationship advice.

The monotony of It takes two is only broken up by visual spectacles, and set piece moments that look great but rarely last long and do little more than put a bandaid on a hemorgaing game. Miss this one.

author: Blazon Stone
review: I never write reviews, but I feel I need to write one in this case as a public service. This game is terrible. Not just overrated, but actively terrible. The characters are all completely insufferable. The dialogue is entirely bereft of any creativity, and although it is clearly intended to be humorous, it consistently fails in this regard. More importantly, the gameplay is drawn out and wholly uninteresting, amounting to little more than a walking simulator and occasional spamming of the 'action button'. Each level 'cleverly' borrows some mechanic from a far better game, presumably in an attempt to appeal to nostalgia, this only has the effect of reminding you that you're wasting your life playing this when you could be playing any one of thousands of better games. The whole experience can only be described as painful. If you want to feel like you would rather be doing *anything* else other than playing this dismal game, then by all means click "add to cart" and prepare to be filled with regret. Otherwise, go buy literally anything else and you will likely have a better time. I cannot understand how this game has "overwhelmingly positive" reviews. I wish I had never heard of it.

author: chelseafeeny
review: How did this win GOTY? It's everything from my childhood games that I HATE. Jump puzzles, OP bosses, repetition, and lousy story. This game is no fun if you're just trying to do something with your partner for an afternoon. If you want an AWESOME 2-player experience get PORTAL 2 .

author: Adnihil
review: I don't feel like this game deserves its awards.The level design is really nice for the most part, beautiful environments, fun puzzles and challenges, but there were some parts that didn't feel intuitive at all and we just stumbled through by dumb luck, or where we knew what we were supposed to do simply because it was a game, but we wouldn't have known if we actually were our characters or if we were new to gaming. The story and character writing are honestly just bad. There are levels that are fun, but there's not much of an overarching story, buildup, mystery, or suspense, with the two characters constantly bickering. Other than the first and last levels, you could randomly rearrange them all and it wouldn't have any effect on the story. It's always "We finished the level but oh, now we have to go do that first" and "Ok, we did that but oh, now we have to do this first", without any real story or character development. This makes the game feel like a chore that drags on for way too long. The gameplay loop only contributes to this feeling. Each level revolves around using different tools/weapons, but as they get taken away and replaced after each level there's no feeling of progression, no increasing difficulty, nothing to master. Just "use this to solve everything in this level and then never use it again". I much prefer games where you get to grow an arsenal of tools/weapons and get to combine them somehow.I know the game is supposed to be about how teamwork is important and overcoming hurdles together and whatnot, but it felt more like the theme of the game was "not growing or progressing". It made it seem like a divorce is this bad thing that can be overcome by just trying harder, while in many cases a breakup or divorce is the best option for everyone, including any children. Sometimes people grow apart and that's OK. Trying to keep a disfunctional relationship together is mentally draining for everyone involved, and fixing it isn't always feasable or even possible because things and people simply change. Sure, for the characters in the game it worked out, but often times it's better to go your separate ways and live on differently, meet someone else or even enjoy solitude. Separation is not a bad thing, especially if staying together prevents you from growing.

review: Thinking it would be a great idea to play it with your non-gamer gf? Think again.Also, F Origin.-----I downloaded the game, then I had to create Origin account and it was A TORTURE. I had to guess dice with a sum of 14 on them at least 15 times. Multiple times I had to start again because time ran out. Who designed this captcha?Then we started playing and it turned out that controls suck. Even in a main menu.... When you press a button your character does some action only after ~0.5 sec. Which made timed jumps difficult even for me, who played all sorts of games for two decades. Also It's quite difficult to move a character accurately, because they always run. (Witcher 3 had the same problem with movement BTW). So when it comes to actions, character feels too heavy, but when it comes to movement they feel too light.Now imagine someone with a skill of a game journalist playing alongside you...We pretty much gave up after a room with wiring.I guess It could be fun if you both have skill, otherwise it might end up in tears. Don't repeat my mistake guys.

author: HeartOfDarkness7
review: So, this is going to be different than most other reviews of this game, I suppose.  It's not an outright "bad" game I suppose, and it has a lot going for it.  However, I do have a few complaints, and depending on who you are, these are not minor.  The game has an unbelievable amount of foul language, and this really took me by surprise considering the fact that the art and characters seem geared toward kids.  The game also has a few major flaws (such as places in the scenery to get physically stuck without dying) that may seriously ruin the experience for you.  Most of the time, the game is a lot of fun, but when that experience is interrupted, it feels the whole game has gone sour.  If none of those things bothers you, then this is a great game with excellent interactivity for teens or adults to play together.  I misunderstood the target audience, because the game is about a small child whose parents are experiencing marital turmoil.  As a result, I let my kids play.  Bad idea.  This game is not for kids.  There is even a dystopian holocaust-themed squirrel war that probably looks cute on the surface, but as you probe deeper becomes too dark for kids.  There are a lot of things like that in this game.

No character arcs, an unsatisfying conclusion, too many walking simulations, and piss poor dialogue. The ice world was the cream on the top, along with the first world. Everything else was meh. Don't waste your time.Also, the game dissed the color purple about 100 times.

author: Kitty Kat Kate
review: Journalist difficulty. I hate this style of game, where you can't fail. The main characters are awful people and should get a divorce. The 'gameplay' loop of; get tool, level is a tutorial on how to use tool, loose tool, is so boring. If you die during a boss fight, you respawn to the boss missing 1/4 health just to make it easier on the player again, Journalist difficulty.The characters never shut up, they are always talking or arguing. You never get a moment to enjoy the environment or make your own opinion on things. The characters immediately tell you when to do something wrong or if you take too long to solve the puzzle. Your not allowed to explore the environments without the main characters complaining at each other. This game is missing silence. During my play through with my girlfriend, the clock tower level made me motion sick and I almost threw up. There is no warning this game contains massive, rideable spiders and other bugs. My girlfriend has entomophobia (fear of bugs). I only played it to completion, because it was a birthday gift from my girlfriend, we both hated the game but had more fun ripping on the characters and asking the simple question of "if they did have a station wagon, would they be in this situation?" in reference to one of the hundreds of ♥♥♥♥♥♥ 'jokes' the characters try and make during the game.

author: sorrywhat
review: Divorce/breakup is a very stressful process, yes, but only for the people who are going through it. It is boring and mildly annoying for those who observe it tho. If evoking boredom and slight annoyance was the point then creators of this game succeeded. Also the infamous  is nothing special too. Yeah, wow, so edgy.The only somewhat interesting character is their daughter but, like, in a "this kid is not alright" way. She seems really traumatized, not like a child going through early stage of their parents separation process but more like a bullying victim or sth like that. The game mechanics are okay. Nothing special but not bad. Some of areas are very pretty to look at.

author: ParaSyt
review: Already in an hour of the first Minigame,  "figure out hour to invite thru Origins garbage launcher", so far we have not gotten passed it. But I have a good feeling about his. I mean EA has been the only company to get my credit card and account hacked. Surly this launcher can't be that F'ed up. LOL EA you are the R Kelly of gaming.Update: This game is hot garbage. My girlfriend and I always know when to call it a night when the game crashes and/or glitches to an unplayable section to where we are to tired to figure out how to google how to fix this stupid bug. We've never got to a point and been like "hey this is a good stopping point". Nope, a couple hours of play time aaand boom, you get to google why there is no where to progress, or why is this "LowLevelFatalError" crash message coming up this time. I have a 2080ti & 8700K and my girlfriend has a 980ti and Ryzen 7.  This game must not be optimized for med to higher end PCs, So play it on trash I guess.

author: De Nachtwacht
review: Because of all the positive reviews I'd like to balance things out a bit. Yes, the game is beautifully created and there are lots of details in it, great storyline and you can see that the team loved to create a beautiful piece of work. And they did. But still, I don't recommend this game for everyone.1. The game is too easy, especially the puzzles. It just gets boring if you're anything above the casual gamer or little kid. We experienced that already in the first playthrough.2. Replay value is zero. It's about 12-14 hours of gameplay max, and if you decide to replay with the other character it's a dissapointment too: not enough variation in playing style so we quit around 40% in the storyline the second playthrough.3. The payment model is quite stupid. Why not charge everyone €15,00 instead of €39,99 for one copy. This way, if friends A, B and C like the game, A has to buy the game, and HAS to play with B or C but B and C can't play together. That's €45 for the developer instead of 40 and more happy games too (I guess a lot of people would have bought the game, considering the "€1 per hour of gameplay when buying games" rule).

author: dpidz0r
review: The gameplay was ok, I really like the concept of a co-op focused game, and I really wanted to like this one, but the following issues caused me to request a refund:1) The linking with Origin was incredibly clunky at best, and doesn't play nicely with steam in big picture mode at all. I often had to relaunch multiple times, and it was a crapshoot if the game would actually start, or get stuck behind the big picture window, or have origin suddenly forget my saved login credentials (only to remember them on next launch). Launching the game but not pressing any inputs fast enough seemed to frequently result in the game terminating itself due to some issue with origin. Very frustrating having to keep putting the controller down and fiddle with the keyboard and mouse multiple times when trying to launch.2) Horrible controls lag. Even playing splitscreen locally on my monitor with a high framerate, there was a very noticeable delay between controller input and movement on screen. It felt almost like trying to play a game on a big TV that hasn't been set to gaming mode... except this was a 144hz gaming monitor. I suspect this may be the source of a lot of the other reviewers complaints of motion sickness.3) I get that it's got a nice story and people worked hard on it, but the animations for the cutscenes with the human parts of the story were stiff and really dipped heavily into uncanny valley territory, at least for me.

author: Freefall
review: It's a comedy game that isn't funny, it's a co-op game that requires almost no communication, it's a puzzle game that keeps throwing out and replacing its core mechanics instead of, you know, developing them...If this was the early 2000s and the story-driven 3D puzzle co-op game was some kind of new invention, I'd be more forgiving. As is, it's 2021 and I promise, this game invented nothing. You have options. Please, go play them instead and give this game a pass.If you're looking for a solid narrative, look elsewhere. I can't even recommend this game's writing on a "so bad, it's good" basis; it's bad comedy, so it's just annoying and boring. All of the one-liners were basically just observations, the banter is atrocious, and the game clearly thinks being mean-spirited is the same thing as having a dark sense of humor. The main characters are completely unlikable, which is unfortunate because we're saddled with them for the whole game. Oh, and the characters will solve the puzzles for you sometimes, by the way; there were several instances where my partner would make an observation at the same time as the character did.Honestly the game feels like it's a long series of ideas for other games. It's like a demo reel, except it's 12 hours long. I suspect that it's meant to parody or reference other properties (I saw some steampunk birds that strongly resembled the Songbird from Bioshock: Infinite???) but the game rarely found anywhere interesting to take the references and it mostly ended up being clutter in an already bloated game.The difficulty curve is all over the place. The puzzles themselves never really get more complicated than the first chapter and the co-op is generally very simple. There are a lot of puzzles that require one person to look at and relay a sequence to another player, but the constant split-screen makes it very easy to just...look over at the other player's screen for the code. Meanwhile, the platforming can spike to absurd difficulty levels without warning.My advice, save your money and your time. Don't waste either of them on this.

author: BetHer2Game
review: It Takes Two is very much a game I would consider as an early access game. This is not for bugs, but a seeming lack of consistent thought.This inconsistent thought happens on a multitude of fronts: the story and the game play and is a prime example of a failing in one aspect: transitions.Part 1: The StoryWhen introduced into this game, there is a consistent theme for a good few hour of the game, that the game is told from a kid's point of view, that they are re-enacting as a coping mechanism for divorce. This inherently comes with the assumption that this game is tailored to a kid’s point of view, and is sort of a coming-of-age story about understanding divorce. The graphics in this game provide a warm and alluring feel of something like Toy Story, in which it is a kid’s movie. It Takes Two contrasts this with graphic death scenes of a vacuum ripping out its own eyes, a very sexual love book that air humps and of course has a foreign accent for more sex appeal. The main characters plot to murder a child toy at one point at you play as you rip it apart. The parents of this kid go into a comatose, where… the kid somehow does not even notice or care to check in. However, the problems with this are that the plot does not make sense at all... If we are to take an adult’s approach, then while there can be a suspension of disbelief at talking animals, as this is a main mechanic of many story lines, you then must entertain a weird psychedelic trip inside a tree where there are space catfish. It is after this that our main characters have a space themed level in which they are in shock because a baboon can talk. The plot does not make much sense, as the main caretakers of the child go on a crusade to make her cry, to make themselves be turned back into humans. The story demonizes divorce as if it is a mechanic intended to harm the child, and that the parents should not get divorced, no matter how incompatible they are, or whether they have grown to no longer love each other. It has a surface understanding of divorce but wants the depth of an adult game.Part 2: The Game playMuch like the inconsistent story line, the game play suffers a similar fate. With a new mechanic being introduced every level or so, the ideas are not very fleshed out or directed to any purpose. The controls are not explained since the transitions happen so abruptly, and often the only queue for how something has changed is a camera angle (such as a fight with a squirrel) this could be easily remedied with more instructional pauses, like at the mini-games? However, for some reason this is not the case, as such right as you are about to learn the controls the game rips away that element of the game. Since none of these ideas are fleshed out either, the camera. gets weird, like when flying a machine on a turret out of a tree in one of the stages, the camera is based not only on your movements, but your partners. So, you do not really have control of what you see and must look at how your partners maneuvering and your own. There is a weird sense of vertigo and finnicky controls, and while I can applaud the fact that I haven’t found any bugsit isn’t a product I would seek out on my own.Part 4: ConclusionThis game is written like a improv drama, where everyone thinks they have a great idea. Much like an improv drama, not everyone has a great idea. It does not excel in any of the areas that it covers and cannot really recommend it to much of anyone. The storyline does not make sense, if this is for new gamers, this would be great as an introduction except for the fact that the game past the 2nd boss (toolbox)becomes wildly inconsistent with controls. As a gamer myself the queues are sometimes subtle and would not make sense to someone who has no understanding of game lingo. Such as firing nails at yellow painted objects. If it is someone who has gamed before there are better games with more fleshed out mechanics to understand in a clearer standalone context. It has an interesting aesthetic, but that is about it.

author: Not A Sandwich
review: A very upsetting story that forces you to spend a huge amount of time with characters that you hate, lead around by another character that you hate. Pretty fun gameplay elements, if you can get past the other stuff. I don't recommend that you try. Would have refunded if I wasn't having fun hanging out with my friend.Cons:- If you have any sort of motion sickness, you will not be able to play this game (the first person I played with had to quit very quickly).- The characters you play are immediately unlikable, and become progressively less likable over time.- Story beats feel unearned, because your characters never display they've learned anything, and continue to be bad people throughout the experience.- When you are forced to do something awful, the mood and state of the game/characters doesn't reflect that you just did something terrible. I felt like I was on an alien planet playing through this.- Your foil for moving forward in the story is a (maybe racist) caricature whose master plan is to manipulate and torture you until you kiss.- Moral of the story appears to be that if you get a divorce, you are selfish, and you must stay together or your kid will think it's their fault.- Some sexist stuff going on with male player character and another male character forcing the female player character to sing because they know what is best for her, as she asks them to stop and says 'no'.- Felt about twice as long to get through as it should be. Repeatedly, the person I was playing with and I found ourselves hoping that after this level it would be over. This could be because we didn't like the player characters and their foil. After finishing however, the first half of the game didn't seem necessary. Nothing happens that would impact the ending, just more hours of gameplay.Pros:- Some of the co-op puzzles were fun.- Pretty and interesting-looking set pieces.- Lots of opportunities to goof around and have fun with a co-op buddy.- Some MMO-style AoE dodging sections that were good.Spoilers ahoy! This section will contain all the terrible things your characters and the book man do that I can remember.

author: SmartassCody
review: First off, I streamed this game.My co-op partner was my younger brother. I would say we did enjoy moments during this game, but we had some issues as well. The biggest issue for me was that it was hard to place what the game was. As in, who was its target audience. If the game was more difficult, perhaps it would have been a better product overall. But it was very simple and played fast-paced, without much challenge.The caveat, as my twitch audience pointed out, is that the game WOULD be better suited, maybe, for a gamer and a significant other— instead of two experienced gamers. For us, as gamers, it would have felt punchier if it was a bit shorter. Full playthrough was 10.5 hours, and 6 would have been the sweetspot.If you want something to play with your girlfriend/wife/boyfriend/husband, that isn't an experienced gamer, then you might actually enjoy this game a bit more, and based on that I WOULD recommend it. There are moments you won't forget, either way. 4.75/10
